RATING: 8
A "gamer's game" with no luck, multiple paths to victory, and alot of very well designed interlocking ideas/parts, despite the generally unoriginal theme.  

This is a placement game, where you have to make tough decisions (including economic) as to where to place your workers, and they cost money to place, which is tight through alot of the game (potentially).  Do you collect resources (essential for building), do you build buildings (useful for scoring points, generating more points when others use your buildings, and provides a cheap building location for yourself), do you work on the castle (required for scoring points, and gaining royal favours, and also required or you lose points), do you try to rack up royal favours in the joust square, do you want to dirty other players (or prevent yourself from being dirtied) by controlling the provost, do you even have enough money to do anything?  

The tight economics, tile-laying strategy, resource management, perfect balance, and multiple options make this about as deep as it gets for a Euro.

The only real negatives are that it's a bit long (this can be bad when you're 30+ points behind, and there's an hour left to play), and although it plays 2-5, and is an outstanding 2-3 player game, you have to force me to play 4 players and I refuse to subject myself to a grinding 5-player game.

RATING: 6
Down from 8 to 6. A fine game, but I've lost my interest in playing it. In the long run the fairly low replay value, long play time and WP player screwage are weighing it down. 

Caylus is a brilliant design that epitomises the worker placement genre. At first glance it appears overwhelmingly complex, but there is a method to the madness and learning the mechanics and strategies is an interesting challenge. Once you do that, though, the game becomes an increasingly tedious and repetitive analysis-paralysis excercise.

Like most WP games, the main interaction comes from blocking other players and making mistakes is very costly. Caylus also has many mechanics that punish you for mistakes and by which the other players may screw you over. This can be very frustrating and causes serious AP issues as players try to calculate everything and avoid making a mistake while trying their best to calculate what others might be doing and how to wreck their plans. 

The game is very long (too long!) and playing it makes me feel like I just ran a marathon. It is challenging and interesting in a masochistic way. The game experience is highly frustrating and the only times the suffering feels justified is when you win. 

The iPhone app version is very well done. It has nice graphics and cuts the play time and bookkeeping down nicely. It still feels just as fiendishly frustrating to play as the original. Worth the money for everyone who enjoys the game.

RATING: 10
I especially like how setting up the 6 neutral buildings randomly at the beginning of each game affects the whole flavour of each individual game. It contributes to a high replayability, high complexity for determining optimal strategies, without randomization. This is one of the reasons I think this one will be played for a long time. The rules were remarkably clear for a game this complex (2nd edition).

In my opinion, it has a similar feel than both puerto rico (production building cash victory points cycle) and in the shadow of the emperor (selecting opportune favors, trying to place "better" than other players in castle building in each turn, buying worker placement vs. buying elector placement).

After a weekend of playing, my initial impression is that I like it better for 2 players than 3. In a 2 against 1 scenario there is not much that can be done against the provost, so there it can possibly be frustrating at times.

RATING: 8
2 plays / 3,5 players

LIKE: Tight resource game. great action selection track. Love how players can pass on their round to increase the action cost to others.
DISLIKE: if you are new, the combo strategies can be used against you. Lots of little rules with the building.
OVERALL: Great game, worthy of it's classic status. I felt the 5 players was great. My first game was fast, the Provost rarely went backwards. The game can get cutthroat, which increases the interaction, but could frustrate some players.

RATING: 8.5
I'm really split on this game.  I'll see where my thoughts go the more I play it.  So far, I've actually enjoyed it and yet...there are a few things about it I normally don't much care for in games: lack of player interaction (there's only the possibility of stitching another player up by combined Provost movement), overly puzzle-like game play, systematic procedures, lack of strategy (there's plenty of short term planning and the chance to have a starting aim - eg I'll go for gold or Castle building - but that's it).  Like most of this sort of game, keeping on top of your money supply is absolutely critical.

Other negatives are that some of the artwork is really dull and the game takes too long...3 to 4 hours depending how much AP there is.  If this was playable in 2.5 hours, it would be better for what it is - still, I suppose we've got Pillars of Earth (which I found vastly inferior) and Yspahan (which I like) for that.

And yet, I did like this, so what gives?  It must have something to save it from those faults above.

Hmm (scratches head)...I think it's the fact that there is SO much to think about.  Ok, so it's a bit puzzle-like and there is a system (buy this to get that), but even so, within that there seems to be a labyrinthine structure which I quite enjoyed.  And I like brain-burning games if they're not too unforgiving (that's where AoS falls down like a building in an earthquake for me).  In this one, you're never quite sure who's going to win because you can look behind and then come from nowhere.  Certain paths are slower burning than others.  I like that unpredictability - it makes up for the fact that there is no randomness in this (save for the set up).

So yeah, the game is a bit like problem solving, and normally that can be very dull, and yet, the problem solving here is so intriguing that I ended up liking it despite myself.

Even so, if the game was quicker and had just a wee bit more interaction, it would rate better for me.

A little bit more play has seen me raise this from a 7.5 to an 8.5

RATING: 8

Despite a long and complicated set of rules you are not always going to be doing everything at once and most of the phases of the game are far more simple than they seem to be. If anything bad can be said about this game is that there are often moments where someone is bribing the provost to screw over another player, but just the fact that you can bankrupt yourself to guarantee another player doesn't jump too far ahead is amazing.

RATING: 9.2
An exciting game if played with a group of friends who likes brain draining games.  This game makes you think a lot, 1 wrong move may led to losing many prestige points in the game.

It is also important to take note of the order on the activation of buildings, as it is always forgotten by players.

Good points: Many dimensions to the game, you need money to place the workers, resources to build buildings as well as the castle.  Royal favours can be really useful in the game too.  Provost is a good way to slow down a player's progress

Bad points: Nothing bad I can really pinpoint about except that it can really be brain draining.

After thought: A game that is really fun if you are a serious gamer, however i doubt that it will appeal to casual gamers.  My favourite game to this point of time and I would really recommend to all serious gamers.

RATING: 5
I finally played Caylus, and I must say that I like it better than Puerto Rico. Caylus is fairly balanced - one wrong move won't take you completely out of the game, since you receive money at the beginning of every round that you can use to place one or more workers on a building. The board is also intuitive (esp. vs. Puerto Rico).

Howver, my bf felt that he was "out of the game "pretty early, and thus didn't really enjoy playing. He says that it suffers from the Power Grid factor (slow, dull, and uninteresting). I can see why he says this, but we're both willing to give the game another go. 

*** UPDATE: I lowered my rating because my husband will never play this game again and I don't care for it that much. I much prefer Cuba and Agricola for my worker placement fix. ***

RATING: 9
Clásico juego de gestión de recursos, ambientado en la Europa medieval. Los jugadores han de colocar trabajadores en los diferentes edificios para contribuir a la construcción de un castillo. El juego es perfecto para 2-3 jugadores, a 4 ó 5 se descontrola bastante. Funciona muy bien, hay muchas estrategias a seguir, cero azar y bastante interacción entre los jugadores. Como nota negativa creo que en determinadas partidas al que se queda a la cola le cuesta mucho alcanzar al resto de los jugadores, es un juego que no perdona los fallos, pero jugado con gente que sepa jugarlo es una maravilla.Es un juego muy rápido de desplegar, que ocupa poco espacio en la mesa y que se disfruta desde el primer turno.
Uno de mis favoritos sin ninguna duda.

RATING: 6
Good game. But chunkiness. When I play it, I feel a lack of continuum. "Place workers. Execute special buildings. Move the provost. Execute all other buildings. Build the castle. Get the favor. Next round. Same thing." Not that this makes anything bad with the game itself, but it leads more to a feeling of tedium and certainly prevents me from enjoying it more than I do. But what's worse is the main game: cube management. That's not bad: what's bad is that the game has lots of other things going on that it seems to hide the fact that it is a cube management game. Moral: if a game is about X, make it seem like it is about X. For cube and card management, Macao is a great example. It doesn't pretend to be something else.

So great game, but I'm inclined to play others, like Troyes and Luna!

RATING: 7
Early worker placement game with relatively straightforward scoring.  The fun comes from the unique Provost/Bailiff tokens that move up/down and activate buildings.  So you might be the first to build at the end of the line, but other players can prevent you from activating that building this turn and thereby ruin your plans.  This gives you more influence over your opponents than just taking up spaces for their workers.

RATING: 10
2-5(3)

With two it's very tight. The game can be as rich or poor as you make it (depending on how soon players pass), and there are several strategies to pursue, and seemingly all of which require some attention. Castle batches, buildings (both production and point buildings), favors, etc. I like the perfect information, the breadth of the decision tree, the game of chicken, trying to plan a turn (grabbing the most desirable spots, often the production buildings) while risking a pass. The goods all have different applications but still seem reasonably balanced. Gold, hard as it is to get, seems really potent, though. Interesting how this takes a while but still moves quickly and often feels like it ends "too soon".

Some AP in going through all the buildings and, at least with two, the Provost is more a threat than anything (you're often very reluctant to pay to activate him).

RATING: 8
My wife and I learned this together using BSW then found friends with a copy.  After playing fairly often for about a month I was impressed, but not ready to give it a 10.  We had a hiatus then played again the other day, and the game had won me over... I can now safely say that I will never turn down a game of Caylus (short of injury or childbirth or something like that).  It is deeper and more interactive than Puerto Rico without the player order bugs.  I'm a big fan of synergistic games with combinatorially many ways of combining components, but usually they suffer from some combinations being significantly stronger than others.  I have to be careful with that sentence because I think that many people might think that some combinations really are super-strong in Caylus (especially in 2p games), but I think that the game forces you to always interact with your opponents, it's not solitaire...  Anyway, this is the first 10 I've given out since my honeymoon period with board gaming.  I think I feel it strongly enough to want to downgrade some other rankings just to make this one stick out more.  I started to wonder why this game wasn't rated higher, but I saw a post saying it reached number 2 before some sort of backlash brought it back down to earth... This game is the chess/go of Eurogames, makes me feel like you could spend a long long time studying it and still finding depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Goodlooking game, but - as goes for so many eurogames - a collection of game mechanics to create fuzz in order to prevent players from determining an optimal strategy, so that the lesser gods can keep up. 

The provost is a game mechanic that doesn't really work. Players are rarely willing to pay for it and if they do if the occasion arrise it can have large consequences if you are in the wrong player order. Besides the major will move anyway. 

I don't like the pass mechanism, which makes labourers disproportionally more expensive. 

Caylus is not unpleasant to play and does have some strong game mechanics, such as the tile laying one. But I haven't seen any of the more expensive ones on the board and I wish  that this mechanic have been done in a more natural way. The reason? See the first paragraph! 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Amazing worker placement game. Very well balanced. The rules are quite easy to teach for a game this complex. The rulebook is very clear. Players are supposed to be master builders trying to build a castle for the King. The game is highly interactive. You can play with the turn order, with the game length and you can try to screw your opponents by using the provost pawn. Many paths to victory, many ways to score VPs, many options to choose from. The "King's favours" mechanic seems very interesting. The random initial setup adds a bit to the replayability. 
Minor issues: the theme is not as strong as I would like and keep in mind that some players might not like the provost mechanic cause it makes the game quite cutthroat (for a euro).

I’ve gone all out with this game! I’ve bought the second edition but have additionally bought: -

*The metal coins and black purse
*Larger 10mm resource cubes
*Gold bar tokens to replace the gold resource cubes
*A small compartmentalised storage container for the resources
*Extra houses as to not run out during a game
*Extra residencies
*The Jeweller tile
*Some favour tins to hold the tiles

RATING: 8.8
I've seen Caylus described as 'dry' many times, and maybe the components aren't overflowing with amazing color and artwork, sure, but despite all that...this seems to really hold up as a paragon of the worker placement genre. Lots of little considerations, playing on your own or other players' buildings, working to score in one of the Castle sections. I also really dig the movement of the Provost and Bailiff, and the rather elegant and simple flow of most actions taken. I'm late to the party on this, but there is no question why it was such a popular game, and you will find its DNA in many hundreds of Euros to follow.

I absolutely love the turn angst when deciding where to place my workers or which favor to choose.  Highly recommended.  

Update: Caylus has dropped 4 points.  My most recent play was much too long, and hoping that a game will end just so the repetition will cease is not a good sign.  Games with similar complexity usually have rules that inspire curiosity and excitement; explaining Caylus' rules just inspires a dull, glazed look.  I still think that some of the game's mechanics are spiffy, but it just plays too long, and this is coming from someone who thinks that three hours of Power Grid rocks!

Things I don't like:

- very few special buildings are built (1 or 2) per player, sometimes none.

- you never build the road all the way 'till the end.
- the last buildings to be build near the end of the game will most likely never get to be used.

RATING: 5
I was skeptical when I opened the box and glanced at the rules.  Playing the game made all the difference in the world.

The game flows very naturally.  All the information you need is printed on the board and tiles.  There is no language dependence so they could have printed it in Russian and it still would have been fully accessible.

The interaction between players is somewhat transparent, but it is clearly there.  Buying buildings and getting bonuses when other people use them is a genuis implementation.  While I did not feel a "squeeze" in resources in the game like I would expect with a resource management game, decisions were extraordinarily difficult to make.  I wanted to do everything, but I didn't want to allow my opponents to do the stuff I didn't take.

The game is quite enjoyable.  My only complaint is the play time, which honestly, I didn't notice go by, however if I am planning a game night, that is a large block of time to allocate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great open information system game with multiple paths to victory (favor track, castle building, gold hording, upgrade building, cash-to-VP conversion). The game certainly is on the long side of the spectrum and has some potential for analysis paralysis. After some familiarization with the game however, decisions should become more obvious and rapid.  

I really enjoy the tension as players race to get to key areas of the board, either for resources, cash, favors, or VPs. This keeps all players constantly involved and immersed in the game. In addition, the game scales well from 2 to 5 in my opinion (certainly as well as PR). The 2 major knocks against the game are the longish playing time and the fairly static valuation of the different areas on the board which can make the game a bit repetitive. 

Dropped rating from 9 to 8 as it does run a little bit too long for my tastes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Classic game that still holds up. The simplicity, variety of decisions and, of course, the provost seem to be the keys to excellence. I do worry a bit that, despite the analysis you need to do to win (assuming players are equally skilled), the layered mechanisms obfuscate dominant strategies. However, the control the players get over the game's pacing and what resources end up being scarce alters the calculus enough for me to, for the most part, ignore that feeling. Still, I've yet to have a game where the winner didn't go up the influence royal favor track. 

The interactivity between the players and pace control keeps you entirely engaged. Further, you want to play again once you finish. Though, I do wish there was a way to cut 10-15 minutes from its playtime (most games are 90-120 minutes, though you can get it down closer to 60-75 with 2 players). This does feel unlike most other worker placement games I've played.

RATING: 7
Will I ever tire of winning the King's Favor?  I highly doubt it for not even Agricola has diminished my enthusiasm!   The order in which the buildings are built, the Provost movement, and the fight (or lack of a fight) for favors will probably keep this game from becoming stale anytime soon. So far no two sessions have played out the same, which is awesome since Caylus is a perfect information sort of game.  
  
The main downside to Caylus is the hard-to-follow rulebook, but Ystari games provides an easy-to-follow rules summary online.  The other downside to Caylus is that it doesn't scale as well as Agricola.  I love the control in a 2-player game.  I also love the player/provost interaction in a 3-4 player game.  Unfortunately, the 5-player game feels more tedious for your choices are rather limited.  With experienced players this game shouldn't take longer than 60-120 minutes.

RATING: 8
Not sure what to say about this one that has not already been said elsewhere. Suffice to say I spent about 4 years or so knowing about this gem and hearing about it, reading about it, and avoiding it. Only because there were so many others I was enjoying I did not want to blast through the current heavyweights, I wanted to savor it. 

With all the hype of a good 2.75 years behind it, that first play with other newbs being taught by a seasoned vet between TWO tables, was what Board Gaming is all about to me: Superb, clever, funny, and just deep enough to have a table full of ADULT gamers on their toes. The simplistic elegance of playing the game well is fantastically hidden in a system and art that actually concedes a bigger scale than is really on tap. Nearly unspeakable was my own glee when I "got it" not the last at the table to grasp, but not the first either, was just right to me. 

Elegance deontes to me in a Board game one that can convey its theme and sense of purpose in spite of the bits and bobs in the box or on the table, and I am ever appreciative of those designers/Publishers who deliver on this. 

Caylus IS this to me, and will for a long time be that to me. 

That I do not own a copy is not nearly as telling as is the fact that I unwilling to own such a Gem when there is much to my collection as it stands that has yet to be played.

They would not see time at all!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPDATE: it is sinking rapidly on my list, and on not my list alone by the sound of it (8.5>7.5>7). It feels more and more like a progressive resource management game akin to Settlers on the PC, except that the fun-pyramid has been turned upside-down. A PC takes over the boring calculating-in-the-background-bit, to allow players to concentrate on all the action and excitement. Here I keep feeling like the computer making all the boring little programmed advancement steps, and I suspect it is [i]the game[/i] that is having all the fun. Throw the marble in at the top, watch it all click and tick, and observe how clever it comes out at the other end. But a good chef knows what ingredients to leave out to make it taste distinct. What we have here is a brainy mechanism soup with one or two too many bits thrown in that thorough playtesting should have thrown out.

I especially don't like the hoarding factor that allows a capable leader to bully players out of catching up moves through sheer castle wall + favour monopolies alone. It also has caught the worst aspect of chess, in that it only makes sense to play players of similar abilities. With the observation that at least with chess you only need one more to have a balanced game. The problem starts with the layout of the board. If the castle and favour track had been placed in the centre, it's importance would have been more intuitive. Now they have been squeezed into a fifth on the side. Downtime can take silly proportions, not helped by a game group that has some players who cannot get themselves to make a move if it isn't the best one. [i]Now if the next player placed there and .....[/i] Peculiarly, and leaving the time to get there aside, it seems to start to get interesting when it ends. Bored already and it is still a few turns short. Strange. I'm starting to suspect Caylus is the reason why someone invented the computer 40 years earlier. So there was no need for it. It takes too long without enough fun, to do too little.

I still think it can be a decent game for comparable players in the right mood with less to choose from, and I am sure some people have had memorable experiences, but I have completely gone off it.

OLD COMMENTS:
First play could be typified by turn-by-turn realizations along the lines of "make mental note not to do that ever again", "ah, that's how it works" and "I should have planned that better". Second one just under my belt and has been plain sailing. Played with one new player and we played one trial round before kicking off proper, wished that had been done for my virgin game as well.

p: This game is inevitably gonna suffer from the same problem I had with Puerto Rico. It has already been praised sky-high, so my initial impression will be measured against mythical expectations. Not fair, but hard to avoid. It probably means that small faults will bring it down a bit further on my scale than it maybe deserves. 

And indeed, like Puerto Rico, my initial response is favourable, but not THAT much. Don't get me wrong, I'll happily play this as it incorporates a lot of elements that get my juices flowing, but it also has elements that keep it well away from my perfect 10. Downtime being the main one. I have played many, many games that thrilled me as least as much on a first play. And it aren't always the flawless games that give me the greatest joy either. Furthermore, this one doesn't offer enough new elements to me to make it particularly stand out, even though it does integrate them very well indeed. Yup, it's high on my hill of great games too, but surely it's not the top ?!

In Settlers the PC game it can be frustrating to hang around with nothing to do until the sawmill has spit out the next plank for the next building for the next resource, but at least you can speed it up. Here you can only stack your resource cubes in new and interesting ways, until all other players have pondered in turn over the perfect information on the table. And whilst it is fantastic that there is quite a bit you can do with your dobbers, only a few are genuinely worth considering, meaning it can feel a bit "programmable".

It also doesn't have the sort of player interaction I like best, as apart from blocking players off their preferred locations, there is not a lot you can do to engage with them. No trading, no negotiating, and no way to mess around with people's hoards. Settlers improves a lot because of the threat of losing half your card resources, making it much more risky to produce powerful combo moves or hang back for that ideal option. Here, with acquired resources safely in the hand, people who carve out a slender lead probably also carve out the option to make more powerful follow-ups, whilst stragglers will keep struggling to acquire the right materials to catch up. Some people will love all that. I don't.

Also a bit worried to see players frequently make the same move combos, just in different phases. One player executes a tile combo with the next player in line preparing for the exact same combo in the next turn, whilst number three realises he's frozen out for now but is gonna make damn sure to sit in the preparation slots next turn. I hope it is more "what to do in what turn", rather than "what turn to do IT in".

On the plus side, I'm a big fan of games where people "bid" for turn order, and the cost of giving up a valuable action slot can be hefty and is a nice twist. I welcome the semi-random set-up and the way to speed up or slow down game progress. With an overdose of resources for development mechanisms on offer any big fans of a well done acoustic settler's pc game will have their pleasure points tickled. And Caylus is certainly challenging and full of great dilemmas. Using the same materials for so many mechanisms is done elegantly, but maybe I would enjoy it more if there was slightly less you could do by yourself. For the downside of so many options is that people will wait until their own turn before they start thinking, and for the 2+ hours you'll invest,  you don't get that many turns. I don't feel that the excitement during your turn is enough to forget the thumb twiddling between turns, even if it's suicide not to pay attention to your opponent's moves.

I am pleased that for once the general excitement of the (easy excitable) gaming community is blasting a small designers' outfit into the outer stratosphere. But that a relatively hard to get game has found itself centre stage says probably more about the output quality of the bigger companies. The lack of imposing titles from the usual suspects has meant that the "next new thing" gamers have been allowed to drift. Add to that the directional power of the wildfire buzz generated on places like BGG and the result? What, call yourself a gamer and you haven't played this yet? I'm sure you are  looking for a way to fill that "big empty void" as soon as you can.

There seems to be a tendency to quest for the ultimate game by some geeks over here, often with lengthy discussions about its perfections, something I will never understand. Maybe I do like gaming and games more than game titles. I have noticed that in our group too, there often seems to be an unwritten short-list of hot games to seek out, invisibly herding general opinion towards a handful of new releases. There was a small outcry when they discovered I had owned a copy of PR for two years without touching it. As if I was missing out on something. They should have seen my face when I opened my red Hilly Billy tube!

Relying on general opinion all adds up to top 100 lists of favourite albums dictated by people who on the whole probably couldn't name 100 albums between them. There is nothing wrong with that. Just don't take those lists too seriously. And if you really want to discover what is out there, it is often wiser to find the discerning voice. Seems I'll just have to accept that this will be the  Beatles' "White Album" for a while. And for that reason alone it no doubt will be remembered that way too.  A classic! But proclaimed by whom and compared to what?

RATING: 7
Resource management game, where actions, money and goods are used to collect victory points.
Interesting is that actions give money and goods, money gives actions and sometime goods and VP too, while goods are needed to VP but also can be used to collect money. Difficult to assess a winning strategy.
A lot of replay value, as players will score part of their points to build houses that will score VP, and will give to everybody their benefit. How much a building is useful depends by the construction order and by which other buildings have been done.
No luck apart starting order that can be managed.
Meaty.

RATING: 5
Caylus, despite any other pretenders, is the true successor of Puerto Rico.  The similarities are truly uncanny.  Like Puerto Rico, Caylus is on the whole more of a short-term optimization game than a long-range strategic one.  The mechanics also bear a striking similarity, if not in fact at least in feel.Most importantly and most unfortunately, both reach a certain threshhold of plays before it feels like a dessicated husk of the game you once loved.  Puerto Rico hit this barrier after a very respectable number of plays; Caylus did not manage the same dignity.  As I approached ten plays, the repetition and stagnancy of the worker placement phase drove towards tedium.  For all its pretensions of variability, Caylus never procures enough to significantly alter your paradigm within a game, let alone between them. So Caylus has dropped from its lofty perch and we shall see if it continues to fall.

RATING: 6.5
2 plays.  It's not the best thing since sliced bread so don't be fooled by the phenomenal rating... but it's a pretty good game.  Steep learning curve for newbies.  I tried to be the "builder of useful buildings" to earn lots of points, but that was difficult to do as a newbie.  Getting the free favors for building the most pieces of the castle seems important... much like making the best offering in Amun-Re to get the most bonus actions.

UPDATE 2014:
With 7 plays logged... The reason I dislike the game is the provost.  It annoys me to have to guess where the provost will end up and to have to hope (and/or ride coattails) to not get negatively impacted.  Early in the game there's some rather petty blocking of actions... actions that nobody will give a rat's pituty about just a few turns later... this really burns me for some reason.  It's a solid (and very strategic/calculating) game if you don't mind dry, set collection/cube-pushing games... and you can tolerate the damn provost.  My tolerance level increases if I play multiple times in a short period of time and the rules, mechanics and strategies are fresher in my mind... otherwise I just get heated and annoyed by people hitting me with the provost and snaking the favors.  Sarah likes b/c she feels there are many ways to win and you don't need to focus heavily on the favors.  I'm not sure, but I won recently by focusing on making buildings and making only the minimum 2 houses per castle area (and got only 5-6 favors for the entire game).

Jonathan68 on BGG says:
Since Caylus is 10 years old now and is one of the founding fathers of worker placement games, a lot of it’s mechanics aren’t unique. What keeps Caylus relevant and what makes it stand apart is the arrangement in which it uses those mechanics. Here are a few notable points: (1) Caylus has a balance of strategy and tactics not often seen in games these days. Like any game you have to adapt to what’s going on to maximize your points but you have a lot of freedom to approach the game in widely different ways. Rarely is there ever a strategy you can’t use because you were muscled out of the spaces and resources you need; there are multiple paths to victory and multiple ways to go about those paths. (2) Caylus gives more workers than most. The aforementioned point is partly because each player gets 6 workers and because there are a lot of spaces that provide the resources you need. This gives you a lot of options, especially as the game moves into the final rounds. (3) Caylus has a lot more player interaction than most Euros. The ever changing turn order, the race to resource spaces, the limited space in the castle sections, the influencing of the provost, even the lack of individual player boards, all create a very engaging experience with your opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a phenomenal game.  It's very fun to have to stay on your toes and keep shifting your strategies depending on other players' moves during the 'placing of workers' phase.  I also like how you can attempt to speed up the game or slow down the game depending on how well you're doing (how the bailiff moves), and in general, it's nice to get a sense of how long the game is going to take.  It's also nice to get a clear sense of how everyone is doing at all times...unlike Tigris and Euphrates, Settlers of Catan (with people hiding their VP cards), Puerto Rico (difficult to calculate how many points people have) and even Carcassone (since it's not so easy to read the farmland).

RATING: 6
I will say now that my rating is based on our first and only play so far, but based on that experience, my desire to play it again soon is low. There are a number of other things I would much, much rather play, though perhaps my rating would go up after more plays.

In short, we found the lack of money in the beginning far more frustrating than either fun or challenging. It feels like you have to claw your way out of a hole from the beginning, and one good screw on a turn (say, by the evil provost, a lack of money and a bad position in the turn order), can set you back two turns before you recover. Intricate, yes. Strategic depth, certainly. Painful, absolutely, excruciatingly so. In the end, I didn't feel so much like I'd had fun, more like I'd been put through a wringer washer a couple times - and I didn't finish in last place (of course, I didn't win, either). Will try again some other day and re-evaluate the rating!

See my notes of "Scepter of Zavandor" for a related thought about the evil starting conditions in these games.

RATING: 4
Good game - with 5 problems:

1. Game Length, it runs a little longer than I'd like, probably because you have perfect information so analysis paralysis can set in. If you have anyone in your game group with this afliction avoid this game or settle down for a long wait between turns! With slow players you might want to avoid playing with 5

2. Graphics - the icons on the tiles are pretty small, especially the building costs and the colours aren't that distinct, causing some players problems
 
3. Money - ugh, horrible plastic disks, and they give you 5's and 1's but most of the time you never need 5's - and the mix is off, more 1's are needed. [fixed with the 2nd printing, but doesn't help me ...]

4. 3 Player - this seems to suffer like many games in that it isn't so great with 3. With 3 if one of your opponents starts competing with you for something (buildings, type of cube, favors, castle building etc) then the player who's doing something else will probably win. Yes you can try to switch strategy mid-game but it's not ideal. Not such a problem with 4,5 and non-existant with 2.

5. Gets rather repetitive - each turn is similar and given the length it can drag a bit, especially if your group has any players who suffer AP :( More I play it the less I like it.

But negatives aside, there's lots of decisions to make and various strategies to follow, and you have to plan for the next turn in the current turn (money needed, cubes needed etc). Not at the stage where it would hit the trade pile 

** update, now played the card game version - much prefer that, and now Caylus is traded for the card game version. Doubt I'll ever play it again.

*** Update, played again, wasn't that great, I can see why others like it, but I don't find it very enjoyable, I just wanted the game to end (not a good sign), dropped my rating, doubt I'll play this again (but I said that last time!)

RATING: 3
I must admit to some surprise that Caylus has both gotten so much acclaim and held its appeal for so long; we'll see if things hold up after the second printing. The game is neat in spots, and has interesting stuff, but at the end of the day it's klunky, inelegant, highly derivitive, poorly-themed, unevenly paced, excessively-analytical, and much too long. Caylus is a classic eurogame in that it's all about taking some resources and turning them into other resources or using them to compete for victory points in some way. Some of the techniques with which they've done this are clever. But the good eurogames take these basic ideas and give them some spark of artistic creation, an idea that breathes life into it somehow: either a well-done theme, as in Settlers; the excitement of Beowulf; or a clever central driver, like Puerto Rico; or something like that. Or it's a design which is in and of itself elegant and artistic, like a Through the Desert. Caylus has no spark. It's entirely mechanical and processional, constrained and technical, without life - which would be much more forgivable were the game not of ungodly length, 3  hours with 5 players if players take any time to think about their moves at all.

This is the core complaint about Caylus, I think, but there is more: there is brutal and completely unnecessary kingmaking with the Provost and some buildings. There are way-too-fiddly mechanical details, like the costs to operate buildings. The Royal Favors are unbalanced. Many buildings are unbalanced. The game lacks variability, tension, or excitement.

I've had differences of opinion with the BGG raters on a number of games: Bang! I thought was hideous, Carcassonne is overrated, Puerto Rico is a fine game but far from #1, and Scrabble and Beowulf are both criminally under-rated. But many of those I could easily ascribe to taste, with my idea of what makes a good game being different from most people's. This is the first game for which I think the raters here are delusional. Caylus is, at best, a second-tier game. Mechanically interesting, it still manages to lack almost everything that a good game should have.

RATING: 4
Updated 6/7/10.  (Rating based on one 2-player game.)

Oh how I wanted to like Caylus. I finally got to play it, after what feels like months of trying, but, sadly, the game was a bit disappointing. I’ll admit at the outset that I’ve been slightly biased against the game because of the dry theme, drab artwork, and sub-par components (and, indeed, many of the houses and workers were significantly deformed). I’ll also admit that I was thoroughly destroyed in my first game, which likely left a bitter taste in my mouth. But, alas, I think my problems with Caylus run a bit deeper. 

My biggest critique was that the game was simply “all work and no play.” The game was sufficiently abstracted that collecting and spending cubes of various colors lacked any sense of meaning to me.  The issue isn't so much a lack of theme for its own sake (I have no doubt that the game contains plenty of subtle thematic chrome), but rather the importance of theme in providing contextual gameplay cues.  Caylus lacked those contextual clues for me.  Maybe I build Random Building X and put my blue house on it. I don't really have a sense of what that means. Was it a good move? What do I do with it now? Will people use it other than me? Do I want them to? Did I just flood the game with pink cubes? Should I try to eliminate other sources of pink cubes? Is that even an efficient strategy? Or should I just take the pink cubes and go build the castle? Do I want to build the castle? It gets me some VP. But so would building another Random Building. But that one produces blue cubes... I ended up getting lost in a sea of seemingly unrelated information each turn because I couldn't intuit a strategy without a stronger sense of thematic integration.

Not surprisingly, much of our gameplay time was simply spent staring intently at the board, counting, recounting, processing, and then recounting again; this may be the single-most paralyzing game that I’ve played. Indeed, the experience didn’t feel so much like gaming, as it felt like we were both trying to reverse-engineer the spreadsheet that (hypothetically) the designer used to balance the game. 

In addition, the game allows for significant interference with other players: spending money to block their actions, occupying buildings they want, building buildings before they do, and out-building them at the castle to snatch a royal favor from under my their nose. The resulting dynamic, combining luckless play, deep and challenging strategy, and intentional interference with your opponent, makes the game feel a bit like a chess match. I hate chess. In our game, there was a moment halfway through the game where it was obvious that I had lost, badly. Not only was it simply demoralizing for future rounds (the game lacks any sort of catch-up mechanic), but it’s hard not to internalize such losses as a sort of personal failing when the game is perfect information. In short, Caylus is a gamer’s game that makes me feel inadequate as a gamer.

For a similar experience that is much more thematic and more satisfying, I recommend Le Havre. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The original worker placement that stood the test of time and is still going strong today. In typical Euro fashion, players must gather resources, and construct buildings to score victory points. Money is very tight in this game having to pay for each worker you place leads to very difficult decisions. I also really enjoyed the favors for a bit of customization between players. RATING: 7
Certainly the many possibilities in this game are intriguing. The game has a strategic depth that few other Euros offer. I can see why it is threatening to unseat the king of resource management games - Puerto Rico. I'd personally probably choose Caylus over PR if in a true game environment and equipped with sufficient time.

Much as say the university in PR, some parts of Caylus may not be too well balanced. The goods favour track is inferior to the other choices, I should say.

Thematically, I feel the game leaves me wanting. For this sort of complexity, I don't think the theme is conveyed in a sufficiently immersive manner. I'm thinking far more in a resources and assets mode than getting the castle-building vibes. In the Shadow of the Emperor or even El Grande strike me as thematically more immersive.

Good game, for sure. Great game? Well, if I were an American (who do seem to use the term in an inflationary manner) I'd probably agree. But as I'm not, I'd probably point to the game not posessing quite the excitement I wish for. It's simply a more calculational game - in that regard not unsimilar to Goa and Princes of Florence - neither being games I'm terribly fond of.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First of all a big "thank you" to Caylus for being one of the inspirations for Agricola, my favorite game! The two games share a similar worker placement mechanic, but other than that they are very different.

Caylus is an old worker placement game, probably one of the very first of its kind, but it still holds up!

The "snake pattern" is awesome as you need to think about in which order you get the resources - oh how many times I've been witness to somebody who went for the king's favor without having cloth, or wanted to build a building before they got the stone etc...

I also like the fact that you only have a handful or workers or so which means that you need to think carefully about where to place them - and in most WP games you can place all of your workers, but in this one you cannot if you don't have enough money! So you also need to juggle your income. The passing mechanism is great as well as it makes it much more expensive for the remaining players to place their workers, so the rounds usually end quickly once one or two players have passed.

The favors are a good idea as they are ways of specializing, and it doesn't seem like any of the favor tracks are better than others. The race for delivering batches makes the game even more tense!

Finally, the provost (and the bailiff) is what really makes the game intense! You cannot just jump ahead and get the benefit of the newly built and better buildings as your opponents can move the provost behind - which means that the buildings ahead won't get activated and you have lost those actions! That can be devastating, so you better be careful...

I like Caylus better with fewer rather than many players as you have much more control of what is happening, and due to Caylus being quite a heavy and thinky game AP is much worse with 4 and 5 players.

RATING: 10
An excellent game.  This game can get rather complicated, but once the game play becomes consistent, there are patterns that develop over time.  

Do not become overly frustrated with the rulebook.  Yes, it is poorly written and difficult to grasp at times.  That should not deter you from attempting the game - it is that good of a game.  Try as best as you can to wade through the rulebook and play a game with at least one other person who is familiar with the rules and can walk you through it.  It becomes intuitive after one or two rounds.

Strategy, on the other hand, is not as intuitive.  Luckily, the seating position does not have a detrimental impact on the game like PR does.  It will take you a few games to develop a winning strategy, but the gameplay experiences of playing while developing that strategy makes this game a winner.

Overal, an excellent game, and definitely something I would play again.

RATING: 6
Rated "7" after one play. By the time I played this "modern classic," I already had at least six other worker placement games under my belt. Surprisingly, there's still a bit about Caylus that I enjoyed. I like how you have to pay to place workers. And, the moving provost (or baliff? Or something?) offers a nice "screw you" factor that leads to some tense decisions. I also totally dig how the early sections of the road become obsolete, with new buildings cropping up later on. And, mooching VPs when others use your hard earned spot is also nice.

At the same time, the theme is thin. Given the choice, I'd still choose Carson City or Age of Empires III for that worker placement style. The first two offer far better theme, and all three offer a greater degree of interaction, whether it's fighting for plots of land in the west, or regions in the New World, or factions in ancient Rome. Still, I admire what Caylus essentially got started. These worker placement games are the "bees knees."

RATING: 6
:sugar: :( :) :D :D :)

UPDATE 5/15: This got traded away a while ago (it just didn't get played -- mine is not a WP-heavy group, and I when I do get the urge for WP I, as I mentioned, tend to reach for Le Havre or Agricola, so Jones Theory and all that) but I keep pounding away at the iOS version of the game and it really is quite a treat of a game -- smart, interesting, and rich with possibilities without provoking sensory overload. This game is a bit of a slow burn -- it feels very samey when you first get into it -- but with further exploration you begin to see the possibilities inherent in different arrangements of buildings on the road and different ways to use the Provost to suck money from your fellow players' coffers, etc.

I do suspect that a game among people who have all mastered their strategy will come down to a simple question of execution, but there's a lot of climbing to do before you summit. If you can't figure out why you would ever put a meeple on the gate, you're still a beginner.

--

Scratches a pretty specific itch -- Caylus is worker placement made pure, with no extrinsic luck elements (apart from the placement of the six starting buildings and inital player order) or hidden information to get in the way of the raw test of skill. All the other heavy WP games I've played (Agricola more than Dominant Species more than Le Havre) have at least a little bit of luck or incomplete information. The game takes advantage of one of my favorite mechanics, wherein the players organically expand the scope of possible actions available not only to them but to others by building new buildings. (Compare Brass and Le Havre, which do the same thing.)  And the game is a true test; a brain burner with a lot of things going on, and working out a clever plan gives the player that warm fuzzy sense of satisfaction that good Euro games give you. 

That's the good news.

The bad news is the unintuitive rules, the paper-thin theme, and the easily-forgotten maintenance players must do to keep the game going. I played this on iOS devices before I played it in the flesh, and I was more sold on the game in computer form, since the computer did all of the busywork for me. This is a good and important game, and a landmark of game design. But if I want a worker placement game, my inclination is to reach for Le Havre or Agricola before this one, at least most of the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
OK, two things.

A.  This is a really terrific game. Full of nastiness, it's really about being the toughest bully on the block, beating down your opponents. A very destructive game but a very solid one too.
B.  The theme is unacceptably lame.

What needs to happen is somebody needs to retheme this baby to something with a little more razzle-dazzle.  I think I'm the one to do it.

Players in "American Idol: The Journey" represent one of five celebrities from the hit FOX game show.  Kelly Clarkson, Ruben Studdard, Clay Aiken, Fantasia Barrino, and Carrie Underwood have all won the grand prize, but where do they go from here?  We'll track their progress over the course of three years, each ending in the Grammy Awards.  Whoever has sold the most records by the end of the third awards ceremony is the winner!

Our stars have to balance their efforts between recording singles ('craft buildings') and doing PR events ('castle building').  Either activity sells records, but Clay's going to need to balance his efforts.  If anybody completely ignores the PR effort, not only will he be forgotten come Grammy time, but they will actually LOSE reccord sales!

These tarts have some nasty tricks up their sleeve, and aren't afraid to pay to have nasty rumors published in Page Six, Defamer, Gawker, and the like.  This underhanded behavior is abstracted easily and effortlessly ('provost') and can potentially ruin a girl's entire plans for the next month or so.

Toward the third year, our stars begin to run out of ideas.  Often, to keep themselves in the running they will expend massive amounts of Street Cred ('gold cubes') to put out a Remix Record ('prestige building').  The Cred is worth a lot if you can hold onto it, but sometimes it's best to just cash in, especially if Kelly Clarkson is angling to do the same!

One single worth mentioning is the megahit "Since U Been Gone" ('Church').  Sure, Kelly recorded it in real life, but this game lets anybody release this hot single.  When this track drops, the artist responsible can immediately get tons of cash, sell even MORE records, get a great review on Pitchfork ('street cred,' or 'resource track'), or immediately drop ANOTHER single which is also guaranteed to hit the top of the charts.

THAT game would sell to Americans.  It's not that nobody is interested in or capable of playing good games, it's that I am too embarassed to tell half my friends that I enjoy activities where I pretend I'm a fucking 'master builder' in the days of King Philip the Fair.  Idol worship might not be that much better, but it's a step in the right direction.

-------------

About BSW.  This game is fantastic there.  In larger games you lose the ability to quickly make provost deals with other players, which is unfortunate.  However, if you play with groups where personal politics play an unfortunate role ("I don't want to screw him over this early, he'll have a vendetta against me for the rest of the game!"), the mostly-silent BSW environment basically negates this aspect.  I haven't played enough multiplayer on BSW to tell how adversely this affects play among mid-level players (experts won't need table-talk and novice decisions are arbitrary enough that it shouldn't matter either way), but I'll keep my eye out.

Two player is another story.  My preferred opponent and I have played this a few dozen times on BSW and we're down to about thirty minutes.

Caylus really provides two games in one box: the 2-player and multiplayer game.  Both are exquisite.  The game scales very well from 3-5, although either your tolerance for multiplayer chaos or your group's willingness to collude and negotiate needs to go way up for each player you add over 3.

Unfortunately it's not American Idol-themed, but it's the best we've got right now.  Anyone interested in low-to-no-luck games that hold up well to lengthy analysis should look seriously at Caylus.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Caylus has a lot of familiar mechanisms from previous games but combines them in a very fresh way. A zero luck, heavier medium weight Euro that features the special buildings of Puerto Rico and the resource gathering and competition of Keythedral and then adds in yet another thing to invest in in the form of an area influence contest at the castle which hands out one time bonuses. The core of Caylus is extremely tactical worker placement which is a straight pull from Keythedral, but it ends up being slightly more interesting because there is more than just goods cubes up for grabs, and the goods cubes themselves can generate VPs in more than one way. I will say, right here though, that this game has started to descend in my personal ratings. I was a very solid 9 for quite some time, but then it was down to an 8, and now it is at 7 because I think Agricola does the things I like here in a more enjoyable and variable way.

To me, the biggest strength of Caylus at first blush was the variability of play due to the way buildings are placed on the board. The initial seeding of buildings stays the same, but the order in which players voluntarily build changes the complexion of the game considerably from outing to outing. Games that are gold rich are considerably different from ones that are cloth rich, and so on. Lately though, I think I've started to not feel that way as much. Certainly, what you can do in a game that is gold poor is different, but it doesn't really feel all that different to me anymore. Unlike Puerto Rico's buildings, the ones in Caylus really don't seem to severely augment the game state that much because in Caylus, the various types of cubes really aren't all that important because you can probably find something useful to do with any of them. What this means, tactically speaking, is that grabbing cloth or spam isn't a hard choice because in many cases, it doesn't matter that much at all. If you're planning on building something out of stone be sure to have stone. By the late game be sure to grab some gold and a lot of one or another thing, but tactically, which is the level that this game operates on almost full time, your priority through most of the game should just be to hoard stuff, and to blow at least some of it on the king's favour track so that you can get the bonus favours and the victory points from the work. I think the game has been hurt somewhat in the long run as well by my disillusionment with the buildings you can put up...I used to actually ponder one over another, but at this point it seems clear there are two things that really matter: 1) the victory points you get immediately. 2) If it comes with a favour (because these generally let you build more buildings (if you're on the building track at least, and you probably should be if you want to win) which will net you even more victory points. Oh, and in the case of the blues, 3) Whether or not it generates income for you. Upon discovering this, my opnion of Caylus took a bit of a dip, because the game suddenly felt much more limited than it did previously.

That's the bad, so why does this game still get an 7? The bottom line is that this is still a resource gathering, neighbour screwing good time in the tradition of Keythedral but with more gamey stuff added onto it. There are a lot of interesting minor tactical decisons on when and where to place dudes, how much to bribe (and when), and how to go about accomplishing certain things. It definitely doesn't stand out at the level of a Puerto Rico in terms of variability, or at a Princes of Florence, in terms of agonizingly tough choices, but it does have some variability, and it does manage to cram some tough choices in, and the overall package is definitely fun.

I've played it at all scales now, and IMO it works very well with all of them, though, for the purposes of having slightly more control and a slightly faster game I prefer to cap games at 4 players. The 2 player version of it even seems to work very well, and while it doesn't have the new nuances that a Goa 2 player brings to the table, or a Zepter, it does at least manage to give one the flavour of the bigger game with only 2 at the table, and there is still some fierce competition over certain spots on the board, which is the entire crux of that portion of the game. 

It must be stated that I really prefer to play this with experienced hands who play quickly at this point though...I have played 4 handed games of Caylus that clock in at under 2 hours and 3 player games that are right around 60 minutes and to me, that 60-90 minutes is exactly where this game wants to be. I will generally avoid playing this game with people prone to AP, because it just does not stand up well to slower play for me anymore.

On a final aside, I feel that Agricola does almost everything I like about Caylus more effectively, and with more variability. The only plus here is that there aren't personally random cards in this like there are in Agricola. I think both are weaker than Le Havre.

RATING: 10
Great theme, clever and polished rules and nice mechanism - Caylus is all of these. 

After many plays I'm totally into this game. What I like the most is that everything in the game is balanced and fast. Each of every mechanism is oiled and easy to understand. The game for me absolutely feels like I'm a masterbuilder of the 13th century in the medieval Kingdom of France. I mean, besides the strong euro-side of the game, there is a well fitted and supported theme.
The game is complex, but it's easy to teach. The rulebook is exceptional and well written. Under a short period of time everyone in my gaming group got fast acquainted with the game.

The word 'agressiv' is too much to describe how the game feels to me in a good way, but it isn't peaceful at all. You need to be a cunning strategist who can easily adapt to the changing situations and who immediatly can choose the best of the available actions whose number is always limited or surely decreasing. You need to plan and think ahead. 

I really enjoy how the competition among players results in building up a magnificent village. Ok, I must confess, I remember that our first play produced a really poorly built village. But since then our villages and of course, gameplays constantly get better. :)

I own the new Ystari edition of the game from 2012. It's beautiful and really a piece of art. 

Great, fast, clever - this is Caylus. :D
No doubt, my rating is 10 points. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So the board game community's hunt for the Next Big Eurogame apparently ends here...and of course, the usual excessive praising of a good but not necessarily groundbreaking or innovative game has followed.  I have to admit I wasn't really interested in Caylus, particularly after reading the rules and anticipating yet another Euro with a worn-out theme, crappy art, and and typical gameplay that rewards exploitation of procedure over creative strategy.  Nonetheless, I gave it a shot and I'm impressed that it was at least interesting and in some spots quite smart- it's probably the best new Euro I've played in a while, but that isn't really saying much.  That being said, I think  the game is pretty dry and boring despite some welcome nastiness and I think overall this is more of a flowchart than a game- seriously, it's all about who can exploit the procedural structure of the game more than anything else.  I'm really surprised that the I-hate-luck crowd is digging this because in Caylus other players' actions have a much more detrimental effect on strategy on this than rolling a dice ever have- you can literally be put out of the game by fault of simply going after another player.  The game has an otherwise really tight design and there is a good sense of development throughout that really makes for some interesting decisions and the possibility for several strategic and tactical avenues to pursue- just be flexible or you'll be eff-you-see-kaid, which is another problem because there are way too many "There's nothing else I can do but make this suboptimal move" moments- indeed, I'd say that 1/3 to 1/2 of my decisions throughout a typical game were circumstantially forced on me rather than through my own strategic planning or speculation.  There's definitely elements of Keythedral and other Richard Breese designs here, but this is probably a better development of that designer's ideas but those games were much more fun than Caylus.  All in all, it's an OK game, that's about it.  Nothing new, nothing terribly exciting, and no action we haven't performed in a hundred other games this year alone.  As far as the length goes, the problem is that a player's plans can literally change throughout the turn sequence causing the beard-stroking min-maxers to have to recalculate every five minutes.  My group has had no problem going through the game in 90 minutes.  A big "so what" I guess is my response to all the hype- it used to be that Euro games of this quality were par for course, now they're exceptions given the glut of German game junk that's been cranked out over the past few years.   Honestly though, I'll likely never play this game again, and in 10 years you probably won't even remember its name.

RATING: 6
Caylus... There is quite a bit of history attached to this game. When I first played it at Spiel (in 2005), I was, like many others, enamoured by the design. But the feeling of fun I had while in Essen did not reappear when I played the game at home (with my partner, so just with 2 players), and especially not when people at my local gaming club brought the title along so we could have a bit of exceedingly grating fun at 5 players. I was at the time too inexperienced with games in general to spot what Caylus was [i]truly[/i] about, and this was reflected in my comment for this game, which at the time of writing is in its fifth or sixth revision. I argued about player chaos, skill level differences, playing time, and a few other things... Issues those were, yes, but there were more subtle problems lurking beneath the surface. But since I never felt comfortable playing the game, I didn't really explore why.

Enter the cardgame Caylus Magna Carta, CMC for short. The cardgame did away with certain mechanics in the game (for example the bailiff, the favours, one resource), streamlined the entire thing (getting rid of many buildings, making resources much easier to obtain and money more difficult), and added a fun piece of hand management. [i]There[/i] I did get a handle on what made Caylus 'tick', and found that I could enjoy it, provided I didn't make stupid errors like forgetting that yes, efficiency of resource conversion is indeed important. The more complex and involved original was relegated to the closet; spurred by the comments of many who played CMC that they found it easier to grasp and play—certainly an issue in casual game groups. This quickly led me favouring CMC over the original, which had been stuck in its box for so long that I eventually sold it off without a second thought.

Sometime before the original was sold, the expansion for CMC appeared, and after giving [i]that[/i] some test runs, I discovered that it gave the somewhat cramped base game a boost of fluidity and strategy alternatives which were really quite welcome. In fact I hadn't realised that the game actually needed this bit of strengthening. Or perhaps 'needed' is too large a word; 'profited from' is a better way of phrasing it. But there was a downside too: the expanded CMC now really took a long time to play to completion, a shame really.

And with all that knowledge [i]now[/i] go back to the original, this title therefore, and play with 3 players. Frankly, afterwards I looked over my comments and could not really understand the hubbub. There were differences, yes, but they were not as big as I wanted them to be. The player chaos? Well, that's a consequence of a luckless design and having very few buildings for players to use in the beginning (and still not that many near the end). At 4 and especially 5 getting Caylus up and running can be a pain for inexperienced gamers: the contention is murder, and you don't have a feeling of 'getting anywhere' because resources are simply hard to obtain. In addition getting buildings along the road is just messy. Don't even get me started on prestige buildings. Skill level differences? Well... yes, they are important, and then perhaps the card game has the advantage of 'easing' the player into the rythm of using other player's buildings to gain an advantage. But surely with just two or three players the feeling of being able to do a lot without being checked all the time is ubiquitous. It makes it more important at the high end of the player scale... But really, don't play at that number then if that is a serious issue!

And so forth. A lot of little things clicked into place, meaning I can finally consider this game without the burden of inexperience or fear for its complexity. My verdict is now going to be: solid game, rewards repeated plays, is probably very good material for large groups of experienced gamers... But there are some issues which cause me to rate it somewhat below the cardgame. There are too many little mechanisms in place (bailiff, castle section end scoring, penalty for not constructing a castle section, building buildings too cumbersome, favours coupled to castle section, ...) which can easily be removed from the game without loss to Caylus' inner core of arbitrary cross-player reuse of previously laid down action tiles. This title makes it clear that the player has to deal with all the little details, and that he has to go through a lot of motions which don't really add anything worthwhile save for it becoming yet another detail to consider, or for the fourth and fifth player to have something to do without introducing too much resources and thus upsetting the balance as-is. In that the cardgame is simply better: you can more readily manage the game's core directly instead of managing the core's outer layers so that in the next turn(s?) you can finally get some stuff done.

Was I right in selling off the original? Yes and no. I feel that with the expansion the cardgame provides me with everything I need from this particular set of mechanics, so in that the sale was justified. But no, it wasn't right because I did not have a good idea of [i]why[/i] I thought about Caylus the way I did. I'll make up by boosting the game's rating to what it deserves at thein my opinion best number of players to play this game with, namely three: a 6. Will I play anew with four or two, or perhaps even five? I can't honestly say. But the issues I now have clear in my mind won't go away, so I guess I'll always suggest we do CMC instead, if necessary with the expansion.

[u]2 PLAYERS[/u]: Played too long ago to remember.
[u]3 PLAYERS[/u]: 6
[u]4 PLAYERS[/u]: 5 at best, already there is notable friction in getting the game going, and forcing players into certain directions because the obvious options are taken.
[u]5 PLAYERS[/u]: < 4 because in my memory, it is an exceedingly grating mess. Even these days I will not willingly play this game with 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What a cool game!  Caylus is a neat worker placement type euro game with unique game mechanisms that force competition among the players through out each and every game turn on an incremental basis.  The game design is clever and the buildings in the kingdom are well thought out for initial creation and re-use by players as the game progresses.  This game is fantastic with 2, 3, 4 or even 5 players.  This is also a heavy thinker euro style game as players need to machinate many plays and the order of resolution of those plays.  Money management is also important as it is not necessarily the amount of money one has, but whether one has enough or more money than his opponents and enough money each turn to not get squeezed in his ability to do actions.  Adding flavor to the game is the dynamic of the bailiff and provost which allows players to game the system or suggestively intimidate other players with certain control mechanisms available for play each turn.  This fantastic game has great replayability and is highly enjoyable.  Caylus is one of my favorite, fun to play euro style games of all time.

RATING: 6
I've played it twice now, and my opinion of it hasn't changed all that much. While it was somewhat interesting, it just wasn't fun.Definitely not a bad game, but I just don't understand all the fawning over it. It has some interesting mechanisms, some of which take getting used to. Its most serious drawback is the length of time to play it; if you're going to play it well, you're going to need time to think about the many, many options as well as try to predict what the other players will do. Both games I've played now have gone to the three-hour mark, which is not a good thing.Update - I've played it four more times, and I'm convinced this game is way too overrated. A small number of mid-game errors can make this two-plus-hour-long game painful as you slowly watch yourself torn apart by a good player. I really want to like this game, but I just can't.

I recommend reading rules and then have someone read the rules to you while going through dry run if no one has played before. Board is intuitive and didnt need to go back to rule book very often. No game is ever the same although it is worker placement which can make it seem somewhat slow at beginning. Best balanced game i have ever seen.  One of my favorite. RATING: 8
This is the epitome of the low-luck, open-information, efficiency, optimization Eurogame. Such clean, intuitive rules, yet complex enough to make for excellent replayability. Very simple to set up, requires minimal table space, and turns go quickly. 

Caylus is a brain burner, and one that can take many plays to develop a good strategy to become a competetive player. This is a game where the players really play each other. The provost mechanic is simply brilliant. Mean enough to allow for clever manipulation, but not too punishing to make players frustrated with the game (I'm looking at you, Vanuatu!).

Finally managed to learn and play a classic. At the surface, it's just a worker placement game in a machine to earn points. The interesting twist on happens when players construct additional worker positions in the town and are then rewarded each time another player uses their spaces. This makes it a race to build out high value and useful tiles quickly to slowly gain points from the other players. Manipulation of the provost also allows players to control the pacing of the game as well as forcing other players to keep just enough money around to counter your manipulation of the provost. This leads to a slight cold war style game where players may choose to manipulate things but it could also lead to retaliation by the other players depending on pass order.

RATING: 9
- Gameplay and replayability: 4/4. As this is a perfect information game that is void of luck, it is a great game if you are looking for a brain burner. Expect to be tired after a match of Caylus! However, in exchange for the effort you get lots of fun and excitement. It is nice to pick a strategy and first invest a little before reaping its benefits. Another fun aspect is the nailbiting worker placement phase in which you have to take the other player's preferred actions into account and act preemptively on this, trying to block them and avoiding they block the actions you want to do.

- Absence of luck: 4/4. There are no random elements, and other players can disturb your game almost only if intended. I'd call Caylus chess-like were it not that it does have a totally different feel to it.

- Duration: 2/4. My last 2 and 4 player games took some 3 hours (the number of players doesn't influence the duration much). Even if those 3 hours are lots of fun, it is a bit too long to hit the table often, especially considering the mental effort it takes. I would hesitate to play this after a hard day's work, which is a bit of a pity. A nice thing though is that unlike the total duration suggests, Caylus plays quickly: you never have to wait long until your next turn.

- Player range: Caylus is superb with 2 players and it is also great with 3 or 4.

- Theme and looks: 3/4. The board is beautiful, and although the colored cubes and cylinders do abstract the theme away I do feel it creates a medieval atmosphere.

- Set up/clean up time: 4/4. Can be set up and cleaned up in 5 minutes or so.

- Learning curve and documentation. 2/4. Caylus has quite a lot of rules to learn. For a newcomer there will be a lot to swallow at once, and it takes at least one game to get to know the tiny-but-important aspects of the game. It is just impossible for a first time player to win the game. If you have to learn the game through the rulebook instead of by getting an explanation and guidance by someone that already knows the game, expect to have to study a few hours. But however difficult the rules may seem at first, they become easy and straightforward after playing a game or two.
Because of the rather extended rule set, Caylus requires a bit more documentation than an average game. The manual is good and the in-game documentation is great, but I do think a reference sheet is indispensable. Especially if it has been a while after the last play, you need an overview to quickly get up to speed again. I always wonder why there are so little games that provide this. One would expect that this can't be too hard for a game developer. Luckily there is boardgamegeek for you.

- Like: interactive, zero luck, strategic, competitive, engine building, large player range, short waiting time between turns

- Dislike: rather long, no reference sheet, colored cubes hurt the theme

RATING: 7
I finally got to play Caylus tonight, twelve years after its original release. It holds up, but it didn't blow me away. I think it was so influential, and has been so often imitated, that it felt like I've already played it many times. This came as a surprise, because usually when I play older Euros I see directions in game design that were abandoned: Mexica, Endeavor, and Maharaja are examples of games that I love that did not strongly influence the designs of the following decade. Caylus (a worker placement, point salad, resource converter) was just the opposite: there is no part of it that hasn't been stolen over and over again. That's to the designer's credit, and if I had found it ten years ago it would probably still be a favorite, but entering the game today felt a bit like entering a looted tomb.

RATING: 4
Caylus is a worker placement resource management game that is quite heavy.  I don't think is is that deep, but there are a lot of things to consider to keep yourself from slipping up with a silly mistake.  So you'll need to remember that the joust happens before other "favor" options, that red (or some other player) will get 3 gold before you can move the Provost, that several things can trigger the scoring round, the amount of resources each player has, etc.  If you are willing to take the time to remember all of the options, and then follow the order that everything will happen in, you have done 90% of what you will need to do to play the game well.  It is the last 10% of the game that requires good judgement, and that is the 10% that I enjoy quite a bit.   

As you can probably tell, Caylus is not my favorite type of game.  It demands your whole attention, but only because you have to think everything through without forgetting one of the many facets.  It is mostly a cluttered memory game, and I don't like cluttered games.  They lead to Analysis Paralysis in a lot of players.   I prefer a games with simple choices (where you can see the trade-offs right away), but making the right play takes good judgment.  Those games move quicker, and are more enjoyable for me to play.

Even so, if you are willing to take the time to learn the game, and you are in the right mood (which comes a couple of times a year for me), then the activity of playing can be quite enjoyable.

RATING: 9

Just an altogether, excellent, well-thought out game that I always want to play.  I never expect this to change, thus my rating has finally been upgraded to a 10. This game is my favorite 3 player game I own, and it's up there for 4er games.

Still a great game, but showing some age now.  Bumping down from 10 to a 9.
