RATING: 5
Players are developing a town that will support workers, and enable a castle to be built.  Each turn the players send their workers out to work the fields, shops, and to the castle construction site.  The players juggle money, gather coloured wooden cubes that mean "food", "cloth", etc, and spend their stuff on other things.  Long term, it's all about gaining prestige.  The game works, but it's rather long, and soon begins to feel a bit same-y.  Once the buildings form, the game essentially begins to play itself.  Plug cubes in, out pop points, and the bloom is quickly off the rose.  Lots of justified comparisons to Puerto Rico, Keythedral and Goa - however these are all games that are 60+ minutes quicker than Caylus, and thus they will hit the table ahead of it.  (But, Caylus isn't bad as a meaty 2 player game!).

RATING: 3
Little more than a long, dry, convoluted perversion of Breese's fun underrated classic Aladdin's Dragons. But unlike Aladdin's Dragons, there's no fun, no bluff, and no bidding, and no hidden info. Just sequential taking stuff and guessing what will be left when your turn comes around again.
 
The more players you add the less there is to go around for everyone, so beware the five-player game.
 
Along with Age of Steam, this game typifies the recent trend of long, overanalytical and ruthless economic games that reward exploiting procedure to the detriment of the other players.

RATING: 6
August 2014. I recently revisited Caylus after not playing it for many years. I was very curious how it would stand up after living through the evolution of worker placement games in the interim. 

My conclusion: Man alive, this game is BRUTALITY in a box in a way best appreciated in retrospect.  With clever play, you can totally hose over your opponents, and with the slightest mistake totally hose over yourself.  This game reminds me there was a time when you weren't handed out some ration of VPs every turn just for showing up and Eurogames would let you fail. I'm talking about the before times when new Knizia games were awesome and points weren't served up at a salad bar. If you suck up a turn in Caylus, you get nothing, you lose, GOOD DAY SIR!  That's jarring in the present day.  However, it is magnificent gaming, and I'm so glad that we can enjoy the current style of games without losing the old. 

UPDATE Aug 2014: All that being said, I think maybe I don't actually so much enjoy this game, because against a good opponent, it is HARD.  I am not sure how fun I ultimately find this game.  I'd like to say it's because the game is rather dry, but I'm afraid it is because I don't want to work this hard.  Maybe if my wife didn't destroy me every time...but she does that at Agricola too and I still enjoy that.  I also tend to prefer games with more of a dynamic setup.  I think I am going to try Tzolk'in, as I think it might scratch the same itch without drawing blood.

UPDATE Sep 2014: Curse you Caylus!  I am now thinking that what I need to do is not to trade away Caylus, but to get better at playing Caylus.  I call this "Agricola syndrome".  I have realized that one thing that throws me about this game is that you don't really build up your own personal infrastructure.  Anyone can use the buildings you construct for a relatively minor payment.  This makes it difficult to build things that benefit you without helping your opponents.  Maybe that payment isn't so minor in the long haul, and your personal infrastructure comes from those baby payments.  There are definitely still some things to explore here.  

Last game my wife and I tried to starve each other out by not building and passing early.  We only had a few buildings the whole game.  It was a very different experience and I was impressed that the game still worked in this extreme mode (although it wasn't the most fun way to play).  Once she caught on to what I was doing, she out-stingied me anyway.

Update Sept 2014:  I finally played a game reasonably well.  However, I think Tzolkin may have further spoiled Caylus for me.  I love the variable setup that Tzolkin offers.  Caylus si the same every time, and I'm not sure what there is to stop me from trying to pursue the same strategy every time.  I prefer it when the game itself forces you to change up your approach.  I also in generally don't like it when controlling the timing of the end of the game or needing to dominate the last turn is a big issue, and it surely is here.

Final update? Sept 2014: I think is the end.  The more I play this, the more joyless I find it.  We had our ups and downs Caylus, but it is time for us to part.  I revisited you to see how you fared in the modern day, and while I admire you for being a pioneer, your descendants have surpassed you in Fun.  Farewell, and I wish you well.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Caylus is big, complex, and deep.  The genius of Caylus is that there is that no one way to win, there are many different strategies that can all lead to victory (or defeat).  Building the kings castle, constructing the town around it, building monuments, and gaining royal favors all offer paths to victory.  Each option is well balanced and a few or all can be used at once.  The direct competition between players can also be intense as each vies to place their workers on the various buildings.  This game requires a significant investment of time to play, but it's a real treat each time I do.

RATING: 6.75
If you're going to judge a game by how long after release it's still getting played, Caylus is pretty high up there.  I still enjoy this grandaddy of worker-placement, and feel like it's aged quite well.

It has a couple rough edges.  I don't feel like all the strategies scale well with different player counts, and 5 is probably too many for the game.  (Frequently someone gets hosed on the last turn because the castle filled all the way up, and they can't build. That means no positive points, and a double-whammy penalty.)
Similarly, the blue buildings are a neat capstone, but they seem super hard to get to.  You've got to either dedicate to that particular favor track to slowly guarantee yourself a shot at it, or force the pace of the game along by building the builders that build the more advanced buildings, etc.  The vast majority of the blue buildings will never be touched, and I'm pretty sure there are some that have never been built in [i]any[/i] game.  Even the wood & stone buildings have some duds, and often come out in the same pattern.

RATING: 6

Brass is probably better though..

RATING: 8.8
This is a fairly thematic game about acquiring resources in order to build up a king's kingdom.  The player the king likes the most at the end of the game wins.

Building things in the king's kingdom makes the king happy.  If another player chooses to use a building you constructed, that helps your reputation with the king and that makes the king like you a little bit more.  If you tell the king you are going to build part of his castle and you don't, he likes you less.  If you build more, he likes you more.  If you build the most in a round or build as much as the other players and commit to doing it first (the other players likely simply appear as copy-cats to the king), the king additionally offers a favor to you for your good work.  If you choose the points track at the top, that is like politely declining the king's offer, which simply makes him like you more.  Repeatedly doing this makes him like you progressively more.  The bottom favor track seems to involve the player responding to the king along these lines: "Good king, I would like to request a special favor of you.  If I again find myself in your good graces and you feel I am worthy of receiving your favor, please allow me to construct a building for you in your kingdom."  And the king responds along the lines of, "If you again do something worthy of receiving my favor, if you so choose, I will entrust you with one of my men skilled in carpentry for a small project in town and I will provide you with some of my wood which you may use if you oversee the construction of a wooden building."

RATING: 9
This is a very fine game, a gamer's game if you want. The rules are very logical and there is a flow to the game that keeps everybody busy and involved, especially with the myriads of strategies involved. The abstracted graphic design is excellent, as it is really possible to understand everything that is depicted on the board quickly and without the use of text. Be prepared to play this a few times before you feel confident, this game is much less forgiving than even Puerto Rico. The only reason why this doesn't get a 10 by me is the fact that a) there is little to no theme here - you never feel a minute like you are building a medieval town, it's all about VP's and resources b) player interaction is limited to where you place your pawns. But every true gamer should feel obliged to play this game at least once, that's for sure.

RATING: 7
Caylus is an old title, but it has certainly held its own. Despite having helped birth worker placement, Caylus' implementation of the mechanic is still incredibly unique, and unlike anything else on the market. The Bailiff & Provost add a healthy dose of meta-game into this solid Euro, forcing players to constantly jostle for position and plan carefully. The game also manages to shift priorities between the early- and late-game, which encourages players to experiment with and pivot to different strategies in a single session. The complete lack of randomness makes this a must play for the luck averse.

RATING: 9
Caylus is the best resource management game I know.  Resources are always tight, so you have to think carefully to make the most of them, but it doesn't get bogged down in calculations.  The competitive worker placement forces you constantly reconsider and reprioritize, and the provost adds even more tension to this already tight game.  The balance is excellent, with even turn order under your control.  There is no randomness past the initial set-up, so there is nothing to undermine the strategy.

Like any game with little to no luck, the tactics in Caylus are unforgiving, with no room for error.  There is definitely a level of strategy beyond that, however, which I have not yet entirely fathomed.  Part of the key seems to be moderation - it is important to build as much as possible each turn, but at the same pushing too hard for one great turn is usually a mistake.  You have to be careful not to overextend yourself.   

Caylus does have a couple of minor disadvantages - it is a little long, it can be a little dry, there isn't a whole lot of opportunity to form long-term strategies, and I wish that the favor tracks were more balanced.  

Overall, though, Caylus is a fascinating resource management game that really makes you think hard about every move. It also works great with two, and is a favorite of both my wife and I.

Update Dec. 2017 - Pulled this out again after a couple years on the shelf (it's hard to find the time to play anymore) and was pleased to find that we love it as much as ever.  This is just a really phenomenal game - so tense and delicious and 100% luck free.

RATING: 5
In one of the many Euro vs AT debates it was suggested that Euro games are characterized by structure and AT games by drama, and this game is all structure and no drama.  No surprise then, that this is the most polarizing game.

It's certainly mechanically sound, but it's entirely small, tough decisions that never develop into dramatic moments of agony.  Perhaps I just couldn't recognize the big moments, but this felt like death by paper cuts to me.  In Power Grid, for example, when a key plant comes up for bid, everybody knows that this is a huge moment in the game.  Caylus doesn't seem to have any moments like that, and that is perhaps the best generalized criticism of the Eurogames that I find dull.

I'd try it again though.

RATING: 9.2
This is the newest game to my collection currently and lives up to its reputation based on only one play so far. I almost compare it to chess where each move is strategic and gives you some sort of long term benefit. Each "pawn" is vital and costs money to place so each placement needs to be placed with a lot of purpose. The game can be a little dry but the gameplay and strategy involved adds so much substance. There is no luck involved in this game so each placement, each resource gained, and each built item is based on skill and strategy. The game is very open, so players must make a plan and try to execute that plan more efficiently than the other player. I can see the potential for frustration because there are so many options to choose from, but that is why a plan is so important. Also, the first time I played with the wife we didn't use the provost as he should be used. I actually think it will be more fun with the provost because it will severely limit a player's plan and will create tension where there needs to be some tension. Provost is probably 50% of the strategy and without him, it is an incomplete game where players can do whatever they want by the end and what is the fun in that, except that it gets the wife to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Just like Twilight Struggle, I'm coming late to Caylus, and just like TS I see the brilliance of the design that everyone has been raving about. It's long, there's no getting around that because almost every placement of your workers is agonizingly difficult (in the best of ways). The depth requires that you have a plan and be patient enough to stick to it; no rushing to the castle willy nilly or just building things because you can. You need to plan ahead for 2 or 3 turn cycles so that your efforts are linked together effectively. It requires more discipline than most games and if you execute your plans it feels great; if not, you're flailing and just want the experience to end. 

If it were that simple it'd still be interesting but Caylus forces you to pay attention to tempo. The more you can stay out of tempo with your opponents as far as passing and going to the castle, the less resistance you'll encounter. Amid the great struggle of all these forces the game then intersects you by asking you to figure out if you should focus on building the castle, regular buildings, or prestige buildings. Absolutely agonizing. The way the buildings come out differently each game means no game should be quite the same.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- Does not really get me. Dry.
- Someone said Caylus is too long for what it is. Now I know what they meant.
- Graphics quality is below average.
- a nightmare when playing with players with analysis paralysis

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After initially hating this game, I finally played through a full game.  The mechanic is fairly simple (go after resources and certain actions [like being able to build more buildings], then decide whether or not to continue paying workers to take actions, then resolve each building's ability [providing resources, allowing certain buildings to be built, building the castle], then score points, then repeat).  Seems like the game took too long and could have achieved its goal in a shorter time.  Also, it's strange that actually building the castle seems to generate far less points than building the ancillary buildings (such as the big 25 point building whose name escapes me).  It would seem since the overall theme behind the game is building the castle, it would follow that the game rewards players the most for actually doing that, when in reality the reward just comes from doing enough to not get penalized.

I'd play this again, but I don't think it's the game that everyone makes it out to be.  Could be because I've only made it through one game.  I am surprised that I liked this game.  Seems like it will go much faster after a couple of plays.  If it can get around an hour, I'd like it much more.

RATING: 8
Oh my.  Finally discovered what all the fuss was about.  I agree with the favorable chatter around this magnificent game but it must be said that Caylus seems more like a highly successful blend of existing mechanics than some new groundbreaking game.  Everything works well together and the turn angst is atrocious (a very good thing in my book).  For veteran gamers, the game is picked up easily yet there are always new strategies you would like to explore.  Excellent in so many ways that for the genre I prefer it to Puerto Rico which is its closest sibling.  Plus, Caylus scales extremely well; I've played 2, 3 and 4 player games and each time the beautiful turn angst is ever present.

RATING: 6
A tight game with a longer-than-I-like playtime and a wide variety of mechanics. With 18 months of Euro experience I'm much more capable of making sense of the interaction, collusion, racing, blocking, and leeching amongst all the actions.

It's reputed to be a very deep game, though the resource track is allegedly underpowered and I wonder if the prestige buildings and stone farms are too dominant (in that they are critical in every game).

The graphic design is easy to understand; despite complaints about abstraction, I feel things fit the theme quite neatly though the theme itself won't intrude. The translation of "donjon" as "dungeon" instead of "keep" is brain-dead.

I have this on iPhone.

RATING: 4
[Resource management, Special powers, Building] Played only on brettspielwelt.de, and I think that's going to be as far as it goes because Caylus is underdeveloped. It's slow, it's fiddly, it's repetitive and it's processional. That's pretty much fatal for a middleweight game of limited depth. [5P:3,4P:4/3,3P:4,2P:4] I've never liked resource swapping as a mechanism, and this game has it in spades. Just looking at all the resources flying around is almost enough to make my head explode. Game mechanism-wise, Caylus has nothing to write home about. Lacks polish. The game's heart is timing to grab buildings each turn, using them to generate resources and set collection on those resources so you can build stuff, with a dash of area majority based on the set collection. I would probably like the game more if it was executed better, but as it is, it's several tweaks away from being good. Dropped from wishlist. UPDATE: Played 4P F2F game. It's substantially WORSE than playing on BSW because of the bits and pieces. Caylus is almost in my "can't stand it" range, and one more F2F play will probably push it over the edge into Settlers and El Grande territory. Sigh. Ystari is the "new alea"? You have to be kidding me. alea's first four games were RA, Chinatown (never played), Taj Mahal and Princes of Florence. Ystari's first three offerings are nowhere near the quality of the three of those that I've played.Old comments: Geekbuddy rating is currently off the scale (13 ratings, 8.69, nothing lower than a 7 so far) but care needs to be taken especially since this is an indy game. My usually reliable buddies led me horribly astray twice (Reef Encounter, which is, to be kind, not good) and Power Grid (good game, not great, and certainly not an 8+ rating game). Watching and waiting for at least half of my Geekbuddies (30+ ratings) to weigh in. *** UPDATE: The low standard deviation (1.31) on Caylus is unusual for a game receiving this much hype. This means it's not likely to be a turkey (Happy Thanksgiving Americans!) but I'm still feeling this is a 6 or 7, along the lines of Power Grid (and agreeing with Siggins about gamers being 'excitable'). Now leaning towards getting the game, despite my serious misgivings. I can always trade it away I guess. *** WARNING SIGNS: The comments from Farrell are underscoring my fear of the indy design - just as Reef Encounter and Power Grid would be greatly improved by going through a rigorous development process where pruning extraneous mechanisms and playing time are the order of the day, so it applies to Caylus. For a 3H game (and that's likely to be the range for Caylus in my group) I'd rather bring Die Macher to the table. Even more cautiously approaching this one now. Has it been that long since an outstanding gamer's game has appeared that people forget the value of elegance and clean design? Still expect this to be in the 5 to 7 rating range for me... sadly.

RATING: 8.75
Caylus is a great strategy and resource allocation game.  I have played this game with my group, and more people enjoy this game than Agricola or Puerto Rico.  Some of the things I really enjoy about the game are the necessity for planning ahead, the way the game adds a level of uncertainty as to the resources you will end up harvesting, and the fact that at the end of the game most of the players are very close to each other in points.
The components are nice, the tiles and game board are sturdy, and the rules are very well written.  The only downside for some people might be that the game can seem somewhat cutthroat.

RATING: 10
William Attia ist ein freundlicher Mensch, der im Grunde für jeden Spielvorschlag erst einmal zu haben ist. Nur bei einem sagt er konsequent Nein: sein Jahrhundertwerk CAYLUS winkt er ab. Nein, das spielt er nicht. Ob es daran liegt, dass er vor lauter Testerei das Spiel zu oft vor sich hatte und es überdrüssig ist oder ob er dem eitlen Spieler-schlägt-Autor-Orden kein Material geben möchte, bleibt sein Geheimnis wie CAYLUS selbst: bahnbrechend, wegweisend und genreprägend sind nur einige der Attribute die dieses Werk verdient, das wie PUERTO RICO oder AGRICOLA eine ganze Generation Brettspiele beeinflusste und ihre Existenz erst möglich machte. Selbst heute, im Jahr 1500 nach Arbeitereinsatz umweht CAYLUS eine zeitlose Aura und steht in seiner besonders hässlichen Erstauflagenschachtel bescheiden und überdauernd als herausragendes Spiel in der eigenen Hall of Sammlung. Vogt und Seneschall sind bei ihrem Marsch auf der Straße des Glücks zu ikonischen, scheibenweißen Symbolen geworden. Und wer überholt jetzt wen? Man kann sich's einfach nicht merken. Der kunterbunte Kindergarten-Pastell-Look auf Leinwand, indem farbkompositorisch so rein gar nichts zusammen zu passen scheint ist Kunst. CAYLUS ist und bleibt Mutter von vielem, was danach kam. Ehre dem Schloß in der Höhe. Auch wenn es dem bescheidenen William gar nicht wichtig ist: er darf dort auf seinem Game of Throne gerne Platz nehmen.

There's always a multitude of decisions to make, with more and more developing with every turn.  Classic Euro, but thematically solid for the most part.  Lots of enjoyment comes from the interaction, blockage and constant holding-on for control.  Even after 10 years of Caylus it is deal one of the best worker placement games.

RATING: 3
Caylus, although highly praised here on the geek was a pleasant surprise.  I was afraid that Caylus would come across as being dry, I was wrong.  Caylus allows for a strong amount of player interactions, through both the mechanic introduced by the baliff and provost, and the necessity to generate wears using businesses owned by others.  The game has a wonderful balance between long term strategy and on-the-fly tactical decisions: as all plans can be stunted or made improbable by the smart play of others. The multiple ways of earning VPs makes each game seem fresh, and never leaving one parched.  From my few playings I feel Caylus is well deserving of it's high ranking.

RATING: 6
This is an enigine-building game in the mold of Goa and Puerto Rico - a "bits mangement" game with a limited strategic horizon (perhaps a 2-3 turn look-ahead) and a good number of interesting tactical choices every turn.  The player interaction does not take place through trading or auctions, but rather, on the board through unit placement and denial.

It's a fairly heavy game:  2-3 hours long with fairly complex rules and a lot of decisions.  Fiddly in a Puerto Rico sort of way.

If it wasn't so long and fiddly it would rate higher.  I find that I would rather play two different (shorter) games in the same amount of time.

RATING: 5
A very engrossing game for the experienced Euro gamer. It has a decent amount of player interaction. What I mean is that it is not a pure optimization of your own position (like Goa almost is) but you can do actions that will interfere with opponents plans.  There's nothing really nasty you can do (this is a Euro game after all) but it does add in a nice little "social" element that effects play.

The theme is weak, not that I expected anything more, but there is stuff to talk about after a game. That's a good sign.  It's a game I will not buy but definitly willing to play occasionally. I never expect to become that good at it either. 

In summary, I've seen it all the mechanics before but in Caylus it is all package together in the current grand poobah of Euro games.

RATING: 7
Many options on each turn, and the best overall strategy is unclear. The royal favor system integrates into the game very well. Because scoring is done in a particular order, and resources gained early in the scoring round can be used later in the round, careful forethought is required to set up the best scoring opportunities.

Nice theme and bits.

I really like the design of Caylus, but for me the play time kills the fun.  My game group can't get through a game faster than 2.5 hours, and 3 hours is more typical.  2/3 of the way through, I'm ready to be done.  One could shorten the game, but only at the expense of losing the more interesting buildings.  I'd be happier just playing something else entirely, which is why I've lowered my score to a 7.

RATING: 10
My only ten so far. I've played the game in a variety of groups, and with two players. The game works surpassingly well with two, although it's much easier to recover from bad decisions.

I love the game's emergent strategy and almost complete lack of randomness. I also love that there are so many different ways to win, and that big-picture strategy and small but efficient victory point engines both have a place in this game. 

Each game is different, and even after multiple plays I feel like there is a lot to discover. There's so much to this game that not all of it will necessarily come out in a given play. There's so much subtlety that even a few creative moves can dramatically change the game.

This is a deep brain burner, and definitely not "lite" fare. I wouldn't pull this out when there are new gamers over or with non-geek family. However, I've been pleasantly surprised at how quickly less-experienced gamers pick this up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't think the game is the second coming, but it is a good game and worthy of taking a look into if you like games of this type.  I look forward to trying it again, that is for sure.

Finefield, 12-16-2015
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros:
* Multiple paths to victory
* Lots of strategic and tactical play
* Lots of great mechanics
* Heavy on player interaction and screwage
* Perfect information, no luck
* Game feels different every play

Cons:
* Playtime can be too long depending on number and type of players


I think it's excellent with 3 players, very good with 2 or 4 pIayers, not enjoyable with 5 players. 

Playtime 
--------
30-45min per player. The game has a variable timer so you don't really know beforehand how long the game will be. The players and their strategies really dictate length here. And also, because of some really tricky decision-making some of your AP-prone players might extend the game. My games have always taken 40-45min per player, but with the right circumstances you could probably play this faster.

2 players
--------- 
Positives: A very nice head-to-head battle where you have a lot of control, both over your own destiny and that of your opponent's. It is easier to formulate a strategy and stick to it during the whole game, but there are still a bunch of tactical decisions to be made due to fierce competition and strong interaction. I would say that the strategy/tactics mix is something like 70/30 here.
Negatives: You are much less likely to be able to use the provost to mess up your opponents plans. There is no competition for player order because you simply switch who goes first every turn. 

3 Players
--------- 
Positives: You have to give up a little of your control but the added player interaction and tactics derived from that more than make up for it. I think the strategy/tactics mix is more like 50/50 with 3 players, and it is more satisfying because of it.
Both the provost and stables (player order) become much more interesting.
Negatives: I can't think of any, it's just great as a 3-player. The only problem is that I seldom have exactly 3 players.

4 Players
---------
Positives: Compared to the 2 player game, this has more interesting provost and stable play. Some other things like castle building, using the gate etc can also be more interesting than with only 2 players. 
Negatives: Strategy/tactics mix drops down to 30/70-ish. Gametime is more than I would like it to be. At least it has been for my group. 

5 Players
---------
Positives: Compared to playing with less players I don't really see any positive things. 
Negatives: Very little strategy left. I usually like tactical games (torres is one of my favourites), but I feel caylus really suffers from the lack of long-term planning. To me it feels more chaotic than tactical and I don't think it's fun for the long time it takes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

To sum up, I respect Caylus, I can play it from time to time, but I don't have the desire to play it often and own it anymore.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My first impressions of Caylus were mixed but mostly positive:  "The tactical decisions of prioritizing and timing the deployment of my workers are interesting.  The game gives you always something to think about and always something to do.  The mechanisms are well-conceived and fit together seamlessly.  My favorite part of Caylus is anticipating and manipulating the power games, guesswork, and shifting alliances surrounding the provost's movement."

However, each time I play Caylus I like it a bit less.  That's not a good sign.  It seems to lack a few of the qualities that a game of this length needs in order to have staying power.  (1) The game decisions are probably about 90% tactical, dominated by short-term prioritization, and thus there is very little opportunity to pursue truly distinct strategic paths.  That's acceptable for a 60-80 minute game, but it's a poor texture for a game that stretches on for two to three times that length. (2) A game of this length needs to have more of a shape.  The game should change from beginning to middle to end.  In Caylus, you're mostly just doing the same things over and over for two or three hours.  Not every turn is the same, of course, but there is this sort of constant ebb and flow that looks the same throughout the game.  There's no story arc, just lather, rinse, repeat.  Try writing a session report and you'll see what I mean. (3) A game this long needs to behave differently each time you play.  Caylus games vary a little bit, but not enough to feel like I'm seeing anything new from game to game.

I think that part of the problem resides in the way that the various buildings and projects are shared among all players.  Because of this, there's no real differentiation among the players, other than their respective positions on the king's favor tracks.  Everything else sort of blurs together, and since everyone has the same opportunities, all the decisions involve seizing short-term opportunities.  My position on turn X will look pretty similar to your position on some other turn Y.  Whichever one of us optimizes all our little decisions better will probably win.  That's fun for a few games, but it's not the sign of a deep game nor is it the sign of a highly replayable game.  Caylus: reasonably fun for now, won't hold up over time, not as deep as it appears, doesn't offer quite enough punch for its length.

[Update] I traded away my copy after a few plays, and have had no desire to revisit the game.

RATING: 8
I might be in opposition here, but I like this game more now than I did when it got out. When it got out I thought it was novel and neat game, but pretty dry and brain burning. The fact that it is a perfect information game (a type of game I normally despise) didn’t make it better. The game might look hard to understand, but it really isn’t that hard because it has sequential phases. It is a highly interactive game, but you have to form your strategy still.

Many gamers have problem with the time it takes to play. I don’t have a problem with that since I found it pretty involving from the first turn. Sometimes the last two turns can seem little automatic, but better that than feeling that the game ends too early.

I found it play good with any number of players, but I prefer to play it with 3 or 4 players. I am a social gamer, so that might be the reason I don’t play this as a 2-player game. I think I am done with five player Caylus. There is just damn too much chaos in the game for that.

RATING: 8
Outstanding game, notwithstanding the required commitment in playing time (which is considerable, especially with players who haven't played it before).

When it came out, it was often compared to Puerto Rico (another wonderful game) in terms of level of enjoyment and "game design quality". Personally, I would vote for Puerto Rico between the two due to the game's ingenious mix and balance of strategic and tactical elements (in Caylus, I find that resource management becomes very strategic at the expense of tactical considerations towards the end, requiring extensive "counting" several game turns ahead to figure out where to place one's workers in order to gain the optimal combination of resources enabling the necessary purchases and actions). But Caylus might be slightly better "balanced" between the various choices available to a player than Puerto Rico.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Firstly one little issue I have with the game - the money is terrible! Seriously, there have been plenty of discussions on money in games and I would have thought they could have come up with something better than tiddly winks! Not only that, the 5s are the same colour as the 1s. Not good enough.
That is my only complaint with the game thus far though. I've played a 5 player game where I finished 4th and a 4 player game where I finished 3rd. Both times I really enjoyed the experience of playing and was hankering after another game of it immediately. Money aside this game has a very good 'bits' value (ok so the cubes are a little small but they don't need to be big). The actually rules are quite simple - You place a worker, the next player places a worker, etc. then resolve all buildings in order. What I like is that there are lots of choices each turn for where to put your workers and what sort of strategy to go for. It seems like it will be intimidating to teach to some of my friends because there are lots of fiddly things to explain (what each building does, what royal favours are, etc.) but hopefully once they've played a game or two it won't seem quite so difficult and they will enjoy it as much as I have.

Edit: I only have the 1st edition and the 2nd edition doesn't have the above mentioned problem with the money.

RATING: 6
I've only played about 5 times, and I still don't get how to win this game.  There are a lot of complexities -- you have to understand all the buildings very well, and try to build the right one given the game circumstance that you find yourself.  With a game like this (with no randomness other than the initial turn order and pink tile layout), you have to read the mood of the group.  If people are paying a lot of money for moving the provost each turn, you have to keep some money in reserve (and perhaps advance on the money royal favours track).  If the lawyer comes out late, you should probably be working on the building royal favours track.  All in all, I need to play this game at least 5 more times to gain an appreciation for it.

RATING: 4
Caylus has a lot going for it, but the Provost movement is worrisome. The rules seem to encourage players to coerce each other into making movements beneficial to them, yet no actual deals can be made, opening the door to back-stabbing and other threats. Worst of all you have to figure out your own best move while your opponents are lobbying for you to do what they want. This seems very out of place in this otherwise nonpolitical game. I am told that without this unpleasantness, the Provost mechanic doesn't work, but I haven't played enough to decide if this is true or not. The game's other major flaw is its length... it is a long game, and may be made worse by overly analytical players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[Initial Impression: 9]
A gorgeous game with a large amount of information to take in, accompanied by strategic variety.  I especially like the mechanics of being able to use an action to influence turn order (the Stables) or to immunize yourself against increasing costs late in a turn (the Inn).  You are constantly left feeling that someone just took the action you wanted, but there is usually another available that you can use to your benefit.  Sessions (especially with new players or a high player count) can be quite long (2.5-3.5 hours) and at times feel overly mechanical, as there are many moving parts and maintenance steps to track during each turn.  The playing time doesn't bother me, however, and seems to fly by, as I'm utterly absorbed throughout each game. 

As I continue to play this, I've become even more enamored with it. Although some complain about the "chaos" in a 5-player game, I think this is much ado about nothing. I like the 5-player version enormously. Resources are much tighter with more players, you really have to fight for favors, and the so-called "chaos" is simply the result of having to account for the interactions of multiple players.  Each player's choices are almost always predictable according to their strategy (which you can infer from prior choices), and you simply have to keep a set of back-up choices in mind and adapt your strategy to take advantage of what others are undervaluing. I believe that those with complaints about chaos are mostly upset that they can't easily carry out their favorite strategy.  It is also a very good 2-player game, but the fluidity of the changing turn order and the value of the Inn are diminished.  With just 2 players, it can become quite nasty, as moving the provost loses all of its cooperative aspect, becoming a struggle to help solely yourself or to harm your sole opponent.

RATING: 10
Having played over 80 games of Caylus, I can write that this is one of the most incredible games I've every played.  The depth of the game is astounding.  There are so many different paths to victory.  There is so much going on, that it is mind boggling.  There is NO luck at all in Caylus (except for initial turn order.)  All information is open to everyone.  Most importantly, this game is FUN!!!  Now for one negative:  The rule book is absolutely the worst I have ever encountered.  It took me days of reading it multiple times and then reading explanations at BGG, until I finally understood all aspects of the game and felt confident to teach it and play it.  It is a shame that the rules were written so poorly because the game is really not that difficult.  (The depth comes in the strategy.)  My first game, I played with two 12 year olds and after my explanation, they understood the game completely and played well.  We only made one error in playing, which we caught before the end of the game.  Ystari needs to do a complete re-write of the rule book (scrap the old one and start over) because the game is awesome - very engaging and challenging.  I can't imagine that anyone but die-hard gamers would go through what I did to learn and play this great game from the rule book.  The game runs long, but picks up a lot after several plays.  I enjoy a longer game anyway, so that isn't a negative for me.  There are just so many choices and the game is prone to AP.  I'm playing a two player game now in about 1 1/4 hours.  I'm always looking for a great two player game and Caylus plays superbly with two.  In fact, it might be best with two, since the provost is always in play and a real factor in the game with two players.  A perfect "10". . . . I just played this game again recently after a long break and I must say that this is a truly great game - one of the best I've ever played.  It holds up very well and is very very intense (in a deliciously fun way).

RATING: 8.8
起始設定: 2食物1木頭 起始5元 2.3家6元 4.5家7元
流程:
一、領取收入 (有住宅、旅館會有額外)
二、擺放工人 (每個工人1元，pass增加工人錢，第一位pass得1元)
三、固定建築啟動功能 
四、市長勘察 (每個人可以花1-3元移動1-3步)
五、一般建築啟動功能
六、建造城堡 (需要三個資源不相同，其中一個必須是粉紅色食物)
七、回合結束 (移動城堡監督、城堡結算檢定)

移動城堡監督:一次一格，市長跑比監督快就移動兩格，然後拉回市長。
每回合蓋最多城堡的人獲得一次獎勵，平手看誰先蓋。(可以蓋到下一階段，有採沒蓋要扣2分。)
城堡結算檢定: 該時期城堡蓋完或城堡監督走到該回合進行結算。

注意:
1.採別人家裡建築物會幫人家加1分。
2.採自己建築物永遠只要1元

RATING: 8
A clever re-distillation of mechanisms that started a craze for 'worker placement' games. Caylus has lots of ways to score, even a little non-binding negotiation. For a while after launch this was among my favourite games, but the fact that buildings are added to a common pool rather than being 'yours' makes this game highly vulnerable to groupthink. My group tends to emphasise cube taking and so adds those buildings that produce double cubes, while few are interested in haggling over moving the provost, which reduces the game to an unexciting minimum. For me, this is the classic star that burned brightly, but was soon gone, and is one of the few games that can be said to have started a genre, but Agricola has now completely stolen its thunder.

RATING: 3
Perhaps a good game in its day, but that age has long since passed.  Its an ok action selection and resource management game.  The player interaction comes in the form of lopsided action blocking and take-that.  Usually to the determent of both the player getting blocked and the player blocking.  The game can be completely destroyed by one weaker player.  There are also unbalances in strategies as the game is nowhere as close to open as it pretends to be.  Furthermore, there are mathematical imbalances based on player turn order that are haphazardly compensated for. Ive played the game a significant number of times and I have won the game against good players in a completely unfulfilling fashion and I see absolutely no reason to ever play again.  If this game is in your Top 100 it is most likely because you havent played 101 games yet.

RATING: 7
Based on one play: Caylus is a nasty, nasty game. First you think it is easy, because there are not that many rules and you can grasp it fairly easily. But then the game starts and you realize how deep it actually is. And then someone moves the provost or places a worker on a spot you really needed and you've practically lost instantly.

Positive points:
- Simple and few rules but still deep and complex gameplay
- Doesn't take too long
- Great implementation of the worker placement mechanic

Downsides:
- Very unforgiving. There is now catch-up mechanism if you've fallen behind.
- Very nasty: other players can screw your plans so much that you really have to hold your temper.
- Dry theme

My summary: I like it, but I won't play it that often. I don't feel it has been replaced by the newer games.

RATING: N/A
Juego de información perfecta  más interactivo y más intuitivo que otros dos grandes eurogames (Puerto Rico, Power Grid) con más formas de ganar que en ellos. Tiene todo lo que me gusta en un eurogame de este estilo: gestión de recursos (trabajadores, dinero, bienes), edificación incrementada (los nuevos edificios son más podersos progresivamente), “draft” (eliges la prioridad de lo que quieres conseguir), estrategia (planificación a largo plazo), táctica (aprovechar oportunidades), sin azar (tan sólo el orden en el que aparecen los primeros elementos), diferentes maneras de conseguir puntos (y por lo tanto, de ganar), excelente equilibrio entre los distintos estilos de juego. Las decisiones a tomar parecen simples, aunque en realidad no lo son (debes elegir sólo una de las múltiples opciones considerando la ganancia inmediata, pero pensando en los efectos a largo plazo). Tres es el número optimo de jugadores PEGAS: Sólo para jugones,  (para novatos recomiendo Agricola o Age of Empires III). Downtime con jugadores con excesivo A/P, excesiva dependencia de lo que hagan los demás,  en el juego a 5 jugadores.

RATING: 6
As much as I'd love to like this game, it's just too long and involved.  There are way too many things to do on each turn, and while the decisions all seem important, a lot of them are very similar.  So there's a lot of analysis paralysis without the benefit of satisfaction of having won the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is the ultimate dry Euro; luck has been virtually removed from the game, so it is almost chess-like in that regard.  I like the theme and the artwork on the board and tiles.  Caylus plays very similarly to Tzolk'in where players are rewarded or punished on the merits of their ability to plan a few moves ahead and to make groups of series of actions in just the right sequence so as to maximize the output of their workers.  Caylus is a very thought intensive worker placement joint, deserving of its cult following. I think it's important to mention that Caylus is very punishing of poor play, particularly in the early going, just like Tzolk'in.  It can be extremely challenging to eke your way back into contention if you fall behind the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simply one of the best worker placements money can buy.  All the systems within the game balance eachother perfectly, giving multiple routes to victory with adjustments to your game plan required based on which one you choose.

The basic premise is that you are trying to construct a castle along with the outlying village in order to score points.  Constructing buildings can score points throughout the game as any player who activates your building gives you a point, whereas expanding the castle nets you points and potentially a favour from the king which can prove to be very useful.

This game can be quite cutthroat, but only in a good way - you are rarely prevented from doing at least something useful, the game is designed well enough that you can modify your turn plan to concentrate on another part of your 'engine' if you get blocked on a particular round.

RATING: 9
My favorite of the medium-weight Worker Placement (Puerto Rico, Agricola, Le Havre etc.) genre. The theme of this one is beyond boring, but the mechanics more than make up for it. I like that you can invest heavily in one strategy, but that you still have to do work building the castle and interact with your fellow players to have any shot at winning. The start-player mechanism, as well as the movement of the provost/bailiff, and the ability of players to mess with this movement, are great. 

Works well for 2-5, though 5 is a bit long

RATING: 9
Caylus is neither the most attractively-presented of games nor particularly well-balanced. But it is among the most interesting. The various mechanisms which balance money, resources, points and other actions are not original in themselves but are put together into a somewhat novel, if inelegant whole. UPDATE: coming back to Caylus after a number of years and I find that it has stood the test of time. Even with the existence of Caylus Magna Carta, there is still a reason to return to the original game.

RATING: 6.5
I played this one when it first came out and I absolutely hated it.  It was dry.  I could care less about impressing the king.  And it played far too long for what I got out of it.  

Flash forward a few years and I tried it again to see if my opinion of the game changed.  I didn't think the game was as bad as I first thought, but it still left me as "eh".  The mechanics work very well, but for most of the game I had no idea how I was doing (I came in a close second because everyone paniced and filled in the castle the last round).  Even with 5 people playing, it felt like a solitaire game.  On your move you try and make the optimal move that is left.  The only real interaction in the game is when moving the provost token to screw your opponents out of actions or replacing a tile someone else might want to use next turn.

I might try it one more time, but if I never do I won't be missing anything.

RATING: 8.5
There's so many things to like about the game: the nice wooden components, the small amount of downtime between turns, and the many paths to victory.  That being said, I have one major complaint about the game: I have a very hard time explaining the rules properly because there's so much interaction between the rules.  (Puerto Rico had this problem as well.)  To teach this game to my opponents, I have to explain the rules during play.  It gets really frustrating explaining the rules for the first few turns, but by turn 5 or so, the opponents usually have a good understanding of the rules and then the game goes much more quickly.  Still, if your opponents can get through one game, they'll usually come back for more.  Then the game is fantastic.

RATING: 8.2
gekocht op Zuiderspel (april 2012) Eindhoven, eerste maal geprobeerd op... 30 december 2012. Als bouwmeester bouw je met je arbeiders aan het kasteel en/of aan het dorp langs de weg door grondstoffen te spenderen. De grondstoffen hout, linnen, voedsel, steen en goud kunnen worden gewonnen door de arbeiders, die op hun beurt weliswaar betaald moeten worden met dinars. Veel bouwen leidt tot prestigepunten, en af en toe ook tot koninklijke privileges. De volgorde van acties uitvoeren is heel belangrijk, en het nodige inzicht daarin vereist toch wel een zekere minimumleeftijd ("12+"). De spelregels lijken heel ingewikkeld, maar eens je aan het spelen bent, valt dat eigenlijk best nog wel mee. 
Gespeeld met Ward (8) in de vereenvoudigde versie (zonder koninklijke privileges); ging wel, maar het was toch wat veel/lang voor hem. Hij heeft het toch tot het einde volgehouden. :)

RATING: 5.8
After a few plays I can see why it's so highly regarded. So many choices, so many effects, so many strategies. Is it the 2nd coming of Puerto Rico? Who cares? This is a decent game in it's own right and it doesn't need to lean on the reputation of the aforementioned game. That being said, it's not the the holy grail of games that some keep searching for. There is no such white elephant, keep looking. However, to the rest of us poor schlugs who just enjoy good games with many ways to win, a little screwage factor, and some fun, I recommend Caylus to you. Pity the poor fools who must compare everything to the "almighty" PR. Nuff' said. Still....after all the hype I can't help but be disappointed.  It's good but not nearly as great as it's being billed and too long for "what it is".

RATING: 7
Caylus is a pure Euro in which you are all helping to build a castle for fame and victory points.  This is a worker placement game in which more building sites are made available as the game progresses.  A unique aspect of the game is that the buildings are being added along a road and there is a provost piece that can be moved back and forth at the advancing edge of this zone that can result in some of the new buildings not being available for use.  This makes for some tense moments and bargaining.  Other than that, one is accumulating resource cubes by using the buildings (only one worker per building) and to build more buildings and ultimately add to the castle.  There is also an interesting mechanic with king's favors that advance one along one of several tracks that provide useful bonuses, depending on the strategy one has adopted.  Overall, an enjoyable game so I'll not say no to it but not one that grips me afterwards or gets me looking forward to the next game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good worker placement game.  Plays well with 2-4.  I have little 5p experience, but it's supposed to be good with that number as well.

This is one that was played to death by a lot of people when it first came out.  I didn't play it that much, but it still makes it difficult to get on the table now.  BSW has a good implementation, although most of the games there are played 2p.  Expect to see a heavy emphasis on the building favors track, as that seems to dominate the 2p online games.  I'm not saying that it's an unbeatable strategy, rather that for whatever reason the online players gravitate heavily toward that style of play.

I would like to play this more, and especially get a group to the point where more is understood about the provost.  Most players treat this exclusively as a hammer to use against unwitting folks who hang their workers way out toward the baliff.  It's used less often to control game length, which I suspect is its main strength.

RATING: 8
The new board fixes is the color issue, so I bump the game to a well deserved 8 rating.

I really like this game, but I had to ding it pretty hard for its color blind gamer unfriendliness. Could they have made the color squares on the tiles any smaller? Or used less distict colors? Who thinks picking colors consisting of grey, brown, pink, purple and yellow is a good idea?
Oh well the game itself is great, but I made several blunders because I mistook one of the small colors on the board for a different color.

It's the kind of game that you don't want to ask somebody what color a critical icon is, because you will invariably give away your intentions and allow someone else to thwart them.

RATING: 6
Update: Despite my lukewarm impression of the game, I have also bought the deluxe version. While the usability of components in Mike Doyle's version is poor(er), it just looks darn cool. :)

First impression: Nice, heavy German game, but too darn long and slow for its own good. Plenty of tactical and strategical choices and multiple paths to victory lead to a challenging game.

But to me it's not even close to the classics in the genre. I feel Caylus has a processual and over-complex feel to it, which I normally associate with Rüdiger Dorn's designs: Lots and lots and lots of elements in the game all interacting in various ways and the whole thing, while fun, all comes out seeming a bit messy and making you think whether the designer couldn't have cut 25% of the rules without impacting the depth of the game.

The processual feel reminds me of Goa, where one's planning is also of the "if I do A, I can then do B, which will give me the resources to buy C, which will let me get D, which yields VP, etc." kind.

My main dissatisfaction with the game, however, is its slow pace and its resulting (much too long) length. Could the game be played comfortably in about 1½ hours, my rating would go up (at least) a point.

RATING: 9
Tense, fairly deep, probably the best worker placement game.  Definitely more to it than meets the eye.  Have played many times with 2/3 and once with 5; like it more with 2/3 players.

The provost, and the faceoff for the castle have to be the two most important parts of this game; the fight over the castle creates fantastic tension.  But there isn't just one way to win.

I really like the simplicity of setup, the lack of thousands of bits, and the tense, but not overwrought gameplay Caylus brings to the table.

RATING: 6.5
2011-10-15  

Initial Rating: 9.5 (October 2010)

A game I have played a few times and I think that´s why I enjoy it. I feel the game has little replayability as the tactics and strategies remain the same (but the fun is in learning them) game after game. Initially I preferred this over Agricola, but I now realize I’m  enjoying Agricola more and more. Agricola, with its myriads of cards, offers a radical different experience with each game while Caylus will stagnate (I feel) after a determinate number of plays.

However Caylus is a very well designed game, there is always great pressure on what to do on your turn, there's is very little luck in the game (a fact that I always like in strategy games) and I really like the resource management/worker placement dynamics. 

I think this game will go no further in my personal ratings but right now Caylus is a game I really enjoy so I won’t refuse a play of it....yet.

Caylus was part of my top ten favorite games some time ago.

RATING: 8
Competition can be very intense for favors and over the provost, making this game a relatively more stressful experience.

Gets less interesting with more players.  5 really isn't a good number for this game; there's too little to be accomplished and too much downtime.

Caylus really goes up and down for me, more than any other game.  Right now it's down, or at least "meh."  This is probably the most "elegant" implementation of worker placement, to throw out a Euro buzzword, but it doesn't always feel fun to me, and that means a lot.

In the end I think Caylus is probably too confrontational a game for me to really enjoy.  I don't find the maneuvering for the favor and the screwage of the provost particularly fun or interesting, though they do encourage player interaction.

RATING: 8
I avoided this game for almost 2 years.  A family member owned it and kept trying to get it to the table, but I thought it looked dry and tedious.  One night, three of us decided to bite the bullet and just get it over with.  Well, all three of us left the table and couldn't wait to play it again.  It hits the perfect balance of the game mechanisms we love...worker placement, resource management, engine-building, various routes to victory (but not too many), a little take-that (when you just have to make a move that messes someone else's game up).  There is surprisingly low down-time, and that time is taken up scouring the board for your next move, especially when the previous player took your planned move out from under you.  This is a top 10 for sure.  I most love it with 3 players, but 2 is good too.  I bought a copy for my husband and I.

RATING: 5
I play a lot of 5 player and the game is too long for that, even when my son becomes the Caylus Commando.  I like games that make you plan ahead.  I also like games that make you think on your feet and adjust your strategy because of what others are doing.  Unfortunately, this game really requires you to do both and that is what marks it down for me.  What I mean by that is - if you have to plan out something for a couple of turns to be really successful, but then also have to change your plans quickly because of what others do, it is hard to do the first thing.  It is like those two aspects of the game work against each other.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another play... another bump in my rating. Fans of [b]Ys[/b], [b]Manila[/b] and [b]Puerto Rico[/b] should enjoy this one.  Place meeples (actually workers... but they [i]could[/i] have been meeples) to do your work and get awards.

There are  different awards for different buildings.  Costs and bonuses make it a tight resource management game.  The early game is cutthroat... there are only 22 initial places for workers, and six workers for each of the five players.

The game length can be controlled somewhat by the players themselves by movement of the [i]Provost[/i]... a mechanic that I tend to like.  Want a short game? Move him forward... Screw your neighbour and extend the game?  Move him back.

Because it's a perfect information game, I think that the game will be [b]very[/b] prone to [i]analysis paralysis[/i] for certain players.  I expect that a five player game to take [i]at least[/i] a half hour for each player for the first few games.  This will definitely improve as players become familiar with the mechanics.  

[b]Caylus[/b] is a mix of many different mechanics and it seems to be very well balanced with many paths to victory.  If it sells as well as I think it will, I expect that there will be additional building expansions in the future.  My only problem with the game is that, like [b]Puerto Rico[/b], there is no DIRECT player interaction... no trading, no direct competition and any deals that a player might make with others are not binding. I agree with Mike Siggins in that the game really deserves a bit more luck and, maybe, hidden resources.  It definitely won't unseat [b]Louis XIV[/b] as my favourite game of 2005, but it's close.  Like a lot of other games, it gets better with every play.  And now that it's on BSW, I've played it more in the past three weeks than the number of times I played Louis XIV all last year!

RATING: 10
Really, what's wrong with this game?  Zero luck!  Not too difficult to learn, but there are several subtle strats you need to know to do really well.  After several face-to-face and even more BSW plays, this gem stays atop as my favorite.
Each round is a challenge to maximize your worker placements and slow your opponents.  The provost adds a little bit of nastiness, but careful play can minimize the risk.  Biggest rookie mistake is to not share the burden of the provost movement and get burned too often.

RATING: 5
Rating after 30-35 plays.  Downgraded rating from an initial 8 mainly because I find no great desire to play it that much. My recent thoughts are that while this is a solid game, the favor tracks are not balanced -- the resource track does not seem to be as strong as the building track or the VP track which seem to be the key paths to victory.  It's not a killer like the Mistress on Turn 1 in St Petersburg, and there are things you can do to control the situation.  It's just that I don't find Caylus as interesting given more recent games such as Leonardo, Imperial, Pillars or Through the Ages.  In retrospect, I believe Caylus' high ratings here on BGG are an artifact of the fact that there were few other strong new games at Essen 2005, whereas the larger group of stronger games (many of which took several months to work their way up the charts) meant none of those games got the immediate boost up the charts we saw with Caylus.The rest is from of my original comment, from over a year ago:  OK, shoot me, but I just don't think this game is the second coming many here have raved about.  No doubt about, Caylus is a very good game, well thought out, fairly straightforward and some unique game mechanics, but it is NOT in the same class as my two all-time favorites, Die Macher and Puerto Rico.  It is at heart a resource management and placement game, placement of the workers being the key strategic decision each turn.  Game differs tremendously with different numbers of players, in my view it's a bit too easy with 3, too chaotic with 5, feels about right with 4.  I generally like games where you have alot of choices, in Caylus, at times, it seems there are almost too many choices--meaning it's a game that could suffer from analyis paralysis with the wrong set of players.  You basically have to decide on an optimum play or set of plays each turn that is unlikely to be disrupted by your opponents.  Caylus was easily the best new game from Essen 2005, but it was generally a weak year for really good new games there.  I wonder if the game will retain its current level of popularity say, five years from now.

Sept. 2010 Update:  Re-rated the game for a second time, dropped it to a 5.  Not only do I have no desire to play  it any more, I have actually used the bits from my original game for prototypes and mock-ups from other games ... never a good sign.  This game, which was the darling of the Geeks when it first came out, has fallen mightily in my opinion.  I know there are people out there that still love and appreciate it, but I am not one of them.

RATING: 7
There are some complexities to doing well in this game that may take a couple plays to understand. You are collecting resources to help build the castle and to build new buildings. The buildings keep getting better so the best are near the front of the road. Unfortunately, there is a marker that people can move to prevent use of spaces near the end of the road. Also there is a bonus for building the most at the castle during a turn. So trying to predict your neighbor is part of the challenge. Finally one must save the proper resources and build some prerequisite buildings to be able to build the buildings with the most victory points. Note the iPad version seems well done and offers some challenging play.

Finally played this and liked it. I love the multitude of choices and how you can plan one turn off of another to create opportunities. The provost is a nice screwage element. Took 4 of us two and a half hours and I'm confident we'll bring that down with more familiarity. [update: times in cleanly under 2 hours for an experienced group.] Good good stuff.

RATING: 8
It's difficult to learn the game by reading the rules (though the rules are very well-written), but once you start playing it's all very intuitive.  The theme of the game is kind of ho-hum, but it is very challenging, offering a plethora of choices that can almost be overwhelming.  The choice of buildings and how they work together seems to be much more involved, than, say, Puerto Rico.  I like the mechanism of the provost, which adds a bit of uncertainty and double-guessing.  I have been pleasantly surprised with the playing time - our initial 3-player game clocked in at 1.75 hours including rules, and subsequent play makes it more of a 1 hour game, which is great.  I find that a 2/3 player game is much different than 4/5 as resources/money are much more plentiful, rendering many of the buildings/options less useful.  But because of play time alone, I would hesitate to play this with 4 or 5.

RATING: 8
There are mostly things to like. The only random variables are at the setup creating differing starts for the game while not damaging any player, there's a lot of resource management (workers, money, goods), new buildings brought into play make the older ones "obsolete", choices are always tough: whether to take this or that when knowing that you really won't be getting the other one later, both strategic and tactical elements, several different ways to score, no clear strategy to win, no real downtime and a good level of player interaction. And the game seems to be all the merrier and tighter the more players you have. Only negative aspect so far is that a player who sees he has run out of chances to win may just start to push the game to end faster and become a kingmaker in the process. That's not nice in a game that lasts so long. Also, the balance of the favour track may be an issue.

RATING: 9
There are constant decisions here and you have to weigh their values against what you think others might do before your next choice. The game's weakness is that a player can be in such a poor position by mid-game that he has no reasonable chance to win. Update: After hundreds of plays online and 15 in person this game never gets old. For my taste Caylus is the first and only %u201Cperfect%u201D boardgame. Bravo Signor Attia! Update - back to 9: On further reflection and after about a year in which I have not played a game in which someone could compete with me I have to admit that there is a flaw in the game that affects my enjoyment - the fact that an experienced player will absolutely crush an inexperienced one and this will happen 100% of the time. I really prefer games where the experienced player wins 70% of the time - decisions are still meaningful and strategic but the game's outcome is in doubt for much of the game. The only solution to this is to concentrate on five player games - a great player can lose those to a good player due to the luck of what other players choose. Perhaps then the five player game still deserves a rating of 10.

RATING: 7
Worker placement game that could be, and perhaps should be for best effect, utterly calculating and cutthroat. My first game took around four hours but didn't really feel like it. Complete lack of cards is appreciated. It's obvious that this can be a completely different game depending on how the provost is handled, and how much attention players pay to what can and should be done to control the game timer and/or hurt those who expose themselves to hurtage. As another example of how mistakes can be brutally punished, the programmed order of resolution means that being blocked out of an action can render already placed workers useless and effectively set you back an entire turn. The prudence and analysis that is ultimately called for will not make for a casual game.

Reading the comments of my GeekBuddies revealed some interesting contradictions: it's too dry, but it's too chaotic; it's the first of its kind, but it's a complete rip-off. There were also some seemingly valid concerns about playability and replayability, e.g. blandness of actions and currencies, efficiency imbalances, lack of evolving gameplay, kingmaking through action or inaction. However, these are hardly uncommon characteristics in games, even good and/or acclaimed ones.

RATING: 8
The game design is a little bland, but the game itself is exceptional. It scales well for two players, with lots of choices and just the right amount of confrontation. I especially like the fact that players can speed up or slow down the game! No doubt about it, Caylus is a superb Euro worker placement game. It's the chess of the Euro game world, with essentially no luck and enough strategic decisions to keep it fresh through hundreds of plays. Unfortunately, being able to play it on iOS or online in half the time made it pointless to keep a copy of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Complex and breathtaking strategy game, which plays equally well with 2, 3, 4 or 5 players. A huge number of choices and options, which only expand as the game progresses and new buildings are constructed along the road to the castle. Downtime between turns is very low, as you are constantly involved. Very low on luck: only the initial starting order and the order of the neutral buildings. The gameboard is beautifully designed - all the information you need is either indicated on the board or the tiles.

RATING: 8
I can understand how it seems repetitive and dry to some, because of no luck, no secrets and no surprises (unless you count opponents' sudden changes of strategy or bluffs with the provost that really got you). Even though it's about exploiting the same linear process every time, each game is quite different, and individual strategies can make it a game of scarcity or a resource-rich race for the big points. Keeps you on your toes and thinking way ahead for the chaining of actions and resources needed for them, which is why in Caylus I don't mind a little downtime.

Caylus works very good even with 2 players. The only gripe I'm having is that it really doesn't speed up much with experience. No way will this be played in the 30min/player that the box implies.

For the time being, Caylus is but a humble village, but soon, workers and craftsmen will be flocking by the cartload, attracted by the great prospects. Around the building site, a city is slowly rising up.

The players embody master builders. By building the King's castle and developing the city around it, they earn prestige points and gain the King's favor. When the castle is finished, the player who has earned the most prestige wins the game. The expansion Caylus Expansion: The Jeweller was included in the 2nd Edition.

RATING: 3
There is 2 things I find good about this game. First all the rules are on the board, it makes it easier not to forget anything.

Second, I like making buildings where other people will give me points and resources to use them. It feels like monopoly: I'll build an hotel there and I expect high income. So you have to judge what the players need and build it. This is fun.

As for the rest of the game, I find it really boring. First, you can screw your self really easily if you miscalculate. At the beginning there is not much buildings so it's easier but when there is a lot of buildings it can become hard to calculate.

Second, this game  as a common syndrome that I found in hacienda. You have so many ways to score points that whatever you do, you will end up with an competitive score. So that in the ends, you do not really know that made you won.

Finally, some favors are really not useful compared to other favors. Getting extra cubes or building is no way comparable to getting more gold and victory points. In our game, the leader won because he collected 5 VP favor at least 5 times.

RATING: 9
Don't play Caylus with newbies: you'll probably have them snoring halfway through the explanation of the rules. But if you play it with a bunch of seasoned gamers - as you should - you'll discover an exquisite and perfectly balanced mechanic and I pretty much guarantee you'll have a great time (although don't play with 5 players or it will take too long). All the hype surrounding Caylus is totally justified and well deserved. The gameplay is very coherent, all the systems nicely fit together. However, since there is zero luck involved (apart from the initial play order) Caylus is a ruthlessly unforgiving game. Make a single mistake and you will be punished heavily and suffer to make a comeback. But that's the price to pay if you want to compete with the best. If you can play Caylus and survive, you're essentially ready to play anything. The only reason I won't give it a 10 is that its artwork is so ugly it's a crime.

RATING: 8
Gran juego al que le veo 2 peros que le restan a mi opinión algunos enteros:
1. Aunque es un juego donde caben diversas posibilidades y estrategias, si tu rival utilizan contantemente el castillo para hacer PV's, a ti no te queda más remedio que hacer lo propio si no quieres quedarte atrás en el marcador de puntos.
2. El hecho de que los edificios que un jugador construya puedan ser utilizados por los rivales con una pobre compensación por ello hace que la estrategia creada por un jugador pueda ser destruida por sus rivales, sino aprovechada por ellos; este aspecto es el que más me chirría del juego, aunque no deja de tener su lado positivo; es un arma de doble filo al que le veo más peros que a favores, y que conste que soy de los que gustan de reventar las estrategias ajenas.
Una opción más que interesante es eliminar este efecto y que lo que construya cada jugador sólo pueda usarlo para sí; de esta forma el juego se convierte en una lucha de estrategias puras sin interferencias.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Caylus's tremendous success implies that my tastes are very different than the average Eurogamer's. In particular, I think that tactical resource management isn't my thing. Where Puerto Rico has just enough strategy to keep it from being obnoxious to me, Caylus almost completely lacks long-term planning, and, as a result, I have little desire to play.

Now that the touchy-feely "this isn't my thing" stuff is out of the way, I also think that Caylus suffers from real design flaws as well, but most BGGers enjoy the good stuff *so* much that they just don't care. In particular, the castle is a big distraction from the heart of the game, which is the play on the road. If the castle was excised, the game would be faster, tighter, and more focused. You might need to add something to the road to make up for the castle's absence, but I think it would be a much more pleasant experience.

Unfortunately, this still doesn't address a rather boring resource-gathering element. With rare exceptions, the first part of each turn is a mad dash to gather as many resources as possible, with building options and a couple of other buildings like the jousting field and the inn the only buildings that compete on equal footing with the best available resource buildings. The special power buildings are much more interesting than the resource gathering ones, though, so the focus on resources, I think, makes the game rather dry.

Finally, provost play tends to swing between irrelevant – except siphoning away a little luchre – and massive screwage, with little in between. There is potential in the mechanic, but it doesn't seem to be properly set up. I can think of alternative rules for provost movement, but without playtesting it is hard to say which might be better.

While I bear Caylus no ill will, it definitely serves as an example of where my taste in games differs significantly from that of the BGG population as a whole.

RATING: 9
Such a variety of avenues to victory....even when the game is tight, there are many, many options. 

First came Ys from Ystari, which was a 9...with it's expansion it became a 10.

I was never surprised that their next release would be even better. I expect great things in Ystari's future.

Superb production values and graphic design are a hallmark of this company and it's games. If you are looking for a short game, or a filler, they have nothing to offer you. If you are looking for a deep gamer's game, welcome home.

Update:

Pending another play, this might drop as far as a 8. The mechanics are brilliant, and I really want to love this game, but I suppose maybe I just don't get it.

Either way, I'll play again and we'll see.

Update:

More plays, more effort, more paying attention to the people beating me silly finally gave me my light bulb moment. It's as good as I ever thought.

Update:

I finally knocked this one out of my top 10. Too many worker placement options have come along to outclass this one, however, it's one of the very few originals of the genre, and while still viable, is not the greatest among its peers.

RATING: 9
The first worker placement game.  Place workers on buildings to gather resources, build buildings and score points from building.  Send batches of resources to the castle to score points.  There is some complexity in the economy as you must build residences before prestige buildings.  It can be fiddly in that you cannot forget to pay for your workers.  Money is very tight in the game.  

There are many people who criticize this game as dry, but the mechanics and the elegance of the game make it very fun.  I still play and I still have things to learn about this game.

RATING: 8
Very straight and cut-throat game, always very satisfying to play. Unsurpassed classic.
