=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Played 27 times]

Excellent game featuring almost everything that I like in a game: resource management (workers, money, goods), incremental building (new tiles are progressively more powerful), a "draft" element (you must choose the priority of what you want to pick), strategy (plan ahead), tactic (seize opportunities), no luck (just two random elements during setup, to create a little more variety), several different ways to score (and thus to win), excellent balancement between the various possible styles of play.
The decisions you must take look simple, but often they aren't (since you must choose only one of the many opportunities, considering the immediate gain but also the long-term effects).
A game for gamers due to the several options that must be analyzed each turn, but it probably could be enjoyed by casual players too.
It scales well (more players mean more tension but more downtime: I consider 3 the optimal number, followed by 2 and 4, while 5 isn't as good).
The rulebook is very clear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Why is this game so great to play? I like games in which you’re building something up; where your constructions help you later in the game. This is true in Caylus for both building houses as gaining favourites from the king.
Each game of Caylus feels really different, simply because houses are being built in a different order, which opens new possibilities very soon or only late in the game. The builder houses function more or less like a modular board that is being laid out due to player actions as the game progresses.
Moreover,  it is nice that you can really adopt several strategies; going for bare points; going for the castle; going for house building; or aiming at large monumentral buildings in the end. All strategies can be maximized by tuning your actions to it, especially when you really focus them  towards one goal. There seems to be no best strategy for all situations. It seems te depend on the number of players and on the order in which the first buildings are being built.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can see why this game is popular, but it's not for me, at least not yet.  Played on game with 5 people, all fairly new.  The game was interesting to be sure, but not one that really trigger that urge to play it again that I get with other new games.

Pros
- interesting mechanics with the bailiff (source of all of our player interaction.
- most actions are fairly intuitive.

Cons.
- No excitement.  We played it as a series of micro efficiency plays.  Afterward there was exactly one play that folks could point to as fun.  (a spirited debate on whether or not to collectively screw the leader with the bailiff.
- Long play with lots of downtime between turns.  Clearly this is a reflection of the number and newness of the players, but this will not be an uncommon situation for our group.
- Too hard to plan ahead.  Playing with five, it was too difficult to do anything but react.  The board is completely different between moves.  I think that I would enjoy this more with fewer players.

Final note.  If I knew that we'd be playing this a lot, then it will likely go up in ratings.  The play time would drop and the appreciation for the subtlties of the strategy would go up.  As it stands, I do not see this likely since the barrier to entry and dryness of play is too high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is no doubt an exceptional game. In particular, I appreciate how well it plays with 2. Unfortunately, it is really really DRY! The game definitely rewards multiple plays since you have to learn the various buildings. Realistically, you are looking at 5+ plays to have a good grasp. For me, there's just other games that I would rather bring out instead.  

Update 7/5/15:

I can't really understand how novice gamers enjoy this game. Caylus is ridiculously tight and unforgiving. This is of particular importance in remembering to have resources before you build AND making sure that you have met the appropriate steps in order to build. However, once you understand the importance of activation order and timing, you can really start to appreciate how clean and beautifully designed this game is. As a seasoned gamer now, I really appreciate this. It's interesting how much more I like it now (so much more). It's just a superb game. The only down side (sort of) is that it is still really dry. It does help to have the Collectors edition though, with the beautiful art and nice components. Overall, I like some of it's "knock-offs" more--like Lords of Waterdeep. But, I still like this game, and if I have 2 hours and I'm in the mood for something brain-burning, this will be near the top of the list. 

*FIMO miniatures

RATING: 10

Each game plays quite a bit differently since the order of the optional buildings and the timing of the quarry and the lawyer drastically affect the flow of the game. Great game that I'd play over Puerto Rico in a heartbeat.

RATING: 8.7
Often referred to as the "grandfather" of worker placement games, how could Caylus possibly contend with modern worker placement games? The answer most certainly involves player interaction, which Caylus unabashedly utilizes as a central mechanic. Many of your decisions will be a direct affront on your enemies, which is to say that Caylus is an extremely cutthroat, albeit rewarding Eurogame. As well or better than any mind-melting worker placement game, Caylus forces you to think your decisions through with thorough scrutiny, and makes you pay if you fail to do so. Masochists need not reconsider; pick Caylus up today!

RATING: 9.1
Un clásico, elegante como pocos, que jugado a dos o tres jugadores se convierte en un auténtico placer. Quizá el único defecto que tiene es que un jugador novato va a ser arrasado por jugadores expertos. Esto pasa en muchos juegos, especialmente en los que no hay azar, como es el caso.

Si te gustan los euros y los juegos con cero azar, Caylus es un obligatorio.

RATING: 9
An open information sequential resolution worker placement/action selection game- which I would normally by wary of, but Caylus has a nice 'take that' mechanism that sees players spending resources to restrict the number of actions resolved post-selection. Few other subsequent worker placement games replicated this facet (Carson City, perhaps excepted). For me it's what sets it apart from other similar games. 

Scales well from 2-4 players, 5 is a bit chaotic. I have had some truly memorable games of this that have been cut throat and down to the wire.

RATING: 9
Favorite Variants:

Gate activates any open space immediately when the gate is resolved.

Cube track gives 2 benefits each time it is activated (can't choose same benefit twice with the same favor). 

for example, if you are on the 1st spot and activate, you move to the 2nd spot. You can then activate the 1st AND 2nd benefit. 

if you are on the 0 spot and move to the 1st spot, you only get 1 benefit since you can't activate the 1st spot twice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Surprisingly positive experience, but I'd expected it to loathe it. Reading the rules it is anthesis to much of what I enjoy the most in games - A hodgepodge of mechanics with gears protruding from the ugly brown framework, nothing is cleanly derived from some overarching principle or idea, everything is just numbers camouflaged by differently coloured cubes. 

However, it has a nasty streak and is not filled with excess like other games in the vein. It's sparse, restrained and works a lot better than the rules suggest. Runs smooth even. Some will not enjoy the added screwage, the lack of anything resembling theme, or the fact that you're not "building something" like you do in Agricola, but I enjoy the meanness of it and the relative simplicity of it's various subsystems. The only thing that will take time for players to familiarise themselves with the building-mix, without which I think it'll bog down quickly as players have to look them up over and over again. This makes it better for me than other games in this category.

RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Compete to get different cubes (resources), use cubes to  build different stuff, different stuff gives points in different ways, most points win!

Played as: 3 player

Pros: Took a basic worker placement mechanic and added a twist to make it interactive. Even the most basic strategy takes a fair amount of careful planning and forethought. There's not too many games that I feel every minute of the two hours or so it takes to play is both important but also fun... this is one.

Cons: Man is this a brain-burner. Every little cube seems so important, I have a tough time keeping track of it all in my head. It's hard not getting a serious case of analysis paralysis. I guess this could be a pro too.

Other: I was borderline on thinking I had it rated a little high as a 9. After I tried Goa, it was enough to take this down a notch. It, Goa, just felt so similar, but more forgiving in the 'Am I sure I got this figured exact?' category.

Best Use: For three people looking to burn their brains for a couple hours.

RATING: 8.5
A multi-faceted game with various routes to victory & an overall great design.  There's area control, resources, building, action/role selection, etc. I suspect the group you play will heavily influence what type of game it becomes. It could be a screw your neighbor negotiation game (moving the provost, paying attention to what your opponents are going for & beating them to it).  The number of players also changes the game (it's much tighter and danger lurks with 5 compared to 3).  

Beware of min-maxers, there's a lot going on.  The bottom line is, and I've said this before, you have to be flexible with this one.  Long-term stategies are good but you're going to be forced into a lot of tactical decisions.  

UPDATE: moved rating down .75 points.  I'm just not as excited about this & it's a long game.  It's an uber-euro that's as tough as your opponent's are bright.

RATING: 8
i own the special edition

**** UPDATE SEPT 2009 ****

caylus has aged pretty well considering the absolute slew of worker placement derivatives that have appeared since launch.  i still dislike a bit of the way that the favor tracks operate and i have some hang-ups about the premium buildings, but it is still really good. 

i have had two poor caylus playing experiences and they soured my taste a bit.  one, was a 5 player slogging that just did not work and really drug along (this seems to be true for most worker placement games).  the other, was a simple 3 player, but one AP player ensured that this went 60+ minutes too long.  

initial plays, will seem to take a bit too long, but i encourage to give it another couple of plays before giving up on the game.

******

2 player has become a bit less satisfying as it seems that the actual paths to victory are reduced to manipulating the building track.  there is just not enough other ways to offset those potential points in a 2p game.

RATING: 5
Update Sep2016:  Revisited this comment on Caylus (due an opportunity to play again after all this time), but can't quite figure out specifically why I reduced the rating from an initial rating of "7" down to a "5".  Which is another reason why I should probably use update notes like this one more often...

Anyways, my previous comments regarding the length of play and the mostly opportunistic/tactical nature of most of the decision making are probably the main reasons.  

I don't mind tactical decision making in games , if it is in turn supported by some other game elements, like strong thematic immersion and a game narrative (e.g. wargames, ameritrash, some multi-player strategy games), or offset by a shorter playing time, characteristics which Caylus does not possesses. 

So, it stays at a "5".

--------------------------

Only one play so far (3 players).  Enjoyed the game, but it was long (2.5 hrs).  Seems to be alot of variety/options/paths in attaining VPs.  Don't think I'd play with more than 4 due to concerns regarding game length.

Like many euros, a very weak connection between the theme and game mechanics.  Addicting (for a first time player) in that there seem to be a variety of different strategies that can be pursued. But, some of the endgame buildings really don't seem balanced. 

Analytical, opportunistic/tactical gameplay with some room for longterm planning (maybe... need to play more).

RATING: 7
I have an inexplicable attraction to this game. My rational mind tells me it is a dull cube-farming game with one moderately inventive mechanic (the provost). But ...  mustt  ... haveve ... cubbbbbeeeeezzzzzz!

This game is like Chess, but with complicated rules. Sure, you can say about any perfect information game that it's like Chess, but Caylus is also like Chess in that one wrong move leads to disaster if your opponent knows how to exploit it. If you have trouble in Chess with making mistakes that cost you the game, imagine how much harder it is with 10 times the rules to keep track of, any of which can be exploited against you.

I like games with lots of rules, but where a big mistake can be made up for by a preponderance of better play for the rest of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Played once as a two-player game.  A tremendously thought-intensive game that requires an insane mix of strategy (much to plan and ponder before you even put down your first piece) and tactics (each area on the board can only be occupied by 1 player per turn, so you're often blocked from doing what you want).  The game is complicated, but the board is exquisitely designed and thus makes the game easy to keep up with once you've started.  

As I've heard from other people, it seems like the game is likely best with either 2 or 3 people; I thoroughly enjoyed it as a 2 player game.  I'm a wee bit concerned that player experience-level will dictate the outcome, as there is absolutely no random component to the game at all (except deciding who starts).  

Definitely a game on-par with Puerto Rico, Princes of Florence, and other great games.

Update: after something like 2 or 3 years, I've now finally played it a second time.  I played with four players, and we finished the game in 2.5 hours (not including rules and setup); it was quite enjoyable, and good brain exercise.  Very nice!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Play as master builders in charge of building the castle and town of Caylus. Players place workers and build buildings to produce and obtain various resources, favors, money, and other items to earn prestige points. It’s a massive resource game where you must remain flexible based on other player’s choices. 

After hearing all the hype on this game I have to say it lives up to the promise! Although seemingly complex at first, game play is intuitive and easy to pick up. The design itself is superb and most everything you need to reference is either on the pieces or the board itself. It is a little hard to explain as there are lots and lots of things to do. New players may feel a little lost at first but will soon find that the game gels pretty quickly after a couple of rounds. Also, it’s one of the few games with perfect information and multiple paths to victory, which is always a good hallmark for deep complex strategies. It doesn’t seem to be prone to too much analysis paralysis from players, especially from this type of game. Very highly recommended and a must for fans of “Puerto Rico” and “Louis XIV.”

RATING: 6
Excellent game, but I feel it's so close in theme and execution to Keythedral (which I own), that I no longer feel a great desire to own this.

Update: my original rating of "9" was adjusted downwards to "6". Why? The first game played was with two others who were also learning. The second game was with one experienced player, and 3 learners. I realize now that this game is overwhelmingly hard to learn on your first play; this degrades it for me, as it seems I'm always playing games with at least one player who's never played that game. Games that are this difficult mean (a) every game will be a struggle to shepherd the newbie through the maze, and (b) lots of newbies won't be back. In our second game (at a con), two newbies dropped out about 45 minutes from the end to go do something else. That's not an endorsement.

There are numerous things about this game that drove me mad on second play. The bingo-chip money. The hundreds of information "bits" on the board. The constantly changing turn order (we made at least a dozen errors of playing out of turn). The activation order based on the winding road (several players booted their entire turn because they misinterpreted which building would activate first). The provost mechanic which introduces a very cheap "screw-you!" factor. I'm just not motivated to play this one again.

RATING: 8
Perfect information and minimally different setups (it's rare that the ordering of the first 6 buildings actually makes a huge difference in strategy or outcome) means this is a strange mix of solvable logical/economic puzzle and arm-wrestling match. Still, a remarkable game. It's easy for one or two players to be out of the running midway through the game, and that can suck the air out of the provost mechanism if they lose interest in trying to win or just decide to mess with the leader.

Probably has been bettered by later worker placement games, but still worth playing. BGA has a decent implementation though playing turn-based with sluggish players is NOT recommended, a single game can drag on for months.

RATING: 7
I like the mechanics and theme of Caylus but the various strategic and the constant review of calculations of options make it feel more like tedious work than fun. I can't help but feel that each session has about 4-5 rounds too many, especially in the end game. Doesn't get on the table much with gamers I know but I like to play it occasionally. Hugely prone to analysis paralysis blowing out the play time ad increasing waiting player's boredom. Movement of the provost seems to bring out bitterness and angst among gamers I've played with, too, but I think players should just accept the risk of placing workers so near the provost and plan accordingly. The iOS version of Caylus makes it much more playable because it takes out all annoying and repetitive administration from the game, and I only rate Caylus a 7.5 on that basis.

RATING: 7
Well, time surely hasn't been kind to Caylus. This used to be one of my favourite games, but revisiting it in 2015 was a disappointment. Sure, it's still an ok worker-placement game which requires good timing and some messing with the other players' plans, but a certain dryness and even some boredom has set in. Basically no luck involved. The turns feel awfully boring, I didn't care about what I did anymore, especially if you compare it to other more modern worker-placement games like Tzolk'in, Castles of Burgundy or even Lords of Waterdeep, which I guess kind of streamlined the core idea & added some cool flavour. Very cut-throat, which appeals to some players. Or maybe I just had a bad day.

RATING: 9
12/19/10 Comment:  Played my 6th game and still no win :(  Doesn't matter, still a very good game.  I just need to adjust my strategy based on what I see other's doing.  Glad I own this title.

Update:  I'll leave my original comments below.  I have a more favorable opinion of this game now for 2 reasons.
1) I've read the rules my self, and buildings make more sense to me now that I understand their usage.
2) I've played both Agricola & Le Havre and both of these have way more options to evaluate than Caylus, causing AP.  Thus I prefer Caylus to both of these.

Old Comments:
Good game.  Lots of strategy.  Even though I enjoy this worker placement game, I find it a bit overcomplicated.

This game has a little too many bits & pieces.  By default I take a point away from games that require continuously referencing the instructions to understand the building types available and their powers.  Puerto Rico falls into this category, and now so does Agricola & Le Havre.

This bogs the game down and causes AP even in non-AP players, because there are too many things to evaluate.

I prefer Pillars of the Earth.

RATING: 10
Acquired: Sept 25, 2007 new
This game is just incrediable!!!!  Object is to set out workers to gain resources (food, wood, stone, cloth, and gold) and denier (money) in order to build a castle and earn the king's favor....which are bonuses (either prestine points (vp's), money, resources, or to build building).  The game has got a great "screw your neighbor" aspect to it.  It plays great with 2 players, and goes up to 5.  I don't know if it's my best game (at this point on 9/25/07 it's El Grande) but right now it's got to be my favorite.

RATING: 8
Overall comment: Complex game with complex rules, once it is played through a couple of times then the strategy presents itself. Game has a plodding feel to it sometimes with many moves that are almost automatic. Advanced players cripple newbies which puts off replayability with new players.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor): 8 (pieces were interesting but the board seemed rather plain)
Family: 7 (rarely requested - wife will not touch it)
Game Group: 9 (want to play it often unless time is tight - requests have fallen off due to online play by the group players)
AP: 6 (occassionally game play gets hung up)
Solo play: 8.5 (has a high replay factor and helps to balance the game between the money, resources and victory points, the multiple paths to victory still exist and the SoloPlay version has rekindled the interest in this game)

When purchased: 2006
Recommend expansions: none available
Age range: 10+
Luck factor (1-10high): 1

Reason purchased: Geek and friend's recommendation

Pros: a "no luck" game with many easy-complicated decisions, play is quick with experienced players but games usually last 2 hours, different paths to victories are apparent, close scoring.
Cons: same game everytime, chess-like mechanics have developed now that everyone is experienced in the play, while different paths to victory are possible(it seems that only a couple actually work), programmed moves that if not taken will put a player behind quickly and catching up is difficult

Recommendation: it is tough not to recommend this game even given the cons, it is very good. It can be played by the casual gamer as well as the experienced one and still be fun. My kids, when they are into it, can play it very well and it is probably the most fun way to play now. The pros are too serious and do not want to employ variants to mix up the gameplay.
Replay rating: Moderate
Game value(play/cost ratio): Average (SoloPlay has raised the rating to average and possibly above-average)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In 13th century France, one attempts to aid in the construction of Caylus by erecting buildings, or help in the construction of the castle. Speed of the game is regulated by the movement of the bailiff, and which buildings get activated depends on the provost, who can be "bribed". Players put workers in turn order on different buildings to activate that building's special ability. There is a lot of interaction, strategy with placing workers to change turn order, earn money, etc. There is a royal favor section, 4 tracks of improvements for VPs, money, goods or building, where one can work on strategy. It is a long game, at about two and a half hours length. There are a multitude of strategies, and will vary with the number of players you play with. The manoeuvering of the provost does add a screw factor to the game, which can be cruel on beginners. 

This is the game that introduces the worker placement mechanic, so it is innovative. It's a bit longer than I would like, and I am lukewarm on this game, but I am in the minority here on BGG since most people really like this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Caylus has all the worst trappings of an early Euro game:

1) Opaque name that conjures up no image in the mind (turns out Caylus is a place, so it has that Euro stereotype too)

2) Bland, characterless art design. People in my gaming group passed on playing Caylus because it looks so ugly and boring. Glad the publisher changed the cover art on the box because the old one was terrible. If I'd known there was a Limited Edition version with all new art that makes the game look like an illuminated manuscript I would have bought it instead of buying the regular version, although the new imagery might be too dense to be easily decipherable for new players.

3) Medieval setting that doesn't involve knights in combat. Now this might just be the gripe of someone from outside Europe because the only thing we know about the Middle/Dark ages is that there were knights and crusades. Perhaps its a limitation in our education, but take a hint: Knights are cool. Use them or risk losing an international audience.

I'm not gonna add resource management, worker placement, and points for victory into the list. Yes, those are Euro stereotypes that some people hate, but that is why I bought Caylus. I wanted a deep game with those qualities.

Also, not sure if everyone's copy is like this, but the component quality is terrible. Misshapen houses, cubes with splinters of wood sticking out of them, cubes that were stuck together; just poorly crafted wooden parts.

This game is flat-out overrated. There are so many better games out there, let alone better Euros. What a disappointment!

RATING: 10
First things first: Avoid Caylus like the devil if you've got AP or play with those that do.  It will annihilate any sense of fun this game has to offer -- my rating drops to 4.5 with AP and/or players who do not actively participate in the road clearing.

Second: Man, this is not the game to drop on your in-laws over Thanksgiving.  This is a no-luck, open-info resource management cubefest.  There are several tactical choices to be made on any given round, and part of the strategy is developing a path that keeps you from being blocked in should the inevitable provost-fights tighten up the game flow.  Also, gameplay with 2 players is radically different than with 5 players; it's amazing the first time you try your small group tactics and see that they have NO CHANCE of working in a 5-player hootenanny.  Even more than a Rosenberg.

It's safe to call me an AT fan.  Maybe not a zealot, but a fan.  And Caylus has got me hooked.  So many ways to play, so many ways to win/lose.  If you rave about Agricola and can't find something good about Caylus, I call shenanigans.

2017 UPDATE: After nearly a decade, Caylus is about as perfect as it gets for me.

RATING: 10
While the topic doesn't strike as anything innovative (a castle being built among all players on the board, striving for the most prestige), Caylus is as memorable as it can be - I don't know any other game that gets twelve pages of rules (written in a transparent, concise style) to work in such a smooth way. This succeds mainly due to two big factors: 
* A rather long turn sequence where all the usual layers in German games are concerned (prestige, resources, money, buildings, turn order, bonuses) flies by with hardly any downtime. The usual recipe against waiting in between turns (having players taking small steps at a time) is carried out to great effect here since players have got to manage the placement of workers (it's not for free) and the range of options for them increases throughout the game.
* The board is designed in such a way that almost half of the sequence can be followed intuitively, and the rest can be easily repeated after a couple of rounds of play (not even a full game). 

As if the smoothness wasn't enough, Caylus boasts another unique feature: the duration of the game is limited to a maximum of rounds depending on the level of aggression the players want to achieve (this allowing a lot of nasty play).

Caylus is an iron fist in a silk glove: a game with staggering tactical richness, room for strategy and no trivial way to win. It manages to match the already incredible balance of complexity and playability of Puerto Rico: Caylus is not as sleek, but it offers even more substance without building on the same mechanisms. An absolute masterpiece and still today the measuring bar of worker placement games.

RATING: 8.5
A bit of a short life-span with two, but Caylus has an elegant and natural mechanic and features the key re-visit element: many possible routes to victory. The need to continuously re-evaluate your strategy on the fly is not that far removed from chess. It's hardly a pretty piece of work, but there are few flaws and the game's status is secure as the quintessential Eurogame to many people. The Royal Favour track can be a little unbalanced with an experienced crowd, but that only adds to the strategy.

Further Thoughts: I just don't enjoy getting this one off the shelf any more. Still a quality game, but the fun is going out of it. Downgraded from 9 to 8.

RATING: 9.9
Caylus is the Granddaddy of Worker Placement games and one I encourage anyone who is likes, or is even mildly interested in, that genre to experience at least once. If not a couple of times.

Compared to the other worker placement games, Caylus is pretty pure in its mechanics, as there is not much more to it than the tactical placement of worker tokens. Yes, there are some strategic elements revolving around whether to pursue favors (you generally need to) and which favor tracks to pursue (developing your strategy), and there are the occasional brinksmanship decisions when building castle components or when moving the provost, but the bulk of the time and the decisions are where to place your workers. 

As I categorize action selection mechanisms, Caylus has: 
* Player-directed, dynamic action set - players build the additional actions
* Multiple, sequential open selection for personal actions – openly place multiple workers, one-at-a-time, in turn order for your own use
* Exclusive usage – no one else can use the selected action
* Conflict resolution is moot - only one player can place on an action slot.
* Pay per placement – pay as you place, as opposed to per worker, or per activation mechanisms
* Post-placement resolution – resolve after all placements, not as you place (like Agricola)
* Player-driven, uncertain activation – through player movement of the Provost, not all actions will activate
* Certain action value

This game plays much heavier than other worker placement games like Stone Age because the VP conversion values of actions is not as straight forward as it is in the lighter games. But if you like worker placement games and want something heavier, this is the game to try.

While it plays anywhere from 2-5 players, Caylus gameplay changes dramatically based on the number of players. I recommend this game with 2-3 players. 2-player is zero-sum, so there are a lot of options to deny your opponent rather than to push your own agenda. 3- and 4-player games are enjoyable and emphasize taking your own path, which changes viability of many strategies, but it can run long with 4. I don’t enjoy the 5-player game because it becomes too chaotic, and it’s difficult to adopt a strategy; control just goes out the window.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The board state will also change from game to game making Caylus highly replayable.

RATING: 8
I love just about every aspect of this game. The pure mechanics, the variety, and the competitive nature. The only downside is the inability for someone to mount a comeback. Very small complaint, really for how great this game is. 12/15/2013

Verdict:

What I Like: Besides initial turn order, this game has zero luck. This means gamestate is always a product of the players collective choices. Even so, it is rare for two games to feel alike or flow similarly because the initial tiles players build drastically change what is possible/beneficial during the rest of the game. Everything is smooth as well in that it's relatively intuitive and I feel no hard edges or clunky rules while playing. This is a battle of minds and therefore winning and losing can never be attributed to anything other than the wits of the players themselves.

What I Don't Like: The mechanical levers, though interesting from a competitive standpoint, aren't enthralling from a mental one. Sometimes I feel the player who just performs adequately and effectively blocks their opponents ambitious big point grabs has the distinct upper hand all the while avoiding creativity themself, but if everyone plays this defensive style the game suffers tremendously from tedium.

RATING: 8
規則:
*起始錢 5-6-6-7-7(2p:5-5),一木兩食
*粉色建築隨機放，鎮長(長)跟監工(扁)在最後一塊
*每一輪有七個階段
1.獲得薪水，基本2+藍或綠建築給的
2.放工人直到pass，放每個工人支付1+pass人數塊錢(兩人的話有人pass另外一個人要付三塊)，如果有工人在酒館則always付一塊錢，如果是自己建築always一塊，建築物被別人放的加一分
3.從閘門開始結算到橋
4.按pass的順位付錢移動鎮長
5.按順序結算建築物到鎮長的位置
6.按擺放順序建城堡，三個不同貨物一個要是食物，有放沒蓋扣兩分，蓋最多的或得獎勵，平手順位前面贏
7.移動監工，鎮長在後或同位移動一格，在前動兩格，如果經過不同階段就結算城堡進度或得對應獎勵或扣分
*監工到城堡時結束，每個金三分，三個其它資源一分，四塊錢一分
*簡單版本可以把所有獎勵都換成三分

RATING: 5.5
A little dry for my tastes and slightly too much AP from the ever expanding decision set. The mechanics are good but the theme seems somewhat arbitrary, dare I say 'pasted on'? 

This is a very 'Euro' Euro, i.e. you push wooden cubes around so you can 'kiss some noble's ass' more efficiently.

However Caylus offers plenty of tactical decisions that require your full attention and some long term decisions, provided you are happy accepting the game for what it is - an abstract VP/economic engine game. 

Caylus is one of those games like PR where you need to already know the strengths and weaknesses of all the buildings before you buy one, so you have to put in some real work to learn the game before you can fully enjoy it.

I find the game drags towards the end (especially with 4-5 players). I don't find worker placement an interesting mechanic will resist playing. Functional but boring.

RATING: 7.5
This is a game I highly enjoy playing despite its mathiness. Since there's so little chance in the game (choosing starting player & placement of starting tiles being the only random elements) this game really is a gamers game.


Something that bothers me about caylus is the setup time, cleanup time and the fiddliness during gameplay. I own a physical copy of this game but I actually prefer to play Caylus online (e.g. on Brettspielwelt.de) because gametime is shortened dramatically, even more so than for other board games that have been digitalized. A two player game takes no more than 30 minutes, on average 20 minutes online. Offline Caylus takes easily 2-3 times as long.

Only get caylus if you have regular gaming buddies who aren't prone to analysis paralysis and don't burn out on you after repeated plays. Caylus really isn't one of those games that you play once a year. It's much more like Chess, Go and other abstract games, where certain strategies become obvious only after repeated plays.

The advantage of Caylus over Chess (besides just generelly being a better and deeper game) is of course, that it can be played with more than two players. Having gaming buddies that will play this with you about once a week or so, must be heaven.

RATING: 8.5
This game seems to me to be sort of a hybrid, combining the resource management and interdependent roles of Puerto Rico with the worker allocation and constantly developing board of Agricola. It's not too tough to teach (15 minutes or so should do it), but it's insanely layered, and it can be frustratingly difficult to find your stride, so much so that new players might feel as though they're being taken advantage of. This game is heavy on strategy, and luck very rarely factors in. Note to super-competitive types-- Playing too aggressively can easily produce disappointing results. The game seems to favor long-term strategy over short-term sniping. A great game, better with 4 or 5.

RATING: 10
The sole worker placement game I'd pick to stand in for the whole genre. Thematically superb in many ways: Pay a worker to work. Pay to get workers to work earlier, then you'll reap the benefit of first choice on resources but you'll have less jingle to spend on more workers. Fewer workers out there in workplace at large because another player's workers are done for the day? Then you'll have to pay more to put one of your own to work. Someone wants to use my building, then fine, pay me a point. Getting too ambitious? Be careful then, a bribed Provost just might shut down your building. A masterful game that rewards focused and repeated play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Has (of course) more in it than Magna Carta. Many try to explain Magna Carta's superiority with it's playing speed, but I disagree: 2h with 3 players is a good time if the game is playable. And in this case, it's almost more than that!

In the first game probably everything confuses and alternatives are neverending, but it'll get better. Even though this game is prone to mistakes, they usually hurt you so little that there is no significant in-game need to whine about the newbie-status!

King's favour is a great bonus-system and incentive to various deeds; Moving the provost is as mean a way to interact with others as usual; Turn order is cleverly build, as everybody can claim the 1st place - just by being the first in corresponding area.

One thing that bothered me was 
the lack of resources in game. Well ok, it's good to the replayability that all the buildings don't get built, but still, it's sometimes quite a rush to the production buildings...

In my case, I'll be willing to play this a lot more. But not with more than 3 players. Finding time to play this can be hard, but definitely worth it.

(Caylus was my 250th rated game.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An absolutely fantastic almost pure strategy worker-placement game. The only random elements in the game are the order of the initial 6 neutral buildings and the initial turn order. Once setup is complete, the game is entirely driven by player actions.

There are multiple effective strategies, so it's not limited in that regard. It also plays differently with two players as opposed to 3 or 4. By that I mean that different paths are viable in a 4 player game that would not be in a 2-player game and vice versa.

The only downside is that there is a lot of administrative upkeep. Points can be scored at a lot of different times during the rounds and there are just a lot of steps to go through for each round. That doesn't make the game take longer than necessary - just means that there is a higher than normal amount of administration necessary.

RATING: 8.5
Caylus.  

Really, I think Caylus is awesome, but that's just me.

For a Euro, it's complicated..  you've got a pile of pieces, tiles, a few fiddly rules and a weird premise.  When you study it, you want to make sure you fully comprehend all of the different 'mini-games' in here.. Resource trading, building, the provost and bailiff, royal favours, castle building.. sections, rounds, .. there's alot going on.

But you know, after a few rounds of Caylus, it all makes sense. The game becomes intuitive and gameplay can move fairly quickly.. provided you aren't prone to analysis paralysis in the first place.

I've played it with gamers, I've played it with 'curious' non-gamers, and it's always been a hit.  As i'm sat here trying to come up with adjectives, the word 'thickness' comes to mind - whatever that means.  

Anyways, Caylus is a good game.  Caylus is an enganging game.  It is a game that will easily be requested as it's bound to be a  good time.  However, there are some rules to learn and some complex things going on, so you'll want to be sure who you play it with.  This thing ain't everyone's cup of tea.  Seriously, Caylus is the 'Chuck Norris' of boardgames.

---

RATING: 5
First play with 5 went over the two hour mark as we grappled with the round of play structure, which has some novel but fiddly aspects. However, several rounds in, this became second nature and you could focus alittle better on what you should be doing and more importantly, what order. Like Puerto Rico, this is a sequencing of actions style of game to generate vps. I actually prefer this over PR functionwise in that the play is centralised (rather than sprawled and inaccessible), actions are translated into icons (though alittle small and browns and purples clash) which I gradually found self explanatory at a glance, with no ponderous text reading, except with player aids. Playwise this is better in that there is more competition for desired actions and so there is greater tension for me. Will play again, probably with less players. However, I can't see the appeal lasting as there is no random element in each round, except the dry uncertainty of where your opponents will place their workers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
-

This is the best game since Puerto Rico in my opinion. A no-luck strategy game with tough and interesting decisions at each turn. Decisions that force you to make a single choice among a wide range of diverse options including turn order, money, resources, buildings, and many others, and even the ability to hinder a couple of your opponents, by moving the Provost and making their last action a wasted move. You have so many choices on each turn that you wish you could choose at least two actions, but you only have one.

The game is also big on money and resource management, making it a well rounded game of both short term tactics as well as long term strategies.

8 is my tentative rating based on a single play, which I enjoyed very much  at BGG.CON, Nov. 3-6, 2005.
Update 12/07/05: Raised my rating from 8 to 8.5. This is for 3-player games. As you add more players, my rating goes down since you lose more and more control.
Update 02/18/06: Raised my rating from 8.5 to 9 (for 2- or 3-player games). For 4-player games my rating is 8 and with 5 it is 7.5.

RATING: 3
Played early in my Eurogaming life. Having played around 300 unique games in the subsequent three years, I have a much better idea of where Caylus fits in and the factors that make me dislike it and others of its ilk.

- lack of elegance. I like games where the complexity of decisions arises from reasonably simple basic rules and player interactions. Caylus is a convoluted brute, in which it feels like a lot of the complexity had to be put in by hand rather than naturally emerging. For example, the favour table is just a big bolted-on spreadsheet.

- resource conversion. I'm not a big fan of games that involve a lot of cube-juggling to turn one fairly abstract resource into another (nope, didn't like Le Havre at all). In Caylus, I don't really feel the theme gives much of a handle on why I need food to do one thing or cloth to do another, so it feels very dry.

- worker placement. I find this mechanic often leads to samey, flat, linear games in which the main form of interaction is cursing someone for taking the space you really needed to complete your laboriously calculated chain of actions. 

- too much thinking, not enough laughing. The more I play, the more I realise I'm not really a heavy Eurogamer. I like games to be not much more than 90 mins, I like some (manageable) randomness, I like ridiculous things happening that make everyone laugh. I don't like furrowed brows and people looking down at the table calculating how to milk the most efficiency out of a chain of micro-actions. That's not to say I don't like deep games, but I think there is a difference between depth and weight. 

- and finally, generic medieval themes that involve pleasing an authority figure and/or/by building a castle/cathedral.

RATING: 7
Played this for the first time last night (4 person game). My first thought was "oh crap, another boring, outside scoring track, non interaction Euro game" (actually, this game has some backstabbing and quite a bit of player interaction). My second thought (as I was being explained the rules to this game) was how am I supposed to remember all of this. The rules for Caylus are daunting at first, but once you learn the game they are quite simple. My suggestion to anyone who wants to learn this one is to watch a game being played first. If you just jump in and play, you will more than likely make the same mistakes that I made, which are: when in doubt, go for money; and being overly concerned about turn order. Money and turn order are important, but I needed to amass more supplies for building and for prestige. Another problem with just jumping in is that the game will last forever with a newbie (myself) in play. Our game lasted 3 hours. It was a fun game, but by the end, I was just hoping for the game to be over. I did come in last, so that may have something to do with losing interest. All in all, a fun game that (due to it's length) I will probably play on occassion.

RATING: 10
Caylus - the grandfather of all worker placement games and a brilliant Euro. I thoroughly enjoy Caylus - the theme of building a castle and what you do on each turn has a good tie-in, and given that there is no hidden information the game is pretty much all strategy and no luck. Caylus tests your ability to plan ahead, roll with the punches and rewards the one who makes the most optimal move each turn and is a genuine "gamer's game"

While I almost always want to play this game, finding other people who have the time + willingness + ability to learn to play Caylus (playing it well is a different thing) is no mean feat. Even so, I've no regrets about this purchase and expect it to have a long play life.

RATING: 9.3
One of my favorite. A good strategy game with no chance factor involved. Many options to be able to win a game. Tile placement and supervisor and intendant movement mecanisms are well tougth for contoling game time. Plays well at 2 or more although.

November 2007: Lowered my rating from 10 to 9.3 because I think that when you play a 3 player game, there is two main strategy. You can try to get the King's favors or try to built the most buildings. Most of the time, two players are choosing the same strategy leaving the path open for the sole player with the other strategy making the game easier for him. The only way to avoid this is to have a player willing to play on both turfs. 

Un de mes meilleurs jeux. La chance n'est pas un facteur et il existe plusieurs options menant à la victoire. Les méchanismes de placement des tuiles et de déplacement du bailli et de l'intendant sont particulièrement réussis pour le contrôle du jeux. Se joue bien à deux ou plus.

Novembre 2007: J'ai descendu la note pour ce jeu de 10 à 9.3. Ceci est du au fait qu'il y a deux stratégies possibles. Gagner des faveurs du roi ou bâtir des bâtiments. Dans une partie à trois joueurs, souvent deux joueurs vont choisir la même stratégie laissant la porte ouverte au joueur qui a choisi la stratégie opposée ce qui rend la partie plus facile pour ce dernier. La seule façon d'éviter ceci est qu'un des joueurs choisissent de jouer sur les deux terrains.

RATING: 8
Caylus is an old classic, and for good reason. It is a very well designed and good game. It is fairly interactive for a heavier Euro and can be flat out mean to players that allow themselves to be put in such positions. Still I love the construction of buildings along a joint path that all players are competing over all while fighting to most efficiently convert resources into victory points in a tense fight. The level of tension and interactivity is not often found in most modern day worker placements and that's a shame as this is a real standout game. 

I play online via the app or on BoardGameArena which has an excellent interface for it as well.

RATING: 1
UPDATE: July 2011.

From 3 to 1 after a five player game. Short Euros are barely tolerable. Euros that last more than three hours are inexcusable.

To the credit of my fellow opponents. no one suffered from AP from my last five player game; the game moved at a brisk pace.

---

Direct cross between Keythedral and Puerto Rico.

This is not my kind of game. It lacks the elegance of Keythedral and the thematic richness of Puerto Rico -- Caylus's mechanics do not mesh well with its theme.

I actually don't care much for Keythedral (except that it's quick) and Puerto Rico (except for the fact that newbies can easily grasp the game) -- two other reasons why I don't like Caylus that much.

Initially, the saving grace for this game was the provost mechanic -- I enjoy games that offer the possibility of the "group screw" -- a negotiated attempt to attack a player in the lead. However, in actuality, the opportunity to benefit from screwing over a player with the provost doesn't occur that frequently. 

UPDATE: Traded away to a better home

RATING: 7
Pros:
1. First! I believe this was the very first worker placement game. Which means it a bit more simplistic than many of the worker placement games of today. I actually enjoy the simplicity of this game.
2. Provost and the Sheriff. This game has a great mechanic where you can only select spots that the provost has moved past. Additionally, if you pick spots close to the provost, but the sheriff moves behind you, then you lose the use of that spot. Players can influence which direction the sheriff moves as well as how many spaces the provost moves. This causes a very interesting semi co-op dynamic where players close to the provost work together to move the sheriff up. Players far away work together to move the sheriff back.

Cons:
1. Simplistic: Above I said this could be a pro. It really just depends on your mood. Generally, I find this game a touch too simplistic.

Summary: This is a solid worker placement game with some interesting mechanics. I'd always be willing to play this game, but not so great that it is a must add to the collection. I would not begrudge anyone who has rated this game higher.

RATING: 8
I was dubious when Caylus appeared and instantly zoomed to an incredibly high ranking. I expected it to drop over time: it might be good, but could it be THAT good? But now I can say that Caylus is a wonderful game, reminiscent in style and quality to the enduring stars of eurogaming like Puerto Rico, El Grande, Princes of Florence, and Goa. Its strategy is deep and rich, it plays well with any number of players from 2 to 5, and it provides a game that is fascinating for its entire length start to finish. If you like eurogames, Caylus is not to be missed.

RATING: 5
Doesn't float my boat.  It's all there and all works, but is fairly unfriendly until you are several games in. The secret of these games is that the engine has to be sufficiently obscure to make the perfect strategy non-calculable.  I think it probably does what it sets out to do reasonably well, however I prefer a game that is more 'readable' and that has greater shifts of fortune to give a sense of drama.

RATING: 9
Caylus is a strong example of the genre where success relies on placing workers in the best order and acquiring the right combinations of coloured cubes etc.

It sounds dry but there are many nuances that make it more interesting. You have many ways to throw opponents off-track, there are diverse strategies and there are fun in-game decisions that modify the game's mechanisms.

There's plenty to like here if you enjoy this sort of devilish, ongoing light-math micro-management.

The overall feeling is of going about your 'worker placement' duties ... but also being like a hawk who will strike quickly to deprive an opponent of exactly what they need to do! They must never assume you will be benevolent and let them get the cubes/money they need.

What makes Caylus refreshingly different to most modern Euro games is how uncluttered it is. You look around the table and observe who needs what cubes etc, then pursue a course. There's no excessive detail or unknown variables to muddle the process. It relies on raw brain power, a bit like chess.

I was worried that improving at Caylus would require excessive mental effort but, after a few more games of it, it has become easier to focus on clever tactics and is becoming more rewarding. The game's relatively few components and good visibility also help you seize control and play-out your tactics with gusto.

Some other games, like the brilliant euro Hansa Teutonica, do seem better at allowing your intuition to help you along. But Caylus can become intuitive with practice.

Each turn goes around the table several times, with players selecting action spaces and typically blocking those spaces at the same time. You rely on whatever spaces haven't already been blocked during the turn. So you often just grab whatever best targets are still available, rather than working to a planned 'engine'. But I think that's fine because that 'routine stuff' is just a haze that might make you miss the glorious chances to mess with opponents.

However it IS a problem in that it makes Caylus much more tactical/reactive than strategic, despite it having many strategies to explore (I'm not sure this is a problem, though? - constant re-evaluation can be fun). You might not actually 'have a plan' until the last few turns (when you'll probably be trying to get a major Victory Points building without being blocked). It also means that AP (analysis paralysis) can be a constant issue, as players try to re-think (and re-math) their priorities mid-turn.

Caylus doesn't feel clunky, despite its age. It has very quick setup and teardown. You get a lot of possibilities in a fairly small playing space. Turns come around very quickly.

I also like how it's one of those games with no face-down components, which means it doesn't matter if pieces get scuffed or damaged.

It is better than the similar Orleans and Lords of Waterdeep. Orleans has arduous housekeeping to plan your actions. Waterdeep makes it really difficult to see what other players might be going for, simply because you can hardly see their face-up objective cards.

Caylus probably equals similar-ish brilliant euros like Vinhos, Bruxelles 1893, Kanban, Terra Mystica etc. I don't think it has as much spark or excitement as my current overall favourite Hansa Teutonica.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
As Caylus is often called to be the first (at least very well known) worker placement game, I wondered how this will hold up with all the refined or stream lined takes on that genre as Agricola, Lords of Waterdeep, Russian Railroads, Tzolkin, Egizia or Dungeon Lords (most of which I quite enjoy). 

Oh boy, Caylus is such a good game! This is not just plain vanilla worker placement as in Lords of Waterdeep. Yes, you have the "building action spots" aspects, but you have replacing buildings, paying your workers for putting them to buildings, increasing the price for inserting workers by passing, asynchronity of placing workers and taking action and much more. I am amazed that such a complex but also clever version of worker placement is (cosidered) the origin of this mechanism (Dominion for example is a very "pure" deck building game). I also like that you cannot gain additional workers, which is very often turning worker placement games in races to get additional workers first.

A really clever design choice is the provost. Even if you have paid the worker, he may not take his action if players choose to pay for moving the provost. The mechanism is that only actions (action spaces are all in one line) up to the provost are executed. This is such a clever way of introducing interaction, but also makes Caylus a rather mean game. Furthermore, this action affects the number of rounds in the game and open ways for more elaborate strategies.

Of course the theme is very dry (building buildings and helping the king build his castle) and the art work is not very elaborate. But to me the art has still some appeal and give Caylus a very unique charm. The component quality is rather bad with many houses and even some worker cylinders (which I would like to have a different shape) malformed. The color of 1 and 5 franc coins could have also be more different and some icons on the board or resources needed for the buildings are not easily visible.

Further plays will show, if Caylus is among my top medium-heavy Euros.

Update: 8.5 to 9.0; after 7 games I still like Caylus a lot. Matches can play out really differently. It may not really seem so at first, but in Caylus the players really create the economy by choosing which buildings are built. I like this aspect in games a lot, when players do not follow a path, but create one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.42
I enjoyed my first game of Caylus a lot, despite finishing last by a huge margin. Players take turns to place workers on an expanding range of options to gather resources or money or to build future resources. It will be very familiar to players of Le Havre/Agricola which are clear fresh implementations of the same idea (even Key Market to a degree). 
However, there is one big difference between this and its imitators, in this there is no attempt to mitigate against the player competition, in fact its actively encouraged. The game is as much about judging when to screw over another player as it is about enhancing your own position. In some ways that makes it more appealing, though in others its a very harsh first play as a result. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

All in all however this is a very solid design.

RATING: 8
Despite having been a gamer for 3 years, and one who mainly gravitates towards the "Euro" end of the spectrum - and preferring "heavier" Euros at that - somehow I only managed to play this classic for the first (and so far only) time in the summer of 2014. I had previously played Caylus Magna Carta (the card game version - we actually own it), and not been that impressed with it - and yet, despite me not being able to identify more than a handful of differences between the two, I somehow found the original boardgame version much much more satisfying. Probably this means that I should revisit the card game, although there are definitely a few differences which I do think for my taste make the original definitely better - the King's Favours (which I don't recall from the card version at all), the fact that each building can only be built once (rather than each player potentially providing their own copy), and the fact that building requires placing a worker on particular spaces rather than always being available as an action. But what most impressed me during my one play was the core of the game - trying to place workers in such a way as to try to gain the resources you need to, say, build a building, or one or more sections of the castle, knowing that the actions will always be resolved in a certain order which has nothing to do with the order in which workers are placed. VPs are scored throughout, scores stay close throughout most of the game on the evidence of my one play, and I imagine that with a bit of experience it becomes very tense at the end as players try to get their hands on the big VP buildings first. I'd be delighted to play this one again at any time. (As of January 2016 I've still not managed to play this since that first game, but I'd be delighted to do so again.)

RATING: 9
Still one of my favorite WP games. Many descendants, but no game has really replaced some of the key features that made it great - paying to place your workers and it getting more expensive as players drop out (none of this paying to recruit/give birth to more workers that seems to be the preferred WP modus operandi), bonuses (points and cubes) to the building owner when another player uses it, access to all buildings to choose from removing luck of the draw, uncertainty about whether an action will activate and the tug-of-war dynamics around that, turn order independent of seating order...  To a new player, the castle building can seem like an add-on when in fact it is the main part of the game everything else is built around.  Unlike most WP, it is quite good 2-player but plays well as all player counts (avoid 5 with AP-prone players).  Another one of the elegant Euros that has fallen by the wayside since it doesn't need expansions or updates to improve it and keep it in the spotlight, but I think this would do well with a retheme and some minor updates to make it seem fresh. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game that is credited for starting worker placement. This is a unique game where workers are placed on the board to take actions that allow you to gather resources, build buildings or work on the Caylus castle. However, the provost can shut down your action space after you have already paid your worker to work.  The provost can be bribed by different players to shut down certain action buildings making this game pretty ruthless.You are always having to adjust and readjust your plans. This game is for heavy strategy gamers and requires a lot of thinking.The game runs long for this reason at over 2 1/2 hours and maybe closer to 3 1/2 hours. I enjoy this one a lot but concede that this game may not be for everyone especially casual gamers.

Pros: Heavy strategy, deep thinking decisions, 

Cons: light on theme, long games with indecisive players,  gameplay can be cutthroat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
In Caylus players are helping to build a castle whilst building up the town around it. Each player is granted up to 6 actions per turn, as long as they can afford it. Actions are determined by the buildings placed on the board (some of the buildings grant the action of building a building) with a few buildings printed on the board.  Each worker placed on a building will cost at least one gold, plus additional gold for each player who has already passed.  If a player's building is used by another player the owner is granted a point and gold, and since most buildings are unique players are carefully considering what to build and what to use. Each building built grants points, as does building onto the castle. At the end of the game the player with the most points wins.

RATING: 8
That creepy Caylus king has been eyeing me for a while, daring me to give it a try. So I finally opened it up this year and gave it a try with my wife. And it is really great.

Because I have played so many games that are derivative of Caylus to varying levels (Waterdeep, Tzolk'in, etc.), the rules were somewhat simple and straight forward for us to understand. In fact, I think that's why I didn't really want to play it for a while: oh, it's another worker placement game with buildings and resources and scoring points? Sounds too familiar.

But it's great! The provost is such a unique and interesting mechanic to add some tension and interaction. All the buildings are out and available to see from the beginning to plan out strategies. Because of the buildings and favor tracks and castle, there are multiple ways to pivot and posture and score points. And in the end, it's another example of a dry, rules-heavy, thinly-themed Euro winning me over once again. (Plus, it played really well with 2, which makes it easy for my wife and I to enjoy.)

RATING: 9
It seems like there are more and more mediocre games being produced each year (or maybe I'm just becoming more selective about the games I like).  So, when a game like Caylus (which I believe to be legitimately on the level of all time classics like El Grande, Puerto Rico or Princes of Florence) is released, there is inevitably a hype and a backlash before it settles down to its place in a game collection.  On some level, the game is similar to Puerto Rico in that the main strategies at first blush are to use resources to either build buildings or to "ship" them to the castle for victory points.  Either strategy (or a mixed one) can win, depending on your opponents' actions.  Since the game play is so dynamic, you need to constantly reevaluate your position to try to use your resources in the most efficient manner.  But it's the royal favors element that really puts Caylus over the top.  These bonuses are available at the castle as well as on the building side of the game, and you can use them to either fill any gaps in your strategy or to push you over the edge to victory.  The knock on Caylus is its length, and there's no doubt that it is a touch long.  Maybe repeated playings will drive the play time down a bit, but, even as it stands, when immersed in the game, time flies by for me, and I consider the time it takes to play Caylus very well spent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Lots of think-ahead, which I enjoy, but I don't like the downtime.  A fast-paced game of Caylus is usually fun.  An extra point for being the first worker placement game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Until you know how to definitively beat this game due to a flaw in the game (see below for more details), Caylus can be a fun game that can keep you on your toes the entire time, and can get infinitely more fun & intense as you add more players. Your strategies must constantly shift moment-by-moment throughout this game based upon what your opponents are doing at any given second, and if you can somehow master the fine art of gaining a holistic understanding of what every player is trying to accomplish, you MAY be able to win the game -- yet there are so many offensive & defensive strategies that your opponents can use against you, there is no guarantee that your plan will be achieved! There is virtually ZERO downtime in this game -- something is happening at every given moment. Plus, there is only a VERY SMALL amount of luck in this game (if any at all) -- the vast majority it is pure strategy. There are a few big downsides to this game, however: one is that the rulebook is very poorly written, and extraordinarily difficult for new players to understand. But with the help of the additional files posted to BGG by other members, you can figure out the game. Another major downside (and the biggest problem with this game) is that my group of friends has discovered a major flaw in the game: if you only do one simple activity during the game -- building in the castle & nothing else -- you are almost guaranteed a victory 100% of the time.  This saps all of the fun & excitement out of Caylus. Up until we discovered that flaw, Caylus was a fun, challenging, and intense game.

RATING: 9.5
Played twice at BGG.CON '05... Not up to the hype. Takes too long, not very 'fun' really. It's still a good game, and fun in the way that Puerto Rico or Princes of Florence are fun. That is to say it's a lot of work... but not the kind of work you hate to do.

Update 2/18/06: I have played quite a bit. For 2 or 3 players it is a terribly good game. For 4 or 5 players it's simply terrible. I highly recommend Caylus 2 or 3 player, not so much for 4 or 5 players unless you're going for a more social, less competetive atmosphere. For me, if I want that atmosphere, I don't play a strategy game.

Update 6/12/06: I have played even more, and I've come around to like 4 and 5p Caylus more and more. 3p is still the better, more strategic, competetive game, but 4 and 5 player is still very good. It's sort of harder that way, and there are things I don't like about it as much, like starting and being low on the turn order sucks, but it's better than I gave it credit for before.

This would be a 10 if I plyed it more often (like PR)

RATING: 10
If you were only going to have one Eurogame in your collection - or one Worker Placement game, then this would have to be a major contender. Whilst not the first WP game, it is the game that defines the genre. Easy to teach and play, very difficult to master, with the tactical choices coming thick and fast. The theme, pasted on as in all Eurogames, works beautifully and feels right.

A brilliant game - a design masterpiece.

Like Arkham Horror there is pain, except this is more like the pain you get from having to go to the bathroom while at work and you can't leave your desk.  I don't like this game for many reasons. RATING: 1.5
One solo game. 

I was surprised that this supposedly terrifying euro wasn't terrifying at all. More along the lines of mediocre and pedestrian. And I didn't realise "Yo, dawg" games were so old (stuff upon stuff upon stuff). If you look at Caylus from the right angle you can see cogwheels protruding from it. 

So let's see - boring as hell, and it's not the theme or lack of one, it's that resource to victory point conversion spread sheet. I almost cried out of boredom when setting up the game, and had intervals of utter apathy while playing. Surely it plays much better than it looks - it's mildly entertaining to juggle these cubes around and go for this or that "clever" mechanism. But seriously, Rosenberg does cold calculating euros gig much better. And Puerto Rico which somewhat inspired this was much more tight and original design. The good thing that Caylus did is that people saw it went [i]"Hm, interesting, but what if I remove half of this stuff?"[/i] and so worker placements were born.

RATING: 8.5
เกมส์สุดโปรด Top 5 ตลอดกาลของข้าพเจ้า

เป็นเกมส์ที่จะให้เราผลัดกันวางตัวตามช่อง Action ต่างๆ หลักจากนั้นก็เริ่มไล่ทำ Action จากหน้าประตูอาณาจักรตามลำดับ หลังจากได้ทรัพยากรก็สามารถนำไปสร้างบ้านหรืออาคารเพื่อขยายความเจริญไปสู่ท้องถิ่น หรือจะเน้นไปพัฒนาสร้างบ้านภายในปราสาทเอาใจพระราชาเพื่อแลกแต้มคะแนนและรางวัลพิเศษต่างๆกันไป

เป็นเกมส์คิดเยอะๆเกมส์แรกๆที่ผมได้เล่นหลังจากเข้าวงการบอร์ดได้ไม่นาน และผมก็ชอบตั้งแต่ครั้งแรกที่ได้เล่น เพราะสมัยก่อนก็เริ่มจากเล่นเกมส์ปาร์ตี้ฮาๆ หรือไม่ก็เกมส์เก็บคะแนนแบบทอยเต๋าเน้นดวงตามประสา พอได้สัมผัสเกมส์ตึงๆเผาหัวเยอะๆครั้งแรกเลยติดใจและกลายเป็นการแตกแขนงเกมส์เผาหัวอื่นๆตามมาอีกเป็นยวง

ข้อดีหลักๆคือเกมส์เล่นได้หลากหลายสาย จะไปเน้นสร้างตึกสร้างบ้านบวกแต้มรอเพื่อนมาเหยียบทำแอคชั่นตอดคะแนนเล็กๆน้อยๆ หรือสายเอาใจพระราชาคอยสร้างเสริมตึกภายในปราสาทเน้นล่ารางวัลพิเศษ หรือจะดองทรัพยากรแล้วตู้มสร้างตึกพิเศษคะแนนกระฉูดเดินคะแนนที่20-30แต้มก็สุดแล้วแต่จะปราถนา แต่ละสายก็ไม่ได้โกงสุดโต่ง ไม่มีสูตรตายตัวเฉพาะ อยากเล่นสายไหนหรือจะผสมสัดส่วนวิธีการทำคะแนนต่างๆกันไปก็ไม่มีปํญหาใดๆ ทำให้อยากเล่นหลายครั้งเพื่อลองวิธีทำคะแนนใหม่ๆ 

อย่างที่สองก็คือเกมส์แทบไม่มีดวงมาเกี่ยวเลย เรียกว่าเฉือดเฉือนวัดความเก๋าเกมส์ของพวกฮาดคอร์เกมเมอร์ได้เป็นอย่างดี (อ่อนแอก็แพ้ปายยยยยย)

เกมส์แอบมีInteractionเล็กน้อยแบบหอมปากหอมคอ มีใครมาเหยียบตัดหน้าช่องที่เราอยากได้ก็มีเรียกพ่อล้อแม้กันเล็กน้อย, หรือจะแกล้งเพื่อนด้วยการบังคับตัวขาว(Provost)เดินไปกันไม่ให้เพื่อนๆได้ทำActionที่ตัวเองวางไว้ เรียกว่าเล่นแล้วไม่เงียบเหงาเฉาตายคาโต้ะเท่าไหร่นัก

อีกอย่างก็คือเกมส์นี้เล่นแต่ละรอบจะได้ฟิวลิ่งวิธีการทำคะแนนคนละแบบค่อนข้างชัดเจน บางครั้งตานี้ทรัพยากรกระจาย เหยียบช่องไหนก็ได้แต่ของ สร้างตึกกันทะลุขอบกระดานทั้งๆที่เล่นไปแค่ครึ่งเกมส์, บางครั้งตึกไม่โผล่มาสักตึก ขาดแคลนช่องหาทรัพยากร เล่นไปจะจบเกมมีตึกอยู่แค่สี่ห้าหลังก็มี นี่ก็อยู่ที่มุมมองความเก๋าของผู้เล่นละว่าเล่นแบบไหนให้สามารถทำคะแนนเพื่ออยู่รอดในสถานการณ์ต่างๆได้

จุดที่ควรระวังคือ ผู้เล่นใหม่ๆจะงงกับระบบการสร้างสิ่งก่อสร้างภายในปราสาท,การจบแต่ละยุคและการโดนลบคะแนน รวมไปถึงระบบ  King Favour ที่มีเงื่อนไขต่างๆที่อาจจะทำให้ผู้เล่นสับสนได้ ตรงนี้ต้องสอนให้ดีและระวังหรือเตือนเพื่อนๆในวงกันสักหน่อย (ยิ่ง King Favour แถวสุดท้ายนี้ เล่นกับหลายวงแล้วชอบเข้าใจผิดกัน คนที่อ่านกฎเก่งๆอังกฤษชับๆก็อธิบายเพื่อนในวงให้ดีๆหล่ะครับ)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many games have the "get resources and then convert to victory points", but this one does it all out, with a dozen different paths, some of them requiring three or four steps each. One of the nice things about the game is how different buildings built earlier in the game can change the opportunities for later strategies, so every game plays very different.

But with ten different colored pieces, a meandering board that goes this way and that, a variable turn order, and a board where the functions get covered over by the pieces, too much of the game's thinking comes just from trying to figure out and remember the game state, which is not a good thing.

The game is 20-40% too long and way too fiddly. There's more struggling with the mechanics than playing against your opponents. And some of these mechanics are simply superfluous.

RATING: 5
A dense and dry worker placement game which I've played sporadically over the years. It's horribly abstract even by Euro standards, and cluttered with random tasks that mostly involve sucking up to the king. I always end up exhausted after playing this because I'd have an expression of bewilderment frozen on my face for two straight hours. 

For me, Caylus has simply been outclassed by subsequent games which have taken inspiration from it and built something better from there. Probably the only reason why I'd come back to this title is because of that darn fickle provost. It's a remarkably layered mechanism which throws players into a game of chicken to see who will end up controlling the provost.

RATING: 7.75
I have no idea why Caylus has been compared to Puerto Rico. Both have wooden cubes and are in the typical German game mold but that's where the similarities end.There are a wealth of options that  require a few games to fully explore but good players will easily beat poor players. One must concentrate in order to get the best from the game. 

Potential Kingmaking if you play with less than serious gamers. I think the hype is real because we all want to see a serious contender to Puerto Rico (in terms of a combination of interesting mechanics, tension and just good gaming magic).Sadly, Caylus is not it.

Overall, it's a little dry, the board looks unattractive, the art amateurish almost and rather linear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[2011-01-23]
Nagyon erős játék. Egy kétszemélyes játék alkalmával ismertem meg, de biztos vagyok benne, hogy 3-4-en működik igazán tökéletesen. Ketten is teljesen élvezhető, nem véletlenül a magas pontszám.
Fa, kő épületek, lakóházak, presztízsépületek, várépítés, különböző módon aktiválódó épületek. Összetett játékmenet, biztosan több játék kell a jó stratégia megalkotásához, emiatt és az épületek biztosan más időben és módon való felépítései miatt nagy újrajátszhatósági faktorú játékról van szó. Átlátható tábla, szép komponensek. A játék összetettsége miatt van esély az elhúzódó gondolkodási fázisra, de mivel egy-egy munkást felváltva teszünk le, így nem olyan nagy a holtidő. Egyedül az intézőt érzem a játék gyenge pontjának, pedig akár a legérdekesebb elem is lehetne. Mégpedig azért, mert óriási konfliktusforrást jelent. Az, hogy egy-egy épületet elfoglalnak egymás elől a játékosok, az teljesen belefér, viszont az intézővel egy-egy játékos munkását akár teljesen kizárhatjuk a játékból és ezzel akár adok-kapok is kialakulhat az már soknak tűnik. Párok esetében pedig erős sértődöttség is keletkezhet. Ha pedig megegyeznek a játékosok az intézővel való csatározások elkerülésében, akkor talán egy érdekes rész esik ki a játékból. Szóval ez nagyon partifüggő elem. A családi verzió is kitalálásra került, így akár könnyedebbé is lehet tenni a játékot. Mindenképp helye van a top játékok közt.

[2011-10-02]
A jubileumi kiadással volt szerencsém a második Caylus partimat megejteni. Felemásak az érzéseim. A lapkák, a fém pénzek csodaszépek, de a tábla szerintem nem sikerült jól. Nagyon sötét, nekem kevésbé átlátható, mint az eredeti kiadásé. A játék továbbra is nagyon jó. Nagyon mély. Annyiban javult a véleményem róla, hogy nagyon is jó elem a kisbíró a játékban. Nagyon drága végig kiszúrásra használni, nem éri meg hosszútávon egyértelműen. De a játék végének kiváltásban jó taktikai elem. A játékban levő sok lehetőség viszont engem frusztrál. Érdekes módon, jobban, mint például a Vulgariban, pedig abban sem kevés a lehetőség. Nem lesz a nagy kedvencem sosem a Caylus, de nagyon jó játék továbbra is. 

[2013-01-26]
Ezzel a kisbíróval valahogy nem tudok megbarátkozni. Sikerült kipróbálni öten, izgalmas így is a játék, de a bíró akár egyszeri mozgatása is helyezésekről dönthet. Olyanokkal játszva, akiknek nem többedik partijuk mindig kijön ennek királycsináló volta. Ez persze valószínű a legtöbb ember szerint nem hibája egy játéknak, nálam viszont egyértelműen nem tetsző elem. Így eggyel rontok a ponton.
8->7

RATING: 10
As a fan of perfect information games this game really hits home.  The great thing though is that while there are an absurd amount of options initially, you are only allowed the ability to do one thing at a time, options get used up, and the turns get faster and faster. 

Still, it can be a long game, especially with A/Pers. Even suffering from downtime I find the system so rewarding that it merits and awards the patient.

This really takes some of the best things from Way out West's (and now Byzantium's) action selection and gives them growth and ownership.  When I first played this I gave it a 9.  After a couple plays I see the error of my ways.

For some crazy reason our last game took 5 hours, and we were so into it, we didn't realize that the game had taken so long.  A game so engrossing time disappears.
..-+!10!+-..

UPDATE: Hitting the table again and loving it.

RATING: 8
Tight game of money and resource management with opportunities for defense and bluffing.  Rewards strategic thinking as well as tactical opportunism.  Many decisions to be made every turn, with minimal downtime.  Challenging, accessible, multiple paths to victory.  Every game is different due to the variety and timing of resource availability.  Like Puerto Rico, there is a long rules explanation at the beginning that seems overwhelming, but it begins to click early in the game, and seems simple and intuitive by the end.

RATING: 8
I always feel like I'm one opponent's worker placement from total disaster in this game.  I like that.

So many neat subtleties to this one, and different strategies to try.  Rush the castle, screw the castle and just build buildings, play the favour track, command the provost.  The bit where you can keep placing workers after somebody passes, but it costs more, is just so deliciously evil.  

I don't have to think too hard playing Puerto Rico or Power Grid anymore.  I have to think during Caylus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the most intense worker placement games I've played. The provost adds a nice mean streak to the game, as a costly option to deny players to perform their chosen actions. These actions have to be bought and money is very tight in this game, making it extra frustrating when your actions are cancelled. When players pass the cost of these actions increases and this is another way to screw with the plans of other players. But, players already have a lot to handle: they have to gather a lot of different resources and money to be able to buy these actions and help build the castle. Turn angst is very tense in this game and there is a wonderful turn order mechanic.
A game of Caylus is a great experience. It's constant pressure and demanding gameplay is both wonderful and exhausting. This alone makes it a great game. I also like the very colourful components.

RATING: 9.5
