UPDATE: I think the other element that is fascinating with this one is how which buildings actually provide benefits are set by the players. You can burn some actions to ensure that you get the benefit of the buildings, which is a costly tradeoff. Also, the order in which players pass affects when players pay to move the track, which is another aspect to this unique mechanic. Truly a classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's no luck beyond the initial building selection. The idea is that players are builders helping to build the king's castle (3 parts: dungeon, keep, and towers or something like that). You use initial buildings (place your workers, in turn) to generate resources, which you use to build better buildings (which generate more/better resources or help in other ways) and to build parts of the castle. Scoring happens when each of 3 stages of the castle are done, or when the game timer marches forward to specific intervals (player actions can affect this speed). In addition to producing resources, buildings/workers can change turn order, reduce the cost of placing other workers, and earn king's favors. You also earn favors each turn by contributing the most to the castle that turn. What are favors? Well, little freebies - ways to get extra resources, or build buildings more easily, or extra cash, or extra VPs. When the game ends (castle complete, or game timer moves to end), most VP wins (unused resources and cash are also worth some VP). 

Sure, this is a good game, but is it THAT good? I don't think so. I think I'd prefer a bit more randomness in the game - more than just the initial shuffle of the pink buildings. The game is good, but I have more fun with other games.

RATING: 8
Caylus is the 500-pound gorilla of Eurogames: long, unwieldy and full of imbalances and rough edges. All stuff I generally dislike in games, but in Caylus, it somehow falls together pretty well. The game has very few random factors and instead offers the players the possibility to determine the game flow by choosing which buildings to erect.
The production buildings are sometimes said to be too important, but I'm not sure whether I agree. Then again, I've played only a few games, so what do I know of strategy? I'm still having fun trying to figure that out.
I used to rate this a 10, but downgraded it because of its excessive length. I wouldn't want to play this anymore with more than 3, unless all players are *really* fast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Caylus is one of the first eurogames I bought; and I bought it purely on the strength of its core feature: the holy trinity of road, provost and bailiff. I still think it's one of the very best worker placement -- which is to say, action-drafting -- games ever made. Some particularly enjoyable features are the ability to build over early production buildings, the variable-length queue and its implications on both building placement and action timing, and the ever-looming spectre of the castle. There are multiple viable strategies and many opportunities for screwage.

It can inspire AP and it does have the potential to run slightly long, but it's a brilliant design that holds up extremely well against its many imitators.

--

I had thought the new wave of worker placement blah blah blah games did not live up to the standards set by classics like this one, but picking it up again for a dozen plays after a year of dust-gathering was a disappointment.

Oh, it's still an excellent design and still better than most of its imitators. But some elements are clunky -- like scoring points for placement on buildings -- and it tends to ever so slightly outstay its welcome. Such tension as there is derives from tedious, indirect competition; the denial aspect of the road is perhaps the most interesting part, but it doesn't go quite far enough -- the systems in Vanuatu is an example of a far better take on the same principle.

Mostly what I am saying is that my tastes have changed. All that slog through resource collection etc. -- it just isn't interesting enough to deserve its length.

Ratings history: 9 -> 7

RATING: 7
[RGG 2005 First Edition w/ replacement coins] {City building, economic; resource-management, variable-player-order, variable-building-powers} Caylus is a good game; esp. for those who like Euro games.  It is elegant, multifaceted and well balanced.  It is surely well play-tested. It is very dynamic; therefore, deep analyzing is not necessary. However, it caters for both tactical options and strategic planning.

Player interaction is strong because the buildings are shared among the players and players have to compete for their functions. It's heavy - players have to focus and make many agonizing decisions. It is better than Puerto Rico in one aspect: the player order can change during the game.  Therefore, it does not suffer from the painful sitting order problem like PR does.

The theme is ok but not as vivid as PR or E&T. The board is colorful and informative but not attractive. The building tiles are informative, too.

In all, it's a good strategy game but it is not 'fun' for me as other strategic games. 

This is very great attempt for first-time designer.  Keep up the good work, William!

RATING: 8
Oof.  I have a hard time determining how I feel about Caylus.

I think the game itself is fantastic.  This is one of the best "multiple paths to victory" Euro-games I've seen.  The worker placement mechanics work extremely well, there is a constant scarceness of resources and money that keeps the game tense, and the fact that you earn points from opponents using your buildings (and vice versa) adds an amazing amount of tactics and strategy to the game.  The board is pretty, the provost mechanic adds some important interaction, the bailiff keeps the game from reaching a stalemate...  I can't imagine the amount of work that went into perfecting the design on Caylus.

That said, I don't enjoy playing it very often.  I think the main problem is this: there are very few other games I have seen that inspire quite as much analysis paralysis as Caylus.  I think the game itself is partly to blame by its design: the fact that you don't get resources until the end of the turn, and you need very specific combinations of resources to work on the castle means that people spend countless minutes dithering "Wait, by this point I'll have two cloth and three stone, and then I'm trading the stone for two food, and... wait, let me start over."  

I don't think I will -ever- agree to five-player Caylus again without a chess clock or something.  I like Caylus a lot, but it should be at most a ninety-minute game; past that I'm getting jittery and bored with it.  Unfortunately, it can tend to go onto two to two-and-a-half hours, and I just don't find it interesting enough to keep my attention that long.

So, in summary: fantastic game, needs to come packaged with turn timers.

COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: The "food" and "stone" cubes are pretty hard to distinguish.  This is even worse on the buildings where the tiny pink and grey cubes are in the costs--it can take some squinting and good lighting to tell these apart.  Might want to mark these up or ask other players.

RATING: 9
[u]Key Words:[/u] Worker Placement - Medieval - Luckless - 2-5 players - 2h

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] Great tense & meaty game.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Excellent. Still good after hours of play.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

A very solid design that leaves nothing to chance.

Players add buildings to the road and supply resources for the king's castle for victory points. You will constantly find yourself jockeying for position, either for the turn order, the resources or special buildings, or to be the first to offer batches of resources to the king to get ever more powerful favors. Once people start passing, everything becomes more expensive - except your own buildings. Provided, of course, that somebody else didn't already use it.

If the theme doesn't sound exciting for you, I can tell you the game when played by serious players is always tense. There is no single route to victory; the huge special buildings give many points, but cost a lot of resources and effort to buils - in my more recent experience this is not always worthwhile.

A monumental game by Ystari.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Worker placement game with a medieval building theme. Players select actions by placing their workers onto buildings on the board, which allow the gathering of resources or the use of those resources to construct further buildings. These new building serve as action selections in future turns and bestow the owner victory points when used. Over the course of the game more and more actions become available and players can assist in constructing the castle, leading to the primary way of obtaining victory points. What stands this game apart from many similar efforts is the Provost, which is used to prevent players from obtaining the benefits of the actions they have taken and brings an interesting amount of player interaction into the game. When first released 'Caylus' was an innovative game which has over the years led to many imitators, but at the time of writing nearly a decade after its original release it doesn't quite posses the attraction of some of the games it spawned.

RATING: 9.5
One of the most brilliantly designed games EVER, in my opinion, let alone among worker placement games.  Incredibly balanced, thinky, zero-luck game with superb player interactivity, that is relatively easy to learn and pick up after a long layoff.  Some minor quibbles: it is a tad dry, and it is prone to AP in the later stages of the game as the number of resources you have to manage, or plan for, increases.  This is the kind of game where you really need to pay attention to and anticipate your opponents' moves.  If a player isn't good at doing that, they are going to lose badly every time.  Plays very well at all levels -- 2, 3, or 4 players.

RATING: 5.5
Essen Math trade 2011.

UPDATE: Finally played this one. What to say about it. 
Is it a good game? Yes.
Did we had a fun time? Meh, it was ok.
Do I see the replay value? Defenitely.
Will it get replayed? Defenitely not.

Why not? In its heart, Caylus is another soulles cube pushing euro. It might be one of the best balanced games, but as the area it is in is very crowded I have lots of other games I'd prefer over it. Also because it is almost completely devoid of theme. 

If I want a nice Euro, I grab Macao or Puerto Ricoh.
If I want a touch of medieval Europe, I'll grab Kaiser, Fief!, Princes of Florance or Traders of Genoa instead.
And most of all, on all points Caylus has been superseded by one of my favorite games: Carson City. 

There is absolutely no reason for me to keep this one.

However. If you do not own that many games and are looking for one of the best euros with a great replayability, Caylus might be just your thing. Well balanced, engaging gameplay and a very clear game-board. Just don't expect any meaningful theme.

Sold it off in Aug 2013 for €25,-

RATING: 5.5
This will likely continue to change as I play more - it started as a 9.5, then 9, now 8.5.  That said, a wonderful game, with meaningful and tense decisions, difficult money and resource management, and practically no downtime.  Like Goa, you want (and even need!) to do everything, but don't have the resources to do it.  Rules are simple and elegant.  Time just flies by when playing, which is one of the highest compliments that can be paid.  Minor quibble - the money sucks (fixed in the 2nd edition).

Update - Absolutely bombed when I tried to introduce it to my newish game group.  The one other 'true gamer' in the group immediately took a liking to Caylus, the rest couldn't figure it out regardless of how many sample turns we took.  Downgraded to 7 - if I need only "true gamers" in order to play, it will not see as much play as one would like.

Update - Downgraded to 6.  A minor move, sure, but every time I'm putting together a collection of games to bring to game night, I look at Caylus, think about it, and say "Nah."  I still like the game, and personally it's probably a 7 for me, but if I can never get it to the table, and furthermore know I [i]won't[/i] get it to the table...then it isn't as good as it could otherwise be.

Update - Downgraded to 5.5.  An even more minor move, but man, when I was at BGG.con, we checked out Caylus, set it up, and then were like...nah.  Put it back in the box, and back into the game room.  Nothing more needs to be said.

RATING: 6
Wow.

Amended rating - Wow, what a turnaround! I initially started out with this as a 9.5. Over time, my enthusiasm has dropped to the point where I would probably not be overly disappointed if I never played Caylus again. Far too long and repetetive for what it is, as many have pointed out. I think one other aspect that bothers me is that I go through time and effort to gather materials to build a certain type of building, and once it is built, it belongs to everyone. I get no pride of ownership, no veto power so I can guarantee myself the use of "MY" building. There is an illusion of control over what I can build and what path I choose to take to victory, but in the end I really have very little control over what happens due to the chaotic nature of all players scrambling over the common pool of resources. While this is a good thing in the eyes of many players, it is just not for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Caylus strikes the right balance between player interaction, buildings (actions), and point optimization that subsequent worker-placement games commonly screw up (I'm looking at you Le Havre). The game is a bit inelegant what with the four favor tracks and 10 separate turn phases. But it has depth and tension.

The game is clearly at its best with 3-4 players. With two, the the provost is effectively out of the game. With five, it's too chaotic. I also wonder if the game shouldn't be a bit shorter.

UPDATE: I find myself wanting to play Caylus more and more. I've increased my rating to 8. Four players is my sweet spot: a perfect balance between chaos and control. The game length is also significantly reduced with experience. Caylus drives me crazy trying to balance my long-term goals against my short-term needs. The clincher, however, is that I find myself worrying about everyone else's actions as well, which heightens the tension and increases my enjoyment. A very good game in a genre I'm not typically fond of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whoo boy there are a lot of decisions to be made in Caylus.  You have to manage resources and money, but the heart of the game seems to be timing everything correctly.  Everything from gathering resources just in time to build, getting into the Inn just when you really need low cost workers, to the very important (and very changeable) turn order.  The flow of the game is easy to wrap your mind around, but not all of the subtle timing issues.  Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At a first glance Caylus is a complex game of construction and economy. It may be a little bit daunting for the non-gamer but somebody with some experience it is fairly easy to learn and play. The object of the game is to score prestige-points by contributing to the construction of the king's castles and the accompanying town. There are many ways to score points, and several long term and short term strategies emerge.

There are many rules and effects, but all of these can be 'read' from the symbols on the board. The game mechanics are nice and simple and the system as a whole is balanced. As an added bonus, it plays relatively well with two player, even though it is better to play with the maximum of five.

RATING: 6.5
First Impression: 

Worker Placement at its best.

The game is deep, the interaction is high, the options great and well balanced, and although there is a sense of accomplishment there is no (or limited) economic snowball. The provost (or however its called) is a mechanic that I particularly loved.

This is a cutthroat game. Player bashing is at certain opportunities available, but the target player must usually ask for it by taking the risk. There is also blocking and rushing the end and other opportunities to hurt players. I can see a certain category of players to dislike this, but in all honesty, I like it even more for this!.

I really liked Caylus, and to me it seemed much more fresh than I expected. A very good cutthroat game, I look forward to playing more.

RATING: 7
Playing this after Caylus Magna Carta; I like Caylus better. Tiles look better than cards and also get rid of the random draws from personal decks, and increase the feeling of competition over a limited resource. Lack of cards also means that every action in Caylus is placing a worker somewhere, which is simpler than having some actions involve your cards.

The "micro-move" feel of CMC that I disliked is mitigated by the feeling that Caylus has a better-defined arc and long term strategy. Players collectively build up a city, almost with the feel of an economic game, and I can see this more clearly in Caylus.

The chicken game of moving the provost is not my favorite, but it's at least clear what's going on. I do think it stunts the growth of the city as players may be afraid to use buildings that might not get to work. Only a few (I think exactly three) buildings give both the building owner and the building user a perk at the time the building gets to activate.

Overall, for now, I think Caylus is preferable to Puerto Rico (because it's less opaque) and Agricola (because the interaction is more interesting).

RATING: 10
Oh, I love this game! There are so many decisions to balance. The decisions are both meaningful and fun. I constantly have to think about what my opponents are going to do. As with most worker placement, some of that is of the form, "I need cloth, and my opponent needs cloth. Is he going there next?" However, many of the choices feel much weightier. The jousting arena is amazing but you assess your opponent's ability to use it effectively. Your opponent just gained the spot that lets him move the provost (or the bailiff, I never tell those apart). Does that mean he wants to play forward, and I can follow him? Or is trying to reign everyone in for a round? The only complaint I have is that it can be hard to look at the board after a long game and tell what you've accomplished.

RATING: 9.8
Simply the best modern euro game.  I play this online all the time.  The game has layers man.  So much tension.  A marvel of design.  Try to exploit the system with two tensions hanging over you, the provost and the need to win in the castle constantly or fall behind.  

Unlike other euro games where the managing of resources is arbitrary, this game forces you to pay careful attention to your money and your cubes.  That is what separates Caylus from the other euros in which you simply cleverly convert stuff into other stuff and figure out puzzles.  In Caylus, you use the resources to control the position!  You use the efficiency game to control the positional game.  If you lose either game, you are done for.  

You use the resources and the threats they represent to influence what the other players can and can't do.  This combined with the reward of building better and better buildings with which to make a pseudo-engine makes for the finest modern euro ever made.

The power of the modern euro to provide FEEDBACK, i.e build buildings and score points is what makes them so popular.  The fact that there is a DEEP and elegant game involved is what separates Caylus from the pretenders to the throne.  A castle for a king indeed.  

Decisions per minute is huge in this game.  Agonizing decisions per minute is huge.  All the decisions are interesting in trying to find what you earn and what you give up and gain positionally.

Nothing comes close.  Caylus is the finest of its class.  If you like to build stuff and manipulate a system and manipulate tempo, you need this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Now I'm a degenerate, cube-fondling eurosnoot, and this game has elements I go for:

Coloured resource cubes, a-lingual tiles to be placed, an esoteric bidding system to determine player order and a mediaeval king to suck up to.

But it has no soul, no joy, no pleasure, no sense of achievement. It's a  mind-numbing, multi-dimensional spreadsheet of a game. Imagine being a clerk hand-writing actuary tables in a Victorian insurance company for forty years.You've just played Caylus.

I really, really, REALLY want to like this game, but I don't. Hell, even the man on the box lid looks like he wants nothing to do with it!

RATING: 9.5
Quando comentei sobre Tzolk'in, escrevi que acreditava ser o melhor "Worker Placement" q provavelmente jogaria. Bem não sei se me enganei, mas no mínimo Caylus chega tão perto que é difícil escolher.

Outra coisa que me atrai é o fato de, apesar de claramente existir umas opções mais vantajosas que outras, todas elas têm o mesmo valor de 1 moeda, cabendo à dinâmica do jogo e dos jogadores, além da ordem de jogo decidir qual vale mais a pena pegar primeiro.
Por último, as construções feitas ao longo da "estrada" dão uma rejogabilidade muito boa, além de (junto com o castelo) dar a sensação que algo está sendo construído por vc.
Enfim, ainda considero Tzolk'in um jogo mais completo, com estilo diferenciado, mas Caylus não deixa nada a dever e tem elementos de um jogo simples e ao mesmo tempo complexo do tipo "esquenta-mufa" que eu adoro.

RATING: 8
It's embarrassing that I finally played this after being told (for years) how awesome it is. Even when compared to its descendants (ie, Agricola), Caylus holds up as a complex game that rewards intelligent play- and the occasional dirty deed.

Deployment costs make HR management trickier than in most games, and the variable player turn order is something I do not recall seeing in any other game so far. 

Being able to claim neutral space for your own war effort is also a really neat mechanic, as is the residual gain in prestige and/or resources when another player utilizes one of your buildings.

The game can seem tedious, because there is so much going on, but the more you play Caylus, the brighter it shines.

RATING: 10
Not sure if we'll get this now that we have both Le Havre and Agricola, but we'll think about it.

Grant got it for us.

This is lookin' like a very good game.  Pure euro.

This game has clawed its way to the top of our euro pile.  The ways that the players can manipulate the jobs (placement options for the workers) really sets this game apart from other worker placement games like Agricola or Dungeon Lords (both of which we enjoy).  The lack of randomness is a definite plus here.

There are a bunch of different paths to take during the game.  Afterwards, we're left with that great feeling of "yeah, if I had just done that differently I might of won" instead of feeling completely lost or that things just tend to average out in the long run.

RATING: 7
One of the best pure worker placement games after [gameid=22545], which is saying something in this increasingly crowded genre.  Lots of competition, and doesn't seem as much like multiplayer solitaire as some of the other games that use this mechanic.  This is certainly long and intense for a Euro, but it's got enough to make it worth it.  The decisions are so frequent and interesting that time flies when I play, and before I know it, the game's over and two hours have gone by.  Has a perfect amount of complexity for a game of its type.  I can see why this is loved by so many, and vilified by so many others.  Never has a game managed to be so perfectly balanced and full of great decisions while managing to have such a thin theme.

RATING: 10
This was the first heavy game I ever tried, our fourth acquisition, as we went from Fluxx to Killer Bunnies to Ticket to Ride to Caylus.

As such, this has been my "gold standard" of excellence, my #1 favourite and highest rated game. Every new game gets compared to Caylus, and so far, all have been found wanting. Some have come close, but Caylus is still the undisputed champ.

This is an amazingly deep game, yet at its core, so simple (crappy rulebook notwithstanding). Put your guys on the board, then in order, do what each spot says. And the spots are all so simple, collect this cube, turn this into that, the vast majority are only of a few different types (collect cubes, convert cubes, etc).

RATING: 6
I went through an initial love affair with the game, but with many repeated plays the game felt too long for how repetitive each turn was. At first, there is a fascination with all the different buildings and how the order in which they come up will effect the game. With repeated plays however this immense variability turns out to be more illusory- the real dynamic aspect of the game revolves around the competition for favors, and the provost and drafting mechanics integrate well into that sub-game. If you aren't playing that particular sub-game in a given turn then you are trying to compensate by using other peripheral methods, but as a general strategy their viability is questionable at best. Ultimately, Caylus is a game that offers real competition, but is a bit boring in how repetitive and dry it is.

RATING: 8.5
Wow.  I thought this game was going to be too primitive, since I had played a lot of the games that came after it, but boy was I wrong.  This game is impressive.  The idea that the players build the "worker placement" locations is brilliant, and the provost mechanic and the special locations help keep things tense right up until the end.  

I really wish I had gotten into this game much earlier.  It has all of the good parts of the modern Euros, but has a very clean layout, easily understood iconography, and very evenly paced gameplay.

Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 5 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 1h00 à 2h30/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 12 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu de stratégie quasi-pure (très peu d’éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné).
! Sans aucun hasard après la mise-en-place initiale.

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Nombres non-déterminés.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
- Aide de jeu : non-inclus, j’aurais aimé qu’il y en ait au moins 1.
- Adversaires : plus agréable lorsqu’il est joué avec des joueurs de même calibre.    
- Déroulement scripté : peut favoriser l’adoption de "scénarios répétitifs" d’une partie à l’autre.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
® Je recommande son essai car il pourrait être apprécié par d’autres joueurs.

L’un des premiers jeux "Euro" que j'ai essayé et qui avait alors impressionné la novice que j’étais à l’époque. Cependant, il s'est révélé trop stratégique pour moi et je n’ai aucun plaisir à subir des parties où des adversaires passionnés maîtrisent par coeur toutes les tactiques d’ouverture et leurs enchaînements. Par contre, j'accepterais peut-être de l’enseigner à des nouveaux joueurs ayant des aptitudes pour ce genre de jeu auquel cas je préférerais guider la partie sans y jouer moi-même.

RATING: 9
This is the father of all worker placement games and in a lot of ways, I think it has yet to be surpassed. Blocking opponents from taking actions has been done a thousand times since this game was released, but most modern worker placement games have gotten rid of any direct player interaction. Caylus has that in spades. Every build action affects what the other players can and will do, passing early raises the price of actions for everyone else and bribing the Provost creates all sorts of negotiations leading to a tense and delightfully spiteful game.

RATING: 6
This and Go are, I think, the only two board games I've played that I think I may not be smart enough to do well at. Part of the problem with this one is that I play it so infrequently (three times since 2007) that I totally forget how to play and strategy in between. It's also fairly fiddly and there are a lot of really important things that are easy to overlook. Having said all that, something about this game makes me want to keep playing it and improve. It's a great intellectual challenge, more so than any other worker placement game I've played (though I have more fun playing, for example, Agricola). It is possible that it would get stale for me if I played it more often, but for now I'd rate it at the lower end of my favorites.

Edit: I've been realizing that, across all forms of entertainment, I tend to overrate things that I can appreciate aesthetically but don't enjoy. My previous rating/comment did not demonstrate that I have very low interest in actually playing this game.

RATING: 4
I don't understand all of the hype on this game. I've only played twice, but neither time was what I'd call a "fun gaming experience." To me they've taken the elegance of Sackson's Bazaar and veiled all of the resource trading/manipulation bits behind an ineligant pasted-on theme with additional manipulation elements. The result becomes a nearly solitary exercise in resource manipulation for an extended period of time. There are many game in different genres that I'd rather spend the time playing and enjoy more. Perhaps due to our inexperience we're not opening up to lots of table talk and deal-making and that's the problem. That would at least make the game more interactive, but wouldn't change the overall gaming element of maximum resource manipulation. People say there are lots of choices. Really? It seems fairly scripted since the best thing to do is maximize those resources with each action... and the choices really are just different avenues of how you manipulate those resources. Ehhh. It's not a bad game, but it's not a very fun one either.

RATING: 8
Played this game 1x. It was a 4 Player game, all experienced boardgamers. At first overwhelming...even for these guys. But they were hooked after the first 2 rounds. With rules explanation it took us about 2 hours. 

There is so much going on, it will take 3/4 plays for making the right choices at the right moment.

The day after the game, 2 guys of my gaming group emailed that they were excited about this game and were planning to buy it. That doesn't happen often...

I'll rate it an 8 at this point, the game needs more playing for my final rating. But we know for sure already that this is a fantastic game.

One player stated that for him this game was a mix between Puerto Rico and Goa with great Player interaction.

I've seen comparisons between Keythedral and Caylus on BGG, but besides collecting goods there is - in my opinion - no link between these games.

I'll come back after more games of Caylus...

I'm back...played my second game of Caylus with the same group as mentioned above. Totally different from the first game, but the same player won.

The first game was more a castle race, now it was a building game. The player who ended as 2nd didn't build at all in the castle. He made one mistake the last turn in not being able to use a architect. He could have build the 25 points cathedral, and that would have been a victory for him.

The winner was about 15 points (!) ahead of us. Number 2-3-4 were very close.

I've to mention that the winner is really a great gamer, he does win most of our games.

The game has lots of 'layers', there is much to discover. It will take quit some games before this game reveals it's secrets...

The winner mentioned that he didn't follow a certain strategy but that he tried to react on how we played.

Great game, but my rating won't change until I know the game better.

Played it again, the first time another player won! I still don't do well in this game, maybe it's bigger than me :). But I'll come back! I find it hard to develop a strategy in this game. The options are so many and what are the right ones? Well that's the question some players know in my group. I still don't know the answer...yet!

RATING: 10
In this fine game players work to collect resources needed to build a castle for the king and gain prestige for themselves.  This game is heavy and strategic, with many different paths to victory.

Caylus is a game where players have many things they want to do, and just not enough money / actions to get them all done.  It is a game of timing, where choosing to help build things 'first' can make a big difference in the end.  It is also a game of deciding when to help or hinder your opponents.  All in all, Caylus is a very fun, fast-moving game of resource management and building.  Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One game with 3 players, another with 4 players.

Like: Caylus does many things very well with the worker placement mechanism that I wish more worker placement games would emulate. The provost is simply a brilliant game element which transforms the board into more than just a menu of actions that players choose from. The penalty of not having your workers activate if they are ahead of the provost on the road is harsh enough to focus a lot of the play and interaction around the provost, which raises the complexity of player interaction in the game far above the basic blocking interaction that many worker placement games settle for. Some of the players can collude to ensure that another player's worker on a space does not activate (by moving the provost back far enough along the road); this is highly significant because typically the most valuable spaces are concentrated toward the end of the road on any given turn. 

Caylus doesn't settle for using the provost and blocking for player interaction though. You can collect a lot of points and resources by constructing the right buildings for your opponents to use. The race for the king's favors in exchange for adding sections to the castle is intense and requires careful timing based on your opponents' moves and resources available. Lastly, I really like that as players stop placing workers, it gets more and more expensive for the remaining players to place further workers. This both rewards efficient use of your workers (so that you can pass earlier) and prevents any one player from getting too far ahead of the other players by placing many more workers. As an aside, I also admire the simplicity with which Caylus controls each player's worker supply. Instead of forcing players to take actions to get more workers, Caylus gives you all of your workers from the beginning and controls the number of workers you place by the number of useful action spaces available, how many players have passed in the round, and how much money you have available. I much prefer these soft methods of control as they lead to more strategic depth.

A few other elements I enjoy: The board's appearance is very clean. I like the choice of color scheme and the brightness of the tiles. I'm a big fan of the ability to build over the starting buildings with the green income buildings, which reduces the number of action spaces available (thus increasing the tension) and forces players to use the more advanced buildings (which other players have built) for resources. The game plays quickly, especially if players move the provost ahead of the bailiff frequently. The game is also very easy to set up and tear down, especially compared to something like Agricola. 

Dislike: Behind the awesomeness of the provost and the other fun player interactions lies a dry, themeless resource conversion game. None of the buildings have names or distinctive art, and the effects of the buildings are limited to awarding resource cubes, money, allowing you to build other buildings, or allowing you to convert resources into money, money into resources, resources into points, etc. The resources themselves are also nondescript. There are brown cubes, gray cubes, blue cubes, pink cubes, and yellow cubes; aside from the brown cubes corresponding to wooden buildings and the gray cubes corresponding to stone buildings, there is not much thematic reason for why certain game aspects require certain cubes. It's hard to feel like you are doing anything more in the game than trying to maximize your points relative to the other players. The victory point and money favor tracks also feel very lazily designed and uninteresting.

Overall: A fantastic game that is a must-play if you enjoy worker placement games. This is a much more competitive game than many euro games, which earns it big points with me. My rating would be higher if the system behind the provost and player interactions was not so dry and themeless. This is the main reason I don't own this game; I already have so many other games which are just as well designed but pack in much more fun and excitement. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I can see why this game is so well received, and while I've enjoyed the games so far, I'm not completely sold on the game. I love the build-as-you-go path of actions, and there are a lot of options available to the players. The value of the actions also seems to vary quite a bit depending on how far into the game you are.

The biggest downside is that the turns get excessively long the further into the game you are -- more tiles and options open up, dragging the game to a slow grind as more and more calculations are required. The brisk pace at the beginning is soon replaced by a plodding finale.

Also, the game can get especially nasty, as players get targeted and hurt by actions meant to target the leader. The bridge/vizier movement (any actions after that counter are not taken) can be especially vicious... If someone wants to target the leader and the current last place person happens to be in the way, that last place person suffers even more. In fact, someone who feels "out" of the game early can heavily influence the game simply by jockeying that token around and threatening to play the kingmaker -- an element so easily abusable that it must certainly be intentional, which seems odd.

The game features many excellent strategic options and sports some very interesting and game elements. With more play, and better skills to evaluate the worth of buildings and actions, I could see this becoming an 8 or so... Still, Puerto Rico and Aladdin's Dragons provide some of the same experience, but in half the time or less.

RATING: 9
Somehow this went from "a game I should try sometime" to "a game I must have" after a random recommendation got me looking into it more... and I'm really glad I picked it up.  I don't think I've suffered that much brain burn from a first play since my first game of Agricola... so Caylus is in great company in my book :laugh:.  The second game was probably even more of a burn... but I felt more in control too... and even won against one experienced and two inexperienced players.  

I want another couple of plays to comment further... but on top of everything I love about the worker placement mechanic I found the potential of the shifting board, minor bouts of aggressive play with the Provost and game timing, and trying to keep your original plan intact throughout the turn even when you got all the placements you want extremely enjoyable.  A worthy classic I'm hoping to explore more!

RATING: 8
Had I played this 3 years ago I imagine I would have been impressed by Caylus just as most people had, but now with the numerous action selection games available I only found it to be excellent.  The many interlocking parts between the worker placement, the resource management, the castle building and the favor track do present the players with an interesting canvas to work with.  There weren't any one specific route to victory but I believe being the first to choose for the better part of the game really gave me the edge over my opponents (even after committing a couple of early and newbie mistakes), something they failed to acknowledge the importance of.

My only problem with Caylus after just one play is how processional each round seemed to be.  This will of course be tested further but I can see how certain buildings will always be preferred over others, and thus will be built (as well as claimed) first.

RATING: 9
After 5+ Plays: A very different game with 2 rather than 5, but great fun either way.  Many different viable strategies.

After 10+ Plays: This was one of my first euros, and it remains one of my favorites.  My favorite aspect of Caylus is the type and level of interaction.  I have a strong preference for indirect interaction in multiplayer games e.g. denying you what you want by taking it first, rather than attacking you directly.  Caylus has this in spades, but also interestingly integrates some more direct screwage in the provost mechanic.  I like the provost far  more than most direct interaction though because you have a choice how open to attack to leave yourself by the riskiness of your placements, the money you keep in reserve, and how early you pass for the round.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Caylus is a solid game in terms of mechanics, but it falls into an awkward spot in my collection where I have other games I prefer that do the same thing.

It's worker placement where each turn likely brings new action spaces into play - I'd probably play Agricola first.

You go around acquiring cubes that are used to complete tasks (building the castle/new buildings) for points - I'd probably play Lords of Waterdeep first.

The combination of those two game devices puts it in its own little worker placement niche, and it's sometimes nice to pull it out. But it's not the primary option in my collection.

RATING: 7
This is a great game. Serious resource management with lots of timing details. I like all of the turn and event order mechanisms. The randomization of the first production and manufacturing buildings as well as the choices buildings the individual players build make every game subtlety to wildly different. My one complaint is that it is a bit long. Now that I have played Caylus Magna Carta, I would choose that one over this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
号称无随机性德式策略游戏的典范，其实还是有随机性的，起始的中立建筑就是。凯吕斯城对人数的要求极高，人数2人，3人，4-5人时策略路线和玩法都有些不同。势均力敌的2-3个人体验的话，游戏就相当于一个零和游戏了，损人则利己；但如果体验人数到4-5人时，游戏就有点外交合纵连横的味道了，总之没体验过的一定要找机会试试。。。
【关键词】国王的奖赏，主城/城墙/塔楼，木屋/石屋/旅馆/荣誉建筑，贿赂市长，监督前进，黄金，行动依次结算

【推荐度】极高 【工人放置，中重度德式爱好者
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
